Synopsis:

Upset about moving from a big city to a small town, teenager Zach Cooper (Dylan Minnette) finds a silver lining when he meets the beautiful girl, Hannah (Odeya Rush), living right next door. But every silver lining has a cloud, and Zach’s comes when he learns that Hannah has a mysterious dad who is revealed to be R. L. Stine (Jack Black), the author of the bestselling Goosebumps series. It turns out that there is a reason why Stine is so strange… he is a prisoner of his own imagination – the monsters that his books made famous are real, and Stine protects his readers by keeping them locked up in their books. When Zach unintentionally unleashes the monsters from their manuscripts and they begin to terrorize the town, it’s suddenly up to Stine, Zach, and Hannah to get all of them back in the books where they belong.

results.description:
There is nothing quite like being in the presence of Abraham. Fortunately for us in the Boston area, Esther Hicks and her crew make it a point to visit with us twice a year. What a blessing. This time we're back to the Boston Marriot. A great room and the first place I saw Abraham back in 2008.

Now it's time for the Fall visit so let's go!

If you've never been to an Abraham workshop there's no time like NOW to do so.

The energy. The people. The conversation. It's like getting together with a few thousand of your closest friends and laughing, sometimes crying, and for sure to raise your vibration through the roof and set you up to have the best week ever.

If this is your first Abraham workshop here's how it works: Esther Hicks takes the stage promptly at 9am. She explains the structure of the day (about 1 hour of Abraham and then a 20 minute break, rinse and repeat 2 more times), and explains how Abraham will select people to come up to the hot seat and ask a question.

Then, she closes her eyes and gets still. Really still. When her eyes open it is Abraham looking out at us.

If you want to get to the hot seat (I've been in it twice) get really clear, I mean really clear, about what you want to ask. Be at ease. Be confident. Be clear minded and focused. If you are unsure, you may be passed over. Or you may be called up and Abraham will give it their best to help you become unstuck. To drop the resistance you may be feeling. To empower you to be who you truly are - you are Source Energy! You are the energy that creates worlds focused here to be and do and have everything you desire!!

If you don't get called up, don't worry. Your question will be answered one way or another. That's just how it works.

So are you in?

I've lost track of how many times I've been to see Abraham (this may be my 7th?), but in the 8 years that I have been immersed in the teachings it just seems to get better and better. Truly the leading edge of thought. If you're reading this, congrats! You are on the leading edge. Something inside you had brought you to this moment so take the plunge and reserve your seat today!

What do you say? Are you in?
results.name: Let's Go See Abraham and Esther

group.name: Exploring the Teachings of Abraham (Esther Hicks)

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who decide to join get a $10 deduction from membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

results.description:
PITCHING IT! with producer/talent agent Marilyn Atlas

Workshop and Pitch Session

You've written a great screenplay.  Maybe it's won awards or placed well in highly competitive contests.  Now, you believe it is ready for "prime time."  Or maybe you've completed an outline but are wondering if your story is on the right track.  How do you pitch it and find out? In this 2 1/2 hour workshop, you'll learn the do's and don'ts from entertainment veteran, Marilyn Atlas.  Enrollment is limited to 20 so be sure to sign up early and receive your member discount.  Deadline for sign-ups is extended to Tuesday, October 6th. 


NOTE:  If you have any issues with Paypal, you may write to Genine directly at [masked].  Send a check to 293 Franklin St., Newton, MA 02458, made out to Harvard Sq. Script Writers, indicating you want to reserve a spot. 


$45.00 for non-members
$40.00 for members of Harvard Square Script Writers or Women in Film and Video/NE   

 What students will learn: 

1)  What to include and not include in your pitch 

2)  Adapting your pitch to the audience you're pitching to 

3)  Mistakes that writers make when pitching 

4)  Understanding the market and projects worthy of pitching 

5)  Importance of the hook 

6)  Refining your pitch.   How to distill the essence of your story into short, sharp, easily digestible bite-size parts.  

Learn to strike the right balance between brevity, colorful detail and cliffhanging suspense.  The pitch is not a tease or a trailer, it is a way of leading your audience through the major beats of the story, with attention paid to how the protagonist changes along the way. 


Know the difference between a log-line, an elevator pitch, and a 10-15 minute pitch. Learn the importance of tailoring your pitch depending on who you're pitching to. Discover effective buzzwords to use in a pitch.


Marilyn will work with brave volunteers to tighten and reveal the compelling narrative thrust of your story... assuming there is one!

++++++


About Marilyn:

An award-winning producer and personal manager of actors and writers, Marilyn R. Atlas is equally at home in the worlds of film, television, and live theater. Among her credits as film producer are Real Women Have Curves for HBO, A Certain Desire, starring Sam Waterston, and Echoes, which won the Gold Award at the Texas International Film Festival. 

In addition to producing a variety of programming for the cable/ pay TV market, Marilyn served as a production consultant on the film Call Me.   

Marilyn is a member of the National Association of Latino Independent Producers. She has spoken at their Writers' and Producers' retreats, and the DGA-sponsored LA Asian Film Festival, as well as various other symposia for the Sherman Oaks Experimental College. Additionally, she was a guest lecturer in the Writing Program at USC for several years, where she taught a class on creating three-dimensional, non-stereotypical characters.   

Her clients have appeared in shows such as Star Trek, Fringe, Pretty Little Liars, 90210, Revenge, Hart of Dixie, NCIS:LA, True Blood, Dexter, Chuck, Castle, and Criminal Minds. In addition, her clients have worked on feature films such as Holes, Transformers, and Ted 2.   

Recently, Marilyn has been developing a miniseries and TV pilot based on the Gary Phillips series of novels featuring Martha Chainey. Her Lifetime movie The Choking Game, based on the YA book by Diana Lopez, aired in summer 2014 and she also spoke at the 2014 International Women's Writer Festival in Italy.   

Marilyn is the co-author of a screenwriting guide called Dating Your Character, an organic approach to character creation, slated for Stairway Press's early 2016 catalog. She is also featured in the book Write Now! from Penguin/Tarcher.

results.description:
Trail: Mt. Pemigewasset Trail Mountains: Mt. Pemigewasset (2557 ft.) Rating: Easy/Moderate Total: 3.6 miles (round trip), approximate time 3-3:30 hrs. Elevation Gain: 1150 feet Date: Saturday, October 10th, 2015 Location: 11:30am Flume Visitor Center North Parking lot. We will leave promptly at 11:45 so don't be late!

Time for our Annual Fall Foliage hiking trip. This is a relatively easy hike and we've done this one before. You can use the bathrooms in the visitor center before and after the hike. Last time some people ended up taking the flume gorge tour by mistake instead of hiking. This hike is FREE and starts in the parking lot, so if you're in the visitor's center, and they ask you to pay, you're on the WRONG trail. Here are some excerpts from the AMC White Mountain Guide: This trail runs from the Flume Visitor Center parking area to the summit of Mt. Pemigewasset (Indian Head), where excellent views can be obtained with modest effort. Grades and footing are mostly easy. The trail reaches the vertical summit cliffs very abruptly, so care should be exercised. The trail follows the bike path north from the parking lot for 150 yd., turns left on a gravel path and passes under old US 3 in a tunnel, then turns left and crosses a brook on a bridge. It goes over a small rise, then turns sharp right and ascends under both lanes of the Franconia Notch Parkway. It enters the woods at .4 mi. and crosses several small brooks on log bridges, then turns right and then left along a small brook, climbing moderately. At 1.3 mi it squeezes around a large boulder and swings left uphill, climbing a bit more steeply to the ridgecrest, which it follows to the left (south). It passes the junction with the Indian Head trail on the right at 1.7 mi. and reaches the summit ledges at 1.8 mi. At the true summit which is just beyond the first ledges and a bit to the left there is a fine northeast view.

Driving Directions I-93 to Exit 34A to the Flume Gorge Visitor's Center Parking lot. Driving time is approx. 2.5-3 hours from Boston without stops.

Transportation is the responsibility of the individual.

However, our members are good about offering carpools. Please note if you need a ride, what town you are coming from and/or what T stop you can meet at. Same for those that can provide a ride. Since it is quite a bit of a drive we will have a carpool fee of $10 - payable to the driver. This will help towards gas & tolls.

Stuff to bring: backpack, lunch, water (2 liters), hiking boots, extra layers of clothing if it is cold,
results.name: Fall Foliage Hike - Mt Pemigewasset

results.description:
HE NAMED ME MALALA
Synopsis:

HE NAMED ME MALALA is an intimate portrait of Malala Yousafzai, who was wounded when Taliban gunmen opened fire on her and her friends’ school bus in Pakistan’s Swat Valley. The then 15-year-old teenager, who had been targeted for speaking out on behalf of girls’ education in her region of Swat Valley in Pakistan, was shot in the head, sparking international media outrage. An educational activist in Pakistan, Yousafzai has since emerged as a leading campaigner for the rights of children worldwide and in December 2014, became the youngest-ever Nobel Peace Prize Laureate.

By: EILEEN FISHER & TakePart
Event Description

Recognizing the importance of the film He Named Me Malala, TakePart has joined forces with EILEEN FISHER INC. to offer our valued readers complimentary tickets for the theatrical release of (our parent company) Participant Media's latest documentary in Boston!

**Please note that the screening time is subject to change by the theater, If changes are made, an e-mail will be sent with at least 24 hours notice.

AMC Loews Boston Common 19 - 175 Tremont Street Boston, MA 02116 - View Map https://youtu.be/vE5gSHJkusU

Join up with Meteor developers, enthusiasts, and first-timers on the weekend of October 10-11 for the Boston instance of the 2015 Meteor Global Distributed Hackathon! Working in teams of 1-4, build an awesome Meteor app in 24 hours and submit it as your entry in this global competition sponsored by MDG. Whether you’re a professional Meteor developer or just getting started, we’d love to have you join us! No worries if you don’t have a team beforehand, just show up and we’ll help get you joined in.


We’ll start on Saturday at 2pm with a quick intro before breaking off into teams and kicking off the hacking. Teams are welcome to work at the Zagster office in East Cambridge until 8pm. We’ll have plenty of free Meteor swag on hand, as well as copious food and drink to fuel your coding. On Sunday at 4pm we’ll reconvene at Zagster and all teams will have a chance to show off their work.

Schedule of Events


Day 1: Saturday, October 10

Intro and Kickoff: 2pm

Doors Close: 8pm

Day 2: Sunday, October, 11

Doors Reopen: 1pm

Team Demos: 4pm


** If you are coming to the Hackathon, please join this Meetup event, then register here: http://info.meteor.com/2015-hackathon**


Prizes will be awarded for the following categories:


- Top Overall Submission

- Top Five Overall Submissions

- Most Innovative Collaborative App

- Best Meteor and IoT Submission

- Best Game

- Best App with Less than 100 Lines of JavaScript, maximum 80 characters/line

Have you been diagnosed with diabetes or pre-diabetes and think that your diet is now destined to be limited or boring?

Are you unsure of what you can or cannot eat on your low-carbohydrate/low-sugar diet and are looking for ways to eat fabulous, yummy food?

Do you just want to learn new cooking techniques or new recipes that include ingredients that your physician or dietitian has told you are included on your prescribed diet?

Join expert Dietitian Melinda Maryniuk (Joslin Diabetes Center) and Celebrity Chef Tiffani Faison as they discuss ways to change your lifestyle and diet to help you to improve your health and cook delicious meals that fit into your dietary requirements, are fun and easy to prepare, and will delight your friends and family.

You will taste the recipes that the Chef cooks and will leave these classes with dietary information and with recipes that you will love to prepare at home! You will also learn that your future is destined to be gourmet, fun and delicious!

About Chef Tiffani

Tiffani Faison is an American chef, restaurateur, culinary consultant and television personality. Her restaurant “Sweet Cheeks,” (opened in the Fall of 2011) is a Southern-style barbecue restaurant located in Boston, MA. Her newest concept “Tiger Mama” will be a Southeast Asia concept that will capture flavor profiles from Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, and beyond. Tiffani was the runner-up on Top Chef Season One and competed on Top Chef All-Stars and Top Chef Duels.

This is a ticketed event-for tickets go to http://www.eventbrite.com/o/foodicine-health-inc-8383710024

Have you been diagnosed with diabetes or pre-diabetes and think that your diet is now destined to be limited or boring?

Are you unsure of what you can or cannot eat on your low-carbohydrate/low-sugar diet and are looking for ways to eat fabulous, yummy food?

Do you just want to learn new cooking techniques or new recipes that include ingredients that your physician or dietitian has told you are included on your prescribed diet?

Then the "Cook Gourmet For Diabetes" class is for you! Join Celebrity Chef Tiffani Faison and Dietitian Melinda Maryniuk as they discuss ways to change your lifestyle and diet to help you to improve your health and cook delicious meals that fit into your dietary requirements, are fun and easy to prepare, and will delight your friends and family.

You will be able to taste the recipes that Chef Tiffani prepares and will leave this class with dietary information regarding diabetes and recipes that you will love to prepare at home! You will also learn that your future is destined to be gourmet, fun and delicious!

About Chef Tiffani

Tiffani Faison is an American chef, restaurateur, culinary consultant and television personality. Her restaurant “Sweet Cheeks,” (opened in the Fall of 2011) is a Southern-style barbecue restaurant located in Boston, MA. Her newest concept “Tiger Mama” will be a Southeast Asia concept that will capture flavor profiles from Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, and beyond. Tiffani was the runner-up on Top Chef Season One and competed on Top Chef All-Stars and Top Chef Duels.
results.name: Cook Gourmet For Diabetes-Celeb. Chef Tiffani Faison/Dietitian Melinda Maryniuk

results.description:
MUSIC! MAYHEM! MUSICIANS PLAYING ON TREE LIMBS! FREE! DANCING IN THE STREETS! COSTUMES!  NO CARS!!!!

This is better than the Harvard Sq event tomorrow why? because Harvard Sq. tomorrow (Sunday) gets packed.  Whereas at this event you can see the musicians up close because there are 30 bands and they are playing all over the place. And you can move around to the music you like easily.
  If you prefer join us at 6 PM @Saccos pizza (43 Day St.), where we regroup at their huge bar.

Join the mayhem.
Bewitching horns, music, & costume. Come along & see if you can stand still. THERE ARE EVEN MUSICIANS PLAYING IN TREES! I mean ON trees.
FREE. There will be "30 bands performing at 6 staging areas" in Davis Sq.

ORLEANS-- 3:45
HONK! FEST--4:15
WE REGROUP-- SACCO's, 6:00 & rest your ears there with some soothing normal voice level conversation & Meetup socializin'
HONK! FEST-- 6:45 --we return to the Mayhem.
You lose the group and the Meetup is over for you. So stay with us.

At Orleans, snatch a refreshment & introduce yourselves. 

<a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B2daMVvOpdQ">

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B2daMVvOpdQ

results.description:
Open since 1999 Organic Garden Cafe is the premier raw vegan restaurant in New England! COMPLEMENTARY TABLE APPETIZERS are provided to the group every 2nd Saturday monthly from 4-5:30pm! The menu offers a wide range of choices to delight your appetite including: juices, smoothies, soups, nori-rolls, spring rolls, pad thai, nachos, salads, pizza, burgers, pasta, tacos, gourmet daily specials, and deserts! www.organicgardencafe.com

Directions from Rte. 128 (including Boston Rte. 93N to Rte 128): Follow Rte 128 North. When Rte 128 North splits to the left from Rte 95, be sure to stay on Rte. 128 "North to Gloucester". Follow Rte 128 to Exit 22E (Beverly Rte. 62). Follow Rte 62 approx. five minutes to Cabot St. and turn right. We are one block before the Cabot Cinema on the right. Note: After Rte. 95 North and Rte. 128 split (north of Rte. 93) the numbering system for exits changes and exit numbers begin decreasing.

Directions from Boston via Rte. 1 [see above for Rte 93N Directions]: Take Rte. 1 North over the the Tobin Bridge. Follow until you see signs for Rte. 128 Gloucester and Rte. 95 North and take that exit. Bear left to take Rte. 128 North and stay on Rte 128 until Exit 22E (Beverly Rte. 62). Follow Rte 62 approx. five minutes to Cabot St. and turn right. We are one block before the Cabot Cinema on the right.

Directions from Salem: Go over the bridge from Salem to Beverly on Rte. 1A. Just after the bridge bear right onto Cabot St. Travel for 1 1/2 miles till you see Cabot Cinema and Organic Garden on the left.

Commuter Rail:
Newburyport/Rockport Line

Note:  Screening time is confirmed for 4.20pm. Tickets are on sale so please get yours now to avoid disappointment! Click here.

This meetup is full and there are people on the waitlist. If your plans change, please change your rsvp.

See you at the movie!

In the timely thriller, 99 Homes, charismatic and ruthless businessman Rick Carver (Michael Shannon, Take Shelter “Boardwalk Empire”), is making a killing by repossessing homes—gaming the real estate market, Wall Street banks and the U.S. government. When he evicts Dennis Nash (Andrew Garfield), a single father trying to care for his mother (Laura Dern) and young son (Noah Lomax), Nash becomes so desperate to provide for his family that he goes to work for Carver—the very man who evicted him in the first place. Carver promises Nash a way to regain his home and earn security for his family, but slyly seduces him into a lifestyle of wealth and glamour. It is a deal-with-the-devil that comes with an increasingly high cost—on Carver's orders, Nash must evict families from their homes. As Nash falls deeper into Carver's web, he finds his situation grows more brutal and dangerous than he ever imagined. Directed and co-written by Ramin Bahrani.


http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/25/movies/in-99-homes-a-man-buffeted-and-then-manipulated-in-floridas-foreclosure-disaster.html

.

results.description:
Connors Farm has again invited Social Fun to their yearly Corn Maze Night, but this year Connors  Farm is only offering their special deal to just us and not to the public or other Meetup Groups due to the extreme popularity of this event! This will be our 7th year attending this!  This is going to be an Amazingly Fun Event with a ton of members coming from many Meetup groups!

What to bring: Please Dress in layers + boot/sneaker as it might get cold at night and please bring cash and a flashlight!

The Deal from Connors Farm: 

1.  HauntedCornfield  called Hysteria is $25 a person by itself and it was Voted one of the “Top 10 Corn Mazes”  by the Travel Channel

2.  Flashlight Maze (Maze of Darkness) is $13 a person  ---Note  This maze is now  WORLD famous when a family called 911 when they could not get out of this Maze!............ Crazy fun!

http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/10/couple-lost-in-corn-maze-call-911.html

3. Bonfire, music, cider and cider donuts  (which are oh so yummy) $10 a person and is NOT being offered to the public or other Meetup Groups.

That a total of $48!.....Luckily we worked out a deal where our members  only pay $20 a member.  What a bargain I know and it’s also $5 under the price of the Haunted Cornfield by itself!

Timeline 

5:00PM Biagio will be to the left of the Main Farm stand (not far from where the cash registers are) and others are welcome to join us early if they want

5:30PM Find Biagio or one of my fellow Head Organizers to the left of the Main Farm stand to find out how to get this $20 deal!

5:30PM to 6:30PM Mix N Mingle with Meteup Members from 10+ invited groups to the left of the Main Farm stand. Members can eat/drink, buy Connors Farm yummy farm products, walk around the farm, feed the farm animals and start to form groups of 8-10 for the Haunted Cornfield (Hysteria).

6:30PM Leave in groups of 6 to start lining at the start of the Haunted Cornfield which this year is behind the farm stand.

When your group is done with the Haunted Cornfield please enter the Flashlight Maze (Maze of Darkness). This is fun as you can enjoin getting lost with other group in
the maze and Mix n Mingle in the maze too!.....Note: Please try to enjoy ALL this for about an hour as the bon fire will not be ready until  after 8:30PM.

8:30PM Gather and enjoy the bonfire, music, cider and cider donuts in the area about 1000 feet behind the farm stand.

======================================================

EXPECT SOME DELAYS and EXTRA WAIT TIMES with this large of a MEETUP group so please bear with us as we'll do our best to accommodate you all to maximize your fun!
Also, use this wait time to Mix n Mingle with your fellow Meteup members!

Please triple check you can make this event and make sure you leave extra time to get
here by car as there might be some additional traffic due to the Topsfield Fair
nearby, also find alternative routes to get there to get around that traffic so
you do not get stuck based on where you are coming from.

=========================================================

Parking is now across the street from the farm stand and on the side of the road. It will be crazy busy so the  earlier you come the easier parking will be for you.

PLEASE try to carpool so everyone can park nearby. Remember 200 members, 1 per car = 200 cars, 2 per car – 100 cars, 4 per car = 50 cars etc. Understand the math. Lol

Always try to help T-Bound members get to this event by offering rides etc. from your local T-Stops. 

If you need a Ride please list and an event comment  what T-Lines and T-Stop you can be picked up at. Also, please offer to help pay for gas or buy something at the farm stand for the person offering you this lift.

If anyone wants to give me a $1 for setting this up, that be great since  I am taking a day off from work to run this event for you as I now work weekend afternoons and nights.

Thanks and enjoy life

Biagio
results.how_to_find_us: Find Biagio or one of my fellow Head Organizers to the left of the Main Farm stand to find out how to get this $20 deal!
results.name: Social Fun Corn Maze Night at Connors Farm

results.description:
What: I'd love to lead a pack of zombie assassins to Danvers for some zombie shooting on October 10th Saturday. Rain Date: Oct. 17th. 

 SHOOT “LIVE” ZOMBIES on the area’s ONLY Zombie Paintball Ride. Our tractors are gassed up and our trailers are ready to roll. Hop on board and man your battle-station at one of the mounted paintball guns. SHOOT “LIVE” ZOMBIES- nuff’ said. You CAN’T miss this http://hysteriadanvers.com

We will meetup here when you get there:  The tractor can take 15 people at a time. So we should go in as one group. 

You will recognize me by...I'll be wearing a Tom Brady Patriots jersey orSuper Bowl XLIX hoodie if it's colder than 40C.


Website is here: http://hysteriadanvers.com/

YOU MUST BUY YOUR TICKET IN ADVANCE. Here is exactly what you should get and where to get it: http://hysteriadanvers.com/tickets-3/

PLEASE NOTE THIS IS WEATHER DEPENDENT. I will update this event no later than 2pm on the day of if we need to postpone. The alternate date will be October 17th.
results.name: Zombie Paintball

1.  HauntedCornfield  called Hysteria is $25 a person by itself and it was Voted one of the “Top 10 Corn Mazes”  by the Travel Channel

2.  Flashlight Maze (Maze of Darkness) is $13 a person  ---Note  This maze is now  WORLD famous when a family called 911 when they could not get out of this Maze!............ Crazy fun!

http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/10/couple-lost-in-corn-maze-call-911.html

3. Bonfire, music, cider and cider donuts  (which are oh so yummy) $10 a person and is NOT being offered to the public or other Meetup Groups.

That a total of $48!.....Luckily we worked out a deal where our members  only pay $20 a member.  What a bargain I know and it’s also $5 under the price of the Haunted Cornfield by itself!

Timeline 

5:00PM Biagio will be to the left of the Main Farm stand (not far from where the cash registers are) and others are welcome to join us early if they want

5:30PM Find Biagio or one of my fellow Head Organizers to the left of the Main Farm stand to find out how to get this $20 deal!

5:30PM to 6:30PM Mix N Mingle with Meteup Members from 10+ invited groups to the left of the Main Farm stand. Members can eat/drink, buy Connors Farm yummy farm products, walk around the farm, feed the farm animals and start to form groups of 8-10 for the Haunted Cornfield (Hysteria).

6:30PM Leave in groups of 6 to start lining at the start of the Haunted Cornfield which this year is behind the farm stand.

When your group is done with the Haunted Cornfield please enter the Flashlight Maze (Maze of Darkness). This is fun as you can enjoin getting lost with other group in
the maze and Mix n Mingle in the maze too!.....Note: Please try to enjoy ALL this for about an hour as the bon fire will not be ready until  after 8:30PM.

8:30PM Gather and enjoy the bonfire, music, cider and cider donuts in the area about 1000 feet behind the farm stand.

======================================================

EXPECT SOME DELAYS and EXTRA WAIT TIMES with this large of a MEETUP group so please bear with us as we'll do our best to accommodate you all to maximize your fun!
Also, use this wait time to Mix n Mingle with your fellow Meteup members!

Please triple check you can make this event and make sure you leave extra time to get
here by car as there might be some additional traffic due to the Topsfield Fair
nearby, also find alternative routes to get there to get around that traffic so
you do not get stuck based on where you are coming from.

=========================================================

Parking is now across the street from the farm stand and on the side of the road. It will be crazy busy so the  earlier you come the easier parking will be for you.

PLEASE try to carpool so everyone can park nearby. Remember 200 members, 1 per car = 200 cars, 2 per car – 100 cars, 4 per car = 50 cars etc. Understand the math. Lol

Always try to help T-Bound members get to this event by offering rides etc. from your local T-Stops. 

If you need a Ride please list and an event comment  what T-Lines and T-Stop you can be picked up at. Also, please offer to help pay for gas or buy something at the farm stand for the person offering you this lift.

If anyone wants to give me a $1 for setting this up, that be great since  I am taking a day off from work to run this event for you as I now work weekend afternoons and nights.

Thanks and enjoy life

Biagio
results.how_to_find_us: Find Biagio or one of my fellow Head Organizers to the left of the Main Farm stand to find out how to get this $20 deal!
results.name: Social Fun Corn Maze Night at Connors Farm

results.description:
Advanced experience level only. Very dark, slippery rocks around the lighthouse for best view. Very dark, obstructed walking at the Fort. Easy access to the bridges. Small group, because there isn't much space to spread out.


There are three potential targets for shooting tonight: the bridges around Jamestown. If you come from the west (Rhode Island or center MA), you will cross the Verrazano Bridge, if you come from the east (eastern MA), you will cross the Clairborne Pell bridge.


Here is the Google map with markers and comments (Points A, B, C, D are for the bridges, EFG for the lighthouse).


We will meet up at one the parking lot of Beavertail light, see "where to meet" for exact coordinates.


The light is challenging to shoot, as it is not well lit, which is good for Milky Way or star trails. Capturing the light as it goes around needs light painting or very high ISO (12.8k) shots for definition. 

Topics to consider: star points and trails (or cloud streaks) at the lighthouse or in both locations and scenic bridge shots, for which you are on your own. Clairborne is best shot from the east side, there is no good vantage point with parking on the west side. The map link above has suggested vantage points (D/E for Clairborne and F/G for Verrazzano)


Suggested equipment: aside from seasonally appropriate clothing, gloves and hiking boots, zoom lenses for the bridges. At the lighthouse, anything from super-wide to medium zoom will work.


Beavertail Light:

Jamestown Verrazano Bridge

Claiborne Pell Bridge:
results.name: Beavertail Lighthouse, & Jamestown Bridges

results.description:
Hi Everyone,

I missed out on the last few group events and am excited that some of you got to enjoy the 'new' Ariana, which is right down the block from where I work now.

So, I figured since I have to work on October 10th, I might as well plan an event that is nearby in a place that most people seem to enjoy.

The topic is a big one: "Morality"....what does that mean to you? Is it a 'pure' concept or more subjective...do you see it from a purely personal point of view, or a more global point of view...is there any difference? What informs your sense of morality...religion, spirituality, what you were taught as a child, what you've learned as an adult, a teacher, a school, a course, a book?

Let's discuss over dinner.

PS/

As per usual, I reserve the right to postpone/reschedule this event if there are less than 4 participants.
results.how_to_find_us: Ask for Beverly's Table
results.name: Discuss 'Morality'..

results.description:
lluminus is Boston’s "nuit blanche", a free nighttime festival of creative innovation that will take place on the weekend of 10/11 October.


This public celebration will feature large-scale projections and light installations alongside immersive sound, performance, and multimedia experiences that reimagine the city at night.


Illuminus will transform Boston’s streetscapes into a vibrant urban canvas where regional artists, designers, creative technologists, architects, performers and fabricators converge to showcase their most thoughtful, innovative, and imaginative works.


The festival will provoke and inspire, celebrating the creative approaches to art, culture, and community that form the foundation of a thriving and dynamic city.

Here is the official website and here is the Facebook fan page.

I assume that this will be challenging to shoot, as the crowds may not allow for tripods and the light projections will be dynamic, i.e. requiring high ISO, short exposures, but you can try to blur the action into something artsi, it's the best place to do so. Super wide to medium zoom lenses will work, but you want to use something that is fast, i.e. has a large aperture.
results.how_to_find_us: It'll be a big crowd, no formal group meeting.
results.name: Illuminus Boston 2015

results.description:
A field trip for an evening of great music!

Buy your tickets here:
https://regent.primetix.com/Tickets/?perfid=1789

Let's take a ride to Ahhhhlington for Two of the best tribute bands in concert representing two of the biggest international performers in American music history.

Hey Nineteen - A Tribute to Steely Dan
Hey Nineteen is the Nation’s top Steely Dan tribute band! An 11 piece group of professional musicians with the theoretical knowledge and musicality required to master the complex music of Steely Dan. They have packed venues throughout New England and are well known for their high energy show as well as their “spot on Steely Dan sound!
Hey Nineteen will amaze you with their exacting solos (as originally recorded), vocals, harmonies, and musicality, all while keeping you moving with their high energy show.
Hey Nineteen a Tribute to Steely Dan is comprised of top professional musicians, many of whom have performed with Grammy- winning, international artists. Hey Nineteen brings the big hits and the deep cuts, from ‘Do It Again’ to ‘Your Gold Teeth II’, from ‘Reelin’ in the Years’ to “Doctor Wu” and many more.
More on Hey Nineteen here: http://hey19band.com/

Don Campbell: Celebrating the Music of Dan Fogelberg
Singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Dan Fogelberg was a multi-platinum selling artist, with hits such as “Leader of the Band”, “Longer”, “Same Old Lang Syne” and a large and diverse catalog of over 20 albums. He passed away in 2007 after a three year battle with prostate cancer.
Dan remains a huge influence and musical hero of Don’s. On November 13, 2012, Don released a double CD, Kites To Fly: Celebrating the Music of Dan Fogelberg and in January, 2013 began presenting live performances of this music around his own busy schedule of Don Campbell Music shows.
More on Don Campbell here: http://www.doncampbellmusic.com/dan-fogelberg
____________________________

Important: RSVP'ing here does not get you a ticket! Please follow link above to buy your tickets.

PRESHOW DInner for our group will be arranged close to The Regent if sufficient interest is shown in this event.
results.name: Hey Nineteen An Evening of Steely Dan & Don Campbell An Evening of Dan Fogelberg

results.description:
Dry Land is the story of a pregnant teenage girl living in Florida, and her friend, and their difficult journey to secure an abortion. This powerful play also addresses issues of eating disorders, suicide, race. I will be speaking on behalf of the reproductive justice oriented group, Boston Doula Project, at the official post play discussions on October 10, 17, and 23rd. While this is not an official Knapsack event it would be wonderful to have our community come out to support the arts, myself, and gain a new point of view regarding the abortion debate. If others are interested then I'd love to have our own post play discussion on 10/10. This play is a great way to become more familiar with these topics for our Reproductive Justice and Race meetup that will be held in Spring 2016.

If tickets prices are a barrier then 10/2, 10/4, and 10/11 are a $6 minimum. Unfortunately, I will not be speaking on those nights. Student ticket prices are always $15.

For more information on the play please see the following links:
http://www.elle.com/culture/a14577/dry-land-ruby-rae-spiegel/

https://companyone.org/production/dry-land-theatre/#tabs-1

The following are helpful links to familiarize yourself with on these issues:
Summary of what Reproductive Justice-http://trustblackwomen.org/our-work/what-is-reproductive-justice/9-what-is-reproductive-justice

Abortion Access & Minors in Massachusetts-
http://www.prochoicemass.org/get-the-facts/minors-/

Laws pertaining to abortion in Florida-
http://www.prochoiceamerica.org/government-and-you/state-governments/state-profiles/florida.html

My abortion story-

https://jendeerinwater.wordpress.com/2013/01/
results.name: Dry Land Play & Post Play Discussion

This and every Saturday night live from the back room of the The Dugout Cafe (722 Comm Ave), John Baglio, Julia Claire, and Zach "Zack" Armentrout bring you a different lineup stacked with the biggest, baddest, and bestiest comedians from Boston and beyond. results.description:
Take a lantern lit tour under the cloak of night through Portsmouth's fabled south end. Walk through the chilling headlines of 100 years ago and see the neighborhood as you've never known withSpectre Scope.  Dark stories of dark deeds from the past are brought out of the cobwebs to bring late night shivers.

 Why do some ghosts choose to linger in this part of town?  Find out more than you may want to know.

Step into an area of town where children built a clubhouse surrounded by the dead of past generations.  Hear about a haunted school where class is still in session.  From spirits who are protective to those who seek to breathe again, you'll visit locations where the veil is the thinnest. Dare to walk into one of the most forgotten burial grounds in the city, the Pleasant Street cemetery.

This tour also invites guests to participate in aspirit circle during the tour. In the spirit circle guests will walk the channel in-between worlds and some guests will receive messages from those residing on the other side.

Tours leave rain or shine.

$20.00.  Tickets must be purchased in advance by clicking here.    Be sure that you choose the correct date!!   The location where the tour will begin will be emailed to those who purchase tickets. 


Note from Todd, Organizer:  I've been on other tours with Roxie, the tour guide.  She's incredibly knowledgeable about history and the paranormal.  I HIGHLY recommend her tours at New England Curiosities.   I have no affiliation with her; I simply think she's incredible :).
results.name: Edge of the Unknown: A Haunted Walking Tour of Portsmouth

results.description:
Rather than a traditional out and back we will do a loop hike that goes through Carrigain Notch, climbs Carrigain from the backside, and descends down the front. Carrigain is a 4000 footer and has an observation deck on top with what many consider the best views in the Whites.

==========================================


INSTRUCTIONS: You must answer the RSVP questions--if you do not respond your RSVP  will be deleted.  Double check your responses to make sure they went through. If you click on CHANGE under where it says "Your RSVP" at the top right, the answers to the questions will be pre-populated with your previous answers if they did come through. If not you can change them there. Best bet is to use a computer, not a phone. Everyone will be waitlisted until responses are screened. 


Please have your preferences for this Meetup set to receive messages from other members, in case I have further questions for you. Similar, recent hiking experience is required. Guests are not allowed, everyone must be a member and signup individually. Dogs are welcomed but must be screened for ability as well.

Weather conditions may cause this hike to be changed or cancelled. Updates will be given as we get closer.

=========================================

THE HIKE:  This hike starts out relatively easy with only 800 feet of elevation in the first six and a half miles as we pass through the notch between Mt. Lowell and Vose Spur. We'll reach the high point of the notch then descend a little to the Desolation trail, where the real climbing starts. In 1.9 miles we'll ascend about 2500'  including some steep and rough sections. After taking in the views from the observation deck we'll descend by the Signal RIdge Trail, returning to where we started.

Totals: 13.42 mi, 4152' of elevation gain, 8:50 book time

Level: Advanced, due to mileage and elevation gain 

==========================================

PACE: We will hike together. Some people hike faster, some slower, some like to be in front, middle, or back. Some like to hike a steady pace, others like to stop often. Kangaroo.

The beginning of this hike will be at a faster pace, closer to 2.5 MPH. We'll slow down on the ascent, but the general average pace of will be 2.0+ MPH which can be reached by any combination of the methods described above. 

HIKING AS A GROUP: We will stop and regroup at all trail junctions, water crossings, or anywhere the trail may be unclear. What I like to suggest is that everyone hikes whatever way they prefer but stay with the group. Do not worry about keeping up with the person in front of you, but DO keep an eye on the person behind you. Someone will be the slowest person in the group. It may be you. Congratulations, you set the pace.

EQUIPMENT: You should be equipped for a 3 season day hike including plenty of food and water, multiple layers of clothing for a variety of temperatures (NO COTTON), sturdy trail shoes or hiking boots, rain gear, head lamp, sun block, a hat, and basic first aid supplies. See the Ten Essentials and the Three Season day Hike List as a reference. 

PROMPTNESS: Be ready to hit the trail within ten minutes of the meeting time. Some people arrive with their bag packed and dressed for the hike and are ready in a few minutes. Others come with everything scattered in their trunk and need more time to get ready. Know which one you are and allow the time you need to be ready on time.

DISCLAIMER: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons
results.name: Mt Carrigain Loop

results.description:
We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
Iron Works House Tour

Step into our 17th century home.

Enjoy a tour through the 1680s Iron Works House and learn about life during the colonial period, the restoration of the house by Wallace Nutting in 1915, and the impact of the house on the reconstruction of the site. This tour has an 8 person limit. You may pick up a ticket in person at the visitor center.

Industrial Site Tour

See the Iron Works come to life! Join a ranger for a tour through the reconstructed iron works and learn about the production of iron on this site in the mid-1600s, an endeavor that was integral to the growth of the early colony, and about the archeological dig and reconstruction of the site in the 1940s to 1950s. Upon availability, this tour may include the operation of waterwheels, the 500-pound hammer and blacksmithing demonstrations.

The tours are free but they limit the number of attendees.

Please call[masked] for any questions.  And no, I won't be making a reservation for ten people.  Regular attendees understand that our not acting like attendance Nazis causes the attendance list to fluctuate wildly.  Let's all be flexible, please.

results.description:
Apple season is well underway, so it's time to bike to Shelburne Farm in Stow to pick (and eat) apples. Starting in Weston, we'll take a scenic ride to Shelburne Farm through the rolling hills of the bucolic western suburbs, and spend about 1 hour or so at the farm. There will be time for lunch (bring your own or buy something yummy from their concession stand), pick (and eat) apples, enjoy cider donuts and, if you want, ice cream.

Although this is a no person left behind ride, please be able to maintain a rolling speed of about 11 - 12 mph on rolling hills. We will stop from time-to-time to regroup. Cue sheets will be available at the beginning of the ride. Total distance about 42 miles.

What you need: a bike in good working order, spare tube, 1 - 2 water bottles (you can refill at the farm), panniers to carry your farm-fresh goodies home, helmet, and a sense of humor, especially if the leader takes a wrong turn on occasion. :)

No ear buds or headphones, please!
results.how_to_find_us: Turn right and go to the end of the parking lot. Look for a white Subaru Crosstrek with a bike rack on top.

This event opens to rsvp'ing 10 days in advance.

The trail is 8.5 miles from Arlington center to Bedford and we ride at a moderate pace.This event auto-repeats monthly and may be leaderless.

Lunch afterwards at Not Your Average Joes, 645 Mass Ave.

Suggested donation $1 for Meetup fees.

This ride happens only if its a nice, clear day above 40 .

Wear a helmet, bring water and sunscreen, watch out for children on the trail, and have a good time!

 

The Minuteman Bikeway passes through the historic area where the American Revolution began in April 1775.

Today, the Minuteman Bikeway is one of the most popular and successful rail-trails in the United States, enjoyed for both healthy recreation and transportation.

The bikeway has become a new type of “Main Street” where neighbors and strangers alike come together while riding, walking, or skating on the path.

In 2008, Rails-to-Trails Conservancy inducted the Minuteman Bikeway into the national Rail-Trail Hall of Fame.

results.description:
Date: Sunday, October 11, 2015
Time: 11:00 AM to 1:00 PM
Location: Central Sq., Cambridge, MA

Fee: Free. An optional donation of $5 or more is suggested
Contact: [masked] for RSVP & address

Words with soul and lovely Chinese characters with spirit can inspire insight and add willpower in daily life. Dr. Sung, a native of Taiwan, is offering an interesting and informative workshop in Cambridge for all who love art and holistic works. Dr. Sung has a unique professional background in the field of education. Please see below for details. In the first 30 minutes of the workshop, Dr. Sung will lead participants to practice basic Tai Chi movements, with a focus on breathing and the balance of energy within the self and with the environment (moving meditation). In addition, Dr. Sung will lead participants to practice the calligraphy of ancient hieroglyphs or modern regular script styles (kai-shu). Individualized instructions will be provided based on each participant’s level of previous experience.

Furthermore, participants are encouraged to bring their favorite words in English and learn their translations in Chinese characters. Participants will practice writing the characters on paper. Afterword, the best characters will be designated “your artwork of the day”. All will love the feel of each stroke and be amazed by power of each on as well as their meaning for the heart and for your well-being. Please come and learn this unique method of self-empowerment and healing in this creative and dynamic class. This workshop is appropriate for anyone age 10 and above. Children under 10 may be admitted with the instructor’s prior approval. - RSVP – ([masked])
Participants who sign up by noon, Wednesday, October 7 will receive hand written Chinese calligraphy. Dr. Sung will select a Chinese character or a word specifically for the participant (based on Dr. Sung’s observation and understanding of the participant) and write the word or phrase on a paper in the front the participant. This individualized and thoughtful calligraphy is the participant’s to keep.

This event is sponsored by YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION INC. (www.Yuan3Chih4Edu.org), a nonprofit organization promoting global education and health care resources sharing, and Tomoko’s Wednesday Dinner [masked]). All donations go to YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION, INC. to promote continuing community education and health care services.

Location: Central Sq., Cambridge, MA
*8-minute walk from Central Square Red Line T station
*Buses # 1, CT1, 47, 64, 68, 70, 70A, 83, and 91
Contact: [masked] for address
Parking: On-street parking along Broadway (meter enforced till 6 pm, please check the current regulations); Green St. garage available for those needing more than 2 hours. FREE PARKING ON SUNDAY ANYWHERE AS LONG AS IT IS A LEAGEL PARKING SPOT, NO PERMIT REQUIRED ON SUNDAY.
What to bring: comfortable clothes, your choice of art paper or sketchpad, and brushes, if you have them. *Traditional calligraphy paper, ink, ink sticks, stone stand, and brushes will be provided if needed. Dr. Yung-Chi Sung M.A., Ph.D.
Born in Taipei, Taiwan, Yung-Chi grew up in a family of teachers. His parents were both teachers. His father taught physics and his mother taught Chinese literature. This may explain how and why he developed a mind that simultaneously admired arts and appreciated the sciences. Dr. Sung has a B.S. in Psychology from Soochow University in Taipei, , an M.A. in Linguistics (with a minor in Cognitive Science), an M.A. in Educational Psychology (with a minor in Psychology), and a Ph.D. in Educational Psychology (with a concentration in Psychological Foundation, Learning, and Cognition, and a minor in Cognitive Science, Linguistics, Neuroscience, and Psychology). He was a research assistant at the Department of Psychology, National University, Taipei, Taiwan. In 1997 he went to University for graduate studies and was a research assistant and method/statistics consultant at University of Minnesota Medical School from 1998 to 2005. Within that period of time, he also served as the President and on the Board of Directors, was Chair of Education and Community Development Committee, Chair of Finance Operation Committee, and Chair of Policy Committee for Chateau Student Housing Cooperative, a not-for-profit co-op providing affordable housing for students from diverse backgrounds, including US and international students. He served as Assistant Director of Outcomes Assessment at University of Maryland University College (UMUC) at Adelphi, Maryland from 2005 to 2008, where for one year he also taught Tai-Chi for stress relief as a diversity initiative. From 2008 to 2014, he was the Director of Evaluation and Assessment at the Tufts University School of Medicine, and Assistant Professor in the Department of Medicine. In 2015, he accepted the position as Director of Assessment and Institutional Effectiveness at Northwestern Health Sciences University, a university aspiring to be a world-class health sciences university, that educates students, practitioners, and leaders in health and wellness solutions to help people live healthier lives. Yung-Chi is a long-term devoted educator. He has been an Adjunct Assistant Professor at UMUC since 2006, and was promoted to Adjunct Associate Professor in 2015. He is also an Associate Professor at NWHSU. He is currently developing a not-for-profit organization (YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION) to promote global sharing of educational and health care resources. In his spare time he enjoys reading, writing, dreaming, dancing (recently salsa and argentine tango), and occasionally playing poker (currently no-limit Texas Hold’em).

results.description:
OSHO Nataraj Meditation is dance as a total meditation, where all inner divisions disappear and a subtle, relaxed awareness remains. This meditation is done with specific OSHO Nataraj Meditation music, which indicates and energetically supports the different stages. The meditation lasts 65 minutes and consists of three stages. In the first part of the meditation, the participant is welcome to move freely, as his body desires. In the second part, the participant lies down, is silent and still. And the last part involves dancing in celebration. This is an individual experience moving with eyes closed throughout the entire meditation, so during the process the participant remains oblivious to others. It is helpful and wonderful to do it with other people in the room as the energy of the group supports the process and creates an atmosphere of love and awareness. After the meditation we will gather in a closing circle where participants will be able to share their experience or ask any questions if they wish to do so. 


The key benefits of the meditation are: finding inner flow, creating a unified body-mind and connecting to the inner source of bliss 

The meditation will take place in Studio 2.

It will run, provided that we have enough participants, every Sunday until December 13th with following exceptions:      October 18th and Nov 8th

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Please check past event pics at:

https://www.facebook.com/events/412224152314026/

Words with soul and lovely Chinese characters with spirit can inspire insight and add willpower in daily life. Dr. Sung, a native of Taiwan, is offering an interesting and informative workshop in Cambridge for all who love art and holistic works. 

In the first 30 minutes of the workshop, participants will practice basic Tai Chi movements, with a focus on breathing and the balance of energy within the self and with the environment (moving meditation). Participants will then practice the calligraphy of ancient hieroglyphs or modern regular script styles (kai-shu). Individualized instructions will be provided based on each participant’s level of previous experience.


Participants are encouraged to bring their favorite words in English to translate them into Chinese characters. Participants will practice writing the characters on paper. Afterword, your best characters will be designated “your artwork of the day”. 

Feel the power of each stroke as their meanings enter your heart and your well-being. 

Please come and learn this unique method of self-empowerment and healing in this creative and dynamic class. This workshop is appropriate for anyone age 10 and above. Children under 10 may be admitted with the instructor’s prior approval. 

Participants who sign up by noon, Wednesday, October 7 will receive hand written Chinese calligraphy. Dr. Sung will select a Chinese character or a word specifically for the participant (based on Dr. Sung’s observation and understanding of the participant) and write the word or phrase on a paper in front of the participant. This individualized and thoughtful calligraphy is the participant’s to keep.

This event is sponsored by YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION INC. (www.Yuan3Chih4Edu.org), a nonprofit organization promoting global education and health care resources sharing, and Tomoko’s Wednesday Dinner [masked]). All donations go to YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION, INC. to promote continuing community education and health care services.

Location: Central Sq., Cambridge, MA
*8-minute walk from Central Square Red Line T station
*Buses # 1, CT1, 47, 64, 68, 70, 70A, 83, and 91 


Parking: On-street parking along Broadway (meter enforced till 6 pm, please check the current regulations); Green St. garage available for those needing more than 2 hours. FREE PARKING ON SUNDAY ANYWHERE AS LONG AS IT IS A LEAGEL PARKING SPOT, NO PERMIT REQUIRED ON SUNDAY.

Bring: comfortable clothes, your choice of art paper or sketchpad, and brushes, if you have them. *Traditional calligraphy paper, ink, ink sticks, stone stand, and brushes will be provided if needed. 

Dr. Yung-Chi Sung M.A., Ph.D.
Born in Taipei, Taiwan, Yung-Chi grew up in a family of teachers. His parents were both teachers. His father taught physics and his mother taught Chinese literature. This may explain how and why he developed a mind that simultaneously admired arts and appreciated the sciences.

Dr. Sung has a B.S. in Psychology from Soochow University in Taipei, , an M.A. in Linguistics (with a minor in Cognitive Science), an M.A. in Educational Psychology (with a minor in Psychology), and a Ph.D. in Educational Psychology (with a concentration in Psychological Foundation, Learning, and Cognition, and a minor in Cognitive Science, Linguistics, Neuroscience, and Psychology). 

He was a research assistant at the Department of Psychology, National University, Taipei, Taiwan. In 1997 he went to University for graduate studies and was a research assistant and method/statistics consultant at University of Minnesota Medical School from 1998 to 2005. Within that period of time, he also served as the President and was on the Board of Directors, was Chair of Education and Community Development Committee, Chair of Finance Operation Committee, and Chair of Policy Committee for Chateau Student Housing Cooperative, a not-for-profit co-op providing affordable housing for students from diverse backgrounds, including US and international students. He served as Assistant Director of Outcomes Assessment at University of Maryland University College (UMUC) at Adelphi, Maryland from 2005 to 2008, where for one year he also taught Tai-Chi for stress relief as a diversity initiative. 

From 2008 to 2014, he was the Director of Evaluation and Assessment at the Tufts University School of Medicine, and Assistant Professor in the Department of Medicine. In 2015, he accepted the position as Director of Assessment and Institutional Effectiveness at Northwestern Health Sciences University, a university aspiring to be a world-class health sciences university, that educates students, practitioners, and leaders in health and wellness solutions to help people live healthier lives. 

Yung-Chi is a long-term devoted educator. He has been an Adjunct Assistant Professor at UMUC since 2006, and was promoted to Adjunct Associate Professor in 2015. He is also an Associate Professor at NWHSU. He is currently developing a not-for-profit organization (YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION) to promote global sharing of educational and health care resources. In his spare time he enjoys reading, writing, dreaming, dancing (recently salsa and argentine tango), and occasionally playing poker (currently no-limit Texas Hold’em).

Fee: Free. An optional donation of $5 or more is suggested
results.name: Sung: The Spiritual Art of Chinese Calligraphy and Tai Chi

results.description:
An RSVP only indicates your interest in the sail!

While an RSVP is useful for me to track your interest it does not guarantee a spot on the boat. I will send you an email to discuss your sailing experience and and to confirm your spot on the boat. This will be an e-mail directly from me, please do not be confused by system generated e-mails confirming your spot! Describing your sailing experience in detail when prompted during the RSVP process will increase your chances of being selected.


To expect

A late season sailing adventure with moderate to strong winds and cold temperatures. You must have done late or early season sails before and be able to dress appropriately! You will be splashed and be asked to hike out.  I like to sail fast so be prepared to frequently trim the sails and adjust boat balance. Significant sailing experience mandatory!  You must be able to steer w/o supervision. This will be an ~4 hour sail with no pit stops on a boat without a head or engine.  You should not be susceptible to seasickness under moderate conditions or bring appropriate medication.

Where we'll sail

To be decided based on conditions.

What we will sail on
Sonar (http://piersparksailing.org/aboutus/our-fleet-and-equipment). This is a 23 foot racer/daysailer with no head, cabin or engine.

To bring
There is plenty of (mostly) dry storage so bring extra layers, food, water, and medicine if you get sea sick. PFDs will be provided.

Important Disclaimer

Sailing with me may be stressful at times. It is unlikely but is possible to sustain an injury during sailing. I will try to ensure that we have a safe sailing adventure but be advised that getting scratched or hurt occasionally is considered part of the sport.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet by the head of the ramp down to the dock
results.name: Sailing a Sonar in Boston Harbor. No Novices!

results.description:
These sessions at The Chinatown Community Center/Josia School will focus on a 6 week rotating schedule of classes designed to introduce the basics of Parkour in concentrate classes. The schedule will follow in order: 

• Safety, Landings and Balance

Class 1 will be focusing on how to land, move and stay safe practicing Parkour outdoor and in the real world. 

• Vaulting

Class 2 will focus on the foundation of Parkour - getting over low-level obstacles fast and efficiently through the use of vaulting.

• Precisions

Class 3 will focus on accuracy of jumping and foot/eye coordination honing basic standing and running jumps.

• Wall Techniques 

Class 4 will focus on conquering obstacles too large or tall to vault, in tandem with using walls as a means to keep a more efficient run.

• Tumbling/Acro

Class 5 focus is on tumbling and acrobatic skills, in pursuit of fully understanding movement in a 3D space and total proprioception.

• Flow + Speed

Class 6 links together all the previous lessons into one cohesive movement, and a timed obstacle course setting. ------

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 


This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be on the main courtyard up the stairs. The location itself is of concrete construction, and has yellow rails!
results.name: -- Adults -- [Boston] Parkour 101 - Introduction to Parkour //

Join me for an easy kayak paddle along the Concord River from Billerica toward Bedford with a potential late lunch stop at the Two Brothers Rocks.  Kayak rental available for experienced members without their own equipment.  Trip may last 3-4 hours / round trip distance approximately 8 miles.  Appropriate clothing needed (no cotton).  Launch time is 11:30 so please arrive early to prepare your kayak.  

http://www.thebedfordcitizen.org/2012/12/17/the-two-brothers-rocks/

No SUPs or inflatables.  12-foot minimum length kayak required.  Shorter boats have had difficulty keeping up with the longer boats on trips.

The available kayaks are not suitable for people over 6 feet tall, or > 220 lbs.   A paddle and PFD is provided or bring your own.  To rent a kayak call or text me (Ed) at[masked] to discuss your experience level and fit.

Concord River Kayak - Rental Page

Here is a link to the Rental Agreement

AS A CONDITION OF ATTENDING THIS MEETUP, YOU AGREE TO: Hold harmless, and indemnify the organizers and their relations and heirs, and all members and participants of the Meetup group from any and all claims for injury, illness, death, and/or property damage including those caused by negligence, ignorance, inexperience and other reasons. You also agree to assume all mental, physical, financial, and/or other risk associated with this meetup. Kayaking, camping, hiking, bicycling, and other activities pose inherent risks and dangers. Participation in these activities is voluntary and dependent upon your own personal judgment. As organizers we make no claims regarding any expertise for this outing. This is not a guided tour. In the interest of safety, consuming alcohol before or during any Casual Kayakers event is not allowed. Wearing of Lifejackets (PFD's) is required when paddling with this group.

results.description:
Our October topic:

Are you a Scarecrow or a Tin Man?

From The Boston Globe -- May 3, 2015:


"LIKE THE SCARECROW, do you prize your brain? Or are you like the Tin Man, prizing your heart? Researchers found that men in general, and Americans in particular, tend to locate themselves in the brain rather than the heart. Likewise, people made to think about being independent were more likely to locate themselves in the brain than people made to think about being dependent on others. And this belief can be a matter of life and death: Where you locate yourself biases your definition of death to be brain death or cardiac death, respectively. It also biases your support for an antiabortion law justified by the presence of a fetal heartbeat. Meanwhile, people who were made to locate themselves in the brain — by being asked to write about it — subsequently contributed more to an Alzheimer’s charity than a heart disease charity. The reverse was true for people made to locate themselves in the heart.

"Adam, H. et al., “Who You Are Is Where You Are: Antecedents and Consequences of Locating the Self in the Brain or the Heart,” Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes (http://bit.ly/whoyouare_bh)."

===============================================

Brunch Menu

Brunch for Thought FAQs
results.name: Brunch for Thought-October

results.description:
This is the regular meetup on Sundays at noon at Brooklyn Boulders in Somerville.  Meet by the first table/bench thing by the entrance.  Hopefully we'll get a good variety of climbing interests coming so that everyone can follow their climbing passion!

(Credit to Francesco Cardiello for the information below):
BKBS is the gorgeous, new, state-of-the-art climbing gym most convenient to those in the Boston, Cambridge, and Somerville area. Although pricier, it features 60+ feet toproping and lead climbing, a massive 22 x 140 foot bouldering wall (and there's still another upstairs), yoga & fitness classes, a sauna, awesome water fountains that fill your water bottle, a retail store, lounge area, weight room, and a soon to open cafe! There's even a collaborative work space where you can study, work, and climb!  If you are looking for a partner, or just want to get your climb on, join us for a fun time.

FAQ:

How do I get there? BKBS is conveniently located within a 10 minute walk of the Porter Square station. Walk down Somerville Avenue and turn right on Properzi way and head all the way down. It is also very bike accessible. If you drive, you can find the lot at 30 Dane St. It is located next to Artisans Asylum.

Why should I do this meetup? Since BKBS is such a new community (opened in late July 2013) few people have developed regular climbing partners to train and climb with. This is a great opportunity to meet other climbers interested in BKBS. Climbing is an inherently social sport - to toprope and do lead, you need to meet people who are dedicated to climbing. This meetup assures you'll meet a partner to climb with.

What if I haven't climbed before? First off, don't be intimidated. Everyone started somewhere. If you have never belayed before, please make sure to take the Learn the Ropes class. More info can be found here: http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before using the walls. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need? You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time? Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): Day Pass - $25 (Students $18)
10 Pack - $200 (Students $169)

RENTALS: Shoes - $5
Harness - $5
Chalk Bag - $2
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Sunday

results.description:
Improv Photo is heading to Harvard Square for our October meetup. 

We'll meet at 12pm on October 11th to introduce ourselves and talk photography.At 12:30 I'll announce the prompt, and we'll head out to find images in response. After shooting on our own for an hour, we'll re-convene to share images and talk about the challenge. 

Please note that we're meeting a bit earlier than usual. I've timed it so anyone who wants to capture the Honk! parade as it enters Harvard Square can do so, but the prompt will inspire great shots wherever you choose to shoot.  

**Note on location: This is not the ABP in the center of Harvard Square. It's just outside the square, away from the crowds. A map is linked to the venue name above.

**Note for those who drive: Parking is free in Cambridge on Sundays, but Octoberfest and the Honk! parade will create traffic issues.

**If you have questions or need to contact me, please message me through meetup instead of commenting on this page. (My app has trouble with comments.)

results.description:
WOW. We got the win last week finally! And how about that awesome Thursday night crowd at Causeway? We had 50+ plus Ravens fans who felt riding the game out at home alone was a bad idea! Good choice.

We've got a 1 pm game this Sunday, perfect time slot for maximum purple partying at Causeway. Get there early to get a good seat! Remember: SECOND FLOOR is Ravens Nation!

Special Announcement: Miller Lite, OFFICIAL sponsor of the Ravens, will be joining us Sunday with some purple giveaways of Ravens Miller shirts and other cool stuff. Don't miss out on that!

Not sure what the "Maryland item" is going to be this week on our Ravens menu. Will let ya know soon though!

Can't wait to get crazy with the Boston army very soon. RAVENS!

Getting to Causeway: 

Driving is doable. During Sunday day games, the lot behind the building is $10, but if fills quickly. There is also parking on the nearby streets. People are having luck on Nashua St. as well.

Taking the T - We are just a block from North Station where Orange and Green lines arrive. For the Red line, transfer at Park St. and go 3 stops to North Station or get off at MGH and walk 5-10 minutes to us. 

From the suburbs? Try the commuter rail. Lines from the west and north go directly to us (North Station). South Station arrivals are about a mile south of us, or a quick cab/uber ride. First uber riders use code P6E94 for a discount!

Using I-93. Try getting off at the new Assembly Row T station in Somerville. Lots of parking, just off highway, and only 6-7 minute T ride to us. Not a bad option regardless of what direction you're coming from.
results.name: Ravens vs. Browns

group.name: Ravens Nation North (Baltimore Ravens Fans in Boston)

• Wall Techniques 

Class 4 will focus on conquering obstacles too large or tall to vault, in tandem with using walls as a means to keep a more efficient run.

• Tumbling/Acro

Class 5 focus is on tumbling and acrobatic skills, in pursuit of fully understanding movement in a 3D space and total proprioception.

• Flow + Speed

Class 6 links together all the previous lessons into one cohesive movement, and a timed obstacle course setting.

------

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 


This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be on the main courtyard up the stairs. The location itself is of concrete construction, and has yellow rails!
results.name: -- Adults -- [Boston] Parkour 101 - Introduction to Parkour //

results.description:
Experience real vocal freedom by learning most important aspects of vocal technique on a foundation of spiritual grace and ego surrender. Guaranteed improvement for beginners and those with vocal problems.

BIO:

“A person who has suffered vocal damage, but was able to repair it,
will probably be unusually qualified to teach vocal technique. The
discoveries he made in the course of his own recovery were priceless.
Since he went through the mill, he seems to be able to understand
and help others in a way nobody else could.” From “Building Your
Best Voice,” by Henry Jacobi. Why is this so? Once you have weakened your vocal muscles, you must learn to sing perfectly, so there is absolutely NO muscle resistance, but your body is merely a vessel for vocal energy. Perfect singing is a combination of mastery of vocal technique and emotional release/spiritual surrender. My background makes me uniquely qualified to teach perfect singing.. In the late 70s and early 80s, I sang in a number of musicals, and with several opera companies in New York City , before weakening my chords due to a combination of poor vocal training, and emotional blocks, which had been present since childhood. I was then extremely fortunate to study with Judy Oas, a world renown teacher, written up in “Opera News.” Judy's students had included both Metropolitan Opera and Broadway stars, but she had chosen to devote herself to exclusively helping promising students who had hurt their voice. She taught vocal rehabilitation, with a spiritual approach, calling her instruction, “Zen And the Art of Singing.” Her unique dual focused approach was to teach vocal technique in a much more detailed manner than is usually the case, for vocal rehabilitation required perfect technique, while simultaneously exploring how the study of voice leads to a self-knowledge that, in effect, makes vocal training a kind of emotional and spiritual therapy. I have retained the same dual focus, but have expanded on her methods in both areas of vocal technique and spiritual/emotional healing. In any case, I teach the foundations of vocal technique, that later can be applied to all types of singing, for good singing is good singing, whether it's blues, jazz, pop, classical, country, etc.

COST FOR WORKSHOP: $60. PARTIAL SCHOLARSHIPS POSSIBLE.
results.name: PERFECT SINGING AS SPIRITUAL PATH AND TOOL FOR EMOTIONAL HEALING
