results.description:
Ladies! I am so excited to be offering a free two hour workshop to you all to formally put together a LIFE plan AND a BUSINESS plan centered around your family, your heart and your soul :) This is the same framework I teach at New England's Center for Women and Enterprise, so if you have already been through my course you are welcome to come for a refresher, or you can stay tuned for follow up workshops that I will schedule this Fall to help you take the life plan & business plan to the next level. I know most of our meetups to date have been informal productive playdates, but I think you are all ready to dive in with a formal workshop that will bring things to the next level!

I am excited that Winchester Library will be hosting us in their beautiful turn of the century Main Room. Children are welcome if you think you can sit through the session with them, or there is a children's room downstairs where if we had enough Moms with the need we could have someone hang out with the kiddos. Hope to see you all there - Get ready to dig into your businesses and kick things up a notch!! Lots of love!

<3 Felicia

Workshop Description: 

Are you a mom who yearns to fulfill your passions through the freedom and flexibility of entrepreneurship, but you’re not willing to sacrifice your family priorities? This course is built on a unique framework  to help you  build confidence in designing a business around your passions & your family. Motherhood and entrepreneurship do not have to be mutually exclusive. Whether you’re a full time working mom hoping to leave the rat race, or a stay at home mom hoping to reactivate your career with something flexible, this course will show you the best ways to ramp up a side business safely, rapidly and more profitably, all the meanwhile putting your family, heart and soul at the center.

Attend this workshop to:

- Establish your lifestyle plan before diving into your business plan

- Build a business strategy that works around your personal and family priorities

- Walk away feeling confident in a lifestyle plan that works for your family, a business plan that leverages your passions and is poised to bring in income, and critical time management strategies that enable you to maintain inner and outer peace as your business grows at a pace that works for you and your family.
results.name: FREE 2 Hour Workshop: Kickstarting a Business Plan that works for your Family

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE: Tavern in the Square in Porter Square

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Look down the street. There's Tavern in the Square! If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Erika and Jack

results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritutual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs. This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/
results.how_to_find_us: Enter at The Hawthorne Building, the large glass doors to the left of H&R Block.

venue.address_1: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138
venue.name: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138

results.description:
Let's join 20+ others from six other walking groups for:

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.

results.description:
This month at the October Dinner, Art, + Music night at Miranda's Hearth, take part in a community mural project to be hung at #WhatIMake: The Conference.

The project will be led by Hearth Founder Miranda Aisling. All attendees will be walked through a series of steps to create a masterpiece. Together.

Following the mural project we'll have our usual jam sessions and potluck. As always, tickets are $7 but you can bring a potluck dish to get in for free!
results.name: Be part of a mural project!

results.description:
“What makes Iago evil? Some people ask. I never ask.”
― from Play It As It Lays

A ruthless dissection of American life in the late 1960s, Play It as It Lays captures the mood of an entire generation, the ennui of contemporary society reflected in spare prose that blisters and haunts the reader. Set in a place beyond good and evil - literally in Hollywood, Las Vegas, and the barren wastes of the Mojave Desert, but figuratively in the landscape of an arid soul - it remains more than three decades after its original publication a profoundly disturbing novel, riveting in its exploration of a woman and a society in crisis and stunning in the still-startling intensity of its prose.
results.name: Didion: Play It As It Lays

group.name: Classic Books: A Book Club for Voracious Readers

results.description:
OPEN MIC, Party with Live Music in Central Square. Great venue, talented musicians and an open mic. Party goers, Musicians, & Singers! Come join the jam at the Wed Night Open mike. Everyone Welcome.

Play music solo or with backing band. All instruments and styles welcome. Originals, covers, blues, jazz, classic rock, R&B, Motown, folk, etc. Back up band with drums, bass, guitar, and Songlist for singers.

This is a great opportunity to further your music experience and career, jam with other musicians, play solo, play originals, and network. The goal is to have everyone play as much as possible. Even if you don't plan to play, come to check this out, listen to inspired music, meet some nice people and make friends. This is a combined meetup of 4 music groups and eventually 1, 2 or more other social groups.  3$ Donation Voluntary at the Door for musicians who are playing; $5 for spectators.  If you are running low on cash, ask for Bill.

We have a songlist and songheets.  Rehearsal available the weekend before at the other meetup in this Meetup Group.  If you want accompaniment, bring song sheets for your songs on one page that will facilitate playing. If you are a beginner open micer, &/or want to play with accompanying bass /lead/harmony try to come early at 7:00PM.  If you have songs you want to play, bring about 4 copies of 2 or 3 songs you want to play on 1 sheet per song if possible, so we can all rehearse/play it.   If you are playing at semi-professional level and are playing solo or don't need to rehearse, just come to the open mic.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the signup Sheet & Brock (I'm 6'4)
results.name: Open Mic in Central Sq.

results.description:
It gets four out of five stars on Amazon, so you know it must be good. 

And how could you not like stories in which (SPOILER ALERT) people sell their souls to The Devil? Especially when said Devil was heretofore your rescue-poodle?

Faust is after ultimate knowledge, and a conversation about 'Faust' will be a worthy successor to our conversation about 'Frankenstein.'

I'll be using the translation by David Luke, which many consider the best: http://www.amazon.com/Faust-Part-Oxford-Worlds-Classics/dp/019953621X/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1443376533&sr=8-1

Good alternatives include the translations by Walter Arndt (http://www.amazon.com/Faust-Tragedy-Norton-Critical-Editions/dp/0393972828/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1443375475&sr=8-3) and Walter Kaufmann (http://www.amazon.com/Goethes-Faust-Johann-Wolfgang-Goethe/dp/0385031149/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1443374745&sr=8-1).
results.name: Goethe's 'Faust, Part One'

We are so excited to announce this awesome opportunity to see a great film and after the screening; hang out and network with other members of the Boston Screenwriters Group.

My co-organizer, Jeff Stewart initiated this event and picked the Sicario movie. Read the description of the film below.

From Coolidge Corner Website: "After rising through the ranks of her male-dominated profession, idealistic FBI agent Kate Macer (Emily Blunt) receives a top assignment.

Recruited by mysterious government official Matt Graver (Josh Brolin), Kate joins a task force for the escalating war against drugs. Led by the intense and shadowy Alejandro (Benicio Del Toro), the team travels back-and-forth across the U.S.-Mexican border, using one cartel boss (Bernardo Saracino) to flush out a bigger one (Julio Cesar Cedillo)."

Hope to see EVERYONE at this event. Please RSVP if attending

Warm Regards,

Deborah & Jeff

venue.name: Harvard Film Archive

results.description:
Los Angeles Plays Itself

Directed by Thom Andersen
US 2003, 35mm, color, 169 min

Thom Anderson is appearing at the HFA on November 6-7.  Los Angeles Plays itself is  an 'epic magnum opus'.  At 169 minutes, we won't plan to meet after the film for discussion, but gather at Grafton Street Pub as early as 5:15 for dinner and discussion of Thom Andersen.

A touchstone of early 21st century cinema, Andersen's magnum opus Los Angeles Plays Itself is an epic and purposefully meandering essay film that distills a bracingly polemic film history from its expansive critical survey of uses and abuses of the City of Angels by an impressively wide range of films—Hollywood blockbusters, low-budget genre pictures, independent, experimental and even pornographic films. Andersen's rigorous mapping of scene after scene onto the actual and imaginary Los Angeles is aided by frequent returns to the "scenes of the crime" of former film locations, via contemporary footage shot by Deborah Stratman. The film's arresting rhythm comes from Andersen's deft and mordant commentary (spoken by filmmaker Encke King), which remains almost conversational yet always imperious in its careful unveiling of those larger historical, cultural and ideological forces that render the cinematic city such a vivid palimpsest for ever-changing ideas of narrative and community. More than a corrective of cinema's faulty sense of place and history, however, Los Angeles Plays Itself powerfully uses rare counterexamples—such as Kent MacKenzie's The Exiles (1961) and Billy Woodbury's Bless Their Little Hearts (1984)—to argue that the indignities and false myths so frequently imposed upon Los Angeles by the cinema are direct expressions of actual injustice suffered by so many of its displaced, disenfranchised and, on the silver screen, silent inhabitants. With Los Angeles Plays Itself, Andersen defined a distinct conception of film analysis: both a guerrilla repurposing of Hollywood films and a personally invested, politically charged yet equanimous mode of close reading that is able to decode an unruly multitude of major and minor films. The enduring cult status of Los Angeles Plays Itself was confirmed by the great excitement and acclaim that greeted its first official release in 2014, more than ten years after its Toronto premiere.
results.how_to_find_us: We can gather at Grafton Street Pub at 5:15 for fuel and discussion of Los Angeles and the work of Thom Andersen
results.name: Los Angeles Plays Itself

October 11 - Uranus at Opposition. The blue-green planet will be at its closest approach to Earth and its face will be fully illuminated by the Sun. It will be brighter than any other time of the year and will be visible all night long. This is the best time to view Uranus. Due to its distance, it will only appear as a tiny blue-green dot in all but the most powerful telescopes.

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during astronomical twilight.


The best time then is 5:20 to 6:00 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.

results.description:
Join TMIRCE as we serve thousands of running ladies water in little paper cups at the Tufts 10K for Women this Columbus Day, Monday, October 12. As in years gone by, we'll be making the Mile 5 water stop extra special by getting extra gussied up in our Monday's finest. Gentlemen and Ladies are equally encouraged to volunteer.

Meeting spot:

Our water spot is on Commonwealth Ave. between Fairfield and Gloucester. You can meet there between 10:00am and 10:30am.

What to wear:

Simple. Dress up. I'll be wearing my vest and bow tie and tux (if it fits). Don't have a tux? A Jacket and Tie work great too. Stay Classy. I'm talkin' Ron Burgundy classy.

Quote from a previous year's runner , "I couldn't wait to see you guys! This is my favorite water stop." Then she kissed Andy. No joke.

When does it end?

The race starts at noon. We are the last water stop. As the race begins to wind down, we'll sweep up as many cups as we can. There is a T10k "sweep team' that will come pick up all the collected trash and left over water. We should be done sometime between 1:30pm and 2:00pm.

results.description:
In this 2 hour Mini Me Yoga workshop, parents, grandparents, childcare, providers and teachers learn simple techniques for introducing 15 minutes a day of yoga and positive thinking to preschool and elementary aged children using games and exercises designed to make it fun and engaging.

No experience with yoga is necessary anyone can join in the fun!

Each participant receives a set of 14 Magick Yoga Cards and will learn about:
•Breathing
•Meditation
•Making energy water
•Why we do kids yoga
•Plus, at least 14 yoga poses

It’s action packed and full of information as well as practical tools. Everyone leaves with what they need to get started right away, with an easy 15 minute a day program designed to be used in your daily routine, whether it be in the home, the classroom, community groups, play dates, weekend sleep overs etc.

Introducing these simple games in school, daycare or the home significantly reduces stress, increases children’s capacity to learn, be gentle to one another, respect nature and grow strong mentally and physically. During this age where childhood diabetes, food intolerance's and hyper active syndromes are on the rise, our games and activities bring much needed fun time where children can create and express themselves. This is an opportunity to strengthen the bond with your child while improving their (and your) well-being in just 15 minutes a day.

$75/person

Only 12 spots available! To register contact me at [masked]!
results.name: Mini Me Yoga 2Hr Workshop for Grown Ups

results.description:
Established in 1950, deCordova Sculpture Park and Museum is the largest park of its kind in New England encompassing 35 acres, 20 miles northwest of Boston. In 2009, deCordova changed its name from deCordova Museum and Sculpture Park to deCordova Sculpture Park and Museum to emphasize its renewed focus on sculpture and to support the institution’s goal of becoming a premier Sculpture Park by 2020. Providing a constantly changing landscape of large-scale, outdoor, modern and contemporary sculpture and site-specific installations, the Sculpture Park hosts more than 60 works, the majority of which are on loan to the Museum. Inside, the Museum features a robust slate of rotating exhibitions and innovative interpretive programming.

Check out the fall exhibitions:
www.decordova.org

Admission Fees

Adults: $14 
Seniors (65+): $12 
Students: $10 
Children 12 and under: FREE

Members, Lincoln Residents, and Active Duty Military Personnel and their families receive FREE admission.

On the first Wednesday of every month admission is FREE for all visitors.

Members receive free admission year-round—Join Today!

All cyclists who pedal to deCordova receive free admission.

The following discounts apply to regular Adult admission only:

$2 discount with a WGBH or MTA membership card 
$3 discount with a WBUR membership card 
Free admission for current WGBH members the last Thursday of every month 
$2 discount with a Zipcar membership card

Admission to deCordova | Store and Café is free. To shop at deCordova | Store or to visit the Café, please see attenda

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
“GOOSEBUMPS”

Running Time: 1-hour, 38-minutes

Rated: “PG”

Opening Date: October 16, 2015

Synopsis:

Scholastic has over 400 million Goosebumps books worldwide in 32 languages in print since the series introduction in 1992, earning critical acclaim and dominating global best seller lists. R.L. Stine has been recognized as one of the bestselling children’s authors in history. Now, the literary phenomenon is coming to the big screen.

In Goosebumps, teenager Zach Cooper (Dylan Minnette), upset about moving from a big city to a small town, finds a silver lining when he meets the beautiful girl, Hannah (Odeya Rush), living right next door, and makes a quick friend in Champ (Ryan Lee). But every silver lining has a cloud, and Zach’s comes when he learns that Hannah’s mysterious dad is in fact R.L. Stine (Jack Black), the author of the bestselling Goosebumps series. As Zach starts learning about the strange family next door, he soon discovers that Stine holds a dangerous secret: the creatures that his stories made famous are real, and Stine protects his readers by keeping them locked up in their books. When Stine’s creations are unintentionally released from their manuscripts, Zach’s life takes a turn for the weird. In a crazy night of adventure, it’s up to Zach, Hannah, Champ, and Stine to team up and get all of these figments of Stine’s imagination – including Slappy the Dummy, the girl with the haunted mask, the gnomes and many more – back in the books where they belong to save the town.

https://youtu.be/7Cn716jv61s
results.name: Goosebumps     10-12     Mon.          AMC  6:30 PM

WE ARE BACK IN DAVIS SQUARE FOR TONIGHT, PLEASE TAKE NOTE OF THIS.

6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
DrinksOnTap is a social meetup for Boston area mobile developers (iPhone, Android and more). Come meet for a drink and catch up on all the new mobile developments at our next DrinksOnTap event - Monday, October 12th at Ned Devine's in Faneuil Hall from 6PM-9PM.


EXCITING NEWS!! Luxe will be providing valet car service for the evening. Use promo code DRINKSONTAP for $30 worth of parking credits.


Luxe is an on-demand valet service, similar to Uber but for parking your car. With the Luxe app, you can have a Luxe valet meet you at your destination and whisk your car away to a secure lot or garage.  Whenever you're ready, just request your car through the app, and Luxe will bring your car back to you, anywhere within the service zone.


Plus, our SPONSOR for the evening will be:

Next Step Living is a leading provider of energy-saving solutions and is currently embarking on a brand new platform vision that will connect consumers, subcontractors, product and services in a single online marketplace.

And finally, our DEMOS for the evening will be:

CareTRx is a novel app and sensor solution that leverages a smart inhaler and your phone to simplify management of asthma and COPD. It combines real-time sensor analytics, patient-centered design, gamification, and remote caregiving.


Toast is an Android restaurant management and point-of-sale platform with a cloud backend adding online ordering, loyalty programs, labor & sales reporting. www.toasttab.com


Use promo code “DrinksOnTap" for $5 off one meal!


Chef Nightly removes all the work involved when deciding what food is for dinner each night. By putting the food first, Chef Nightly is the easiest way to order the best meals from the best local kitchens.


Looking forward to a great event!


Be sure to spread the word: @DrinksOnTap and #DrinksOnTap! 


Note: This event is 21+ only.
results.name: Demos, Drinks and Discussions about Mobile Development (21+)

What the experience of drumming offers:

* A peak experience that bonds all who share it
* An atmosphere of truth, support, and harmony
* Techniques to reduce tension, worry, and stress
* A tribal celebration in an indigenous tradition
* Open heart and mind to awareness of spirit.

Mamadou teaches the importance of the drum in the African culture to the community as a mode of communication and in the daily life.

West african drumming is not just music, but an experience of the heart, mind, and spirit. It evokes self-discovery, spiritual renewal, joy for life, and a deep sense of community.

Each class is $10 per person.
results.why:
Mamadou has been teaching African drum in the North Shore area for over 10 years. He has an inherent talent for sharing his abilities with others. Let him teach you how to feel the rhythms of West Africa.

Plus, its a lot of fun :)

The 50 cent charge is totally voluntary and is only to approximately cover the meetup charge, however It is suggested that you buy a drink or something else there, to compensate the hosting establishment.

New people are very welcome and will probably will play their first few hands, about an hour of instruction, with the Meetup organizer and selected players before playing at-large with the rest of the group.

This is SOCIAL CARDS conversation is encouraged, however please be aware of when it is your turn to bid or play a card, we try to keep the fun balanced and considerate of everyone between the two activities.

results.description:
Formaggio Kitchen is Boston's premier cheeseshop. Literally. Pretty much all they sell is cheese, wine, and baguette. Their cheese comes from all over the world. Some of it is delicious. Some of it smells like stinky feet. Some of it is colors that cheese should never be. But if you show up at Frommagio Kitchen, can sample all of their cheese before purchasing, and have a really good time doing it. So let's swing by this unique store and try the best and weidest cheeses you've ever had. We'll probably have a dinner of baguette, cheese, and wine shortly afterward.

NEW RSVP POLICY: Please RSVP if you plan to come. If you RSVP, I'll be waiting for you, so please show up! If you change your RSVP or ditch us within 48 hours of a meetup more than once per calendar year, we'll have to remove you from the group. Two members have been dropped so far. When you RSVP, you're making a commitment and taking a spot, so come. If you need to get a hold of me, my number is four four zero 488-5055.
results.name: Get some cheese at Formaggio Kitchen

results.description:
For a free ticket to this event, please e-mail [masked] and they will send you a confirmation with the venue address!

Ever been told you have a great voice? From audio books and cartoons to documentaries, commercials, and more, this class will introduce you to the growing field of voice over. Today, the range of voices hired has grown dramatically from the days of announcers. Learn what the pros look for, how to prepare, and where to find work in your area! We’ll discuss industry pros and cons and play samples from working voice professionals. In addition, you’ll have an opportunity to record a short professional script under the direction of your instructor. This seminar is lots of fun, realistic, and a great first step for anyone interested in the voice over field. 

Getting Paid To Talk is a two-hour upbeat and realistic introduction to voice-overs, also known as voice acting. During the seminar, your instructor will discuss:



The different types of voice-overs

What it’s like to work in the studio

Voice types that are in demand

Where to look for work opportunities close to you

Effective demo development and examples

Industry pros and cons

Everyone in the class will also have an opportunity to record a short Voice Over for playback at the end of class. Your instructor will also be more than happy to offer you some basic voice feedback at the completion of the class.

Who should attend this seminar:


Designed specifically for adults, though older children are welcome with parental accompaniment


A great seminar for anyone who has been told they have a good voice


Those who use their voices prominently in their occupations


People with music or theater background


Anyone who is interested in how voice-overs work and how people get started.


Space is limited for this great introductory seminar on how to get paid to talk, so register today!

NOTE: If you want to purchase food or beverages at this event, this venue accepts cash only.
results.name: Seminar: Getting Paid to Talk—An Introduction to Voice Over

results.description:
Do you have a family member or friend who wants to get in shape but doesn't know how to start? Help get them walking or jogging.

We have 2 groups:

Our Walking Group will exercise and encourage one another towards walking a 5K. 

Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.

Using CoolRunning.com’s Couch To 5K program we introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 8-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles).

•  Anyone from the community can participate. 


• Led by experienced runners. 


• Mondays through Thursdays 6:30pm-7:15pm; Saturdays 10 am-10:45 am 


• 45 minute time commitment (3 days a week) 


• Goal of jogging and finishing a 5K

• Our Fall session will begin on Monday, September 28.

(Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.)

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group at the Dedham High School Track.

Our Couch to 5K will end with the "Dedham Turkey Trot" on Thanksgiving morning.
results.name: Fall Couch to 5K

results.description:
Dr. Connie Cepko:
Quite a Sight! Gene Therapy to Treat Blindness

Join us on October 12th at 7:00pm at the Burren, for Science by the Pint.

From Dr. Cepko's lab website:
The mechanisms that cells use when they choose their fate during development of the central nervous system is the main problem under study in our lab. We have focussed our studies on the retina, a tractable model for the rest of the central nervous system. In addition, we are interested in why photoreceptor cells die in the many forms of retinal degeneration, and are developing a gene therapy that prevents their death and the subsequent loss of vision. We also enjoy developing new technologies that enable these studies as well as others.

Science by the Pint is sponsored by an organization of Harvard graduate students called Science in the News.  In between their sleepless hours of hard work at Harvard Med School, they bring cutting edge scientific research to the public in a fun and informal format. 


The Burren is located on Elm Street right in the heart of Davis Square, just a short walk from the Red Line stop.  If you prefer to drive, there are metered spots on the street and in nearby municipal lots (see link below).  Meters are active until 8:00 PM, and metered spots are free thereafter. Municipal lot meters are good for three hours, and street spots are good for two.

Links:

SITN Facebook Page

SITN: Science by the Pint

The Burren

Davis Square Parking
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the back room starting at 6:30.  Lecture starts at 7PM.  I will (possibly) be wearing a nerdy Meetup pin graciously on loan from Doreen.
results.name: Science by the Pint: Quite a Sight! Gene Therapy to Treat Blindness

results.description:
Juno award winning singer and song writer, Rose Cousins is performing two special shows on Monday October 12 at Club Passim in Cambridge. In celebration of Thanksgiving the chef has created a special "Thanksgiving themed" burger along with pumpkin pie.  There will also be multiple options created for the occasion, with input from Rose, and some surprises from her personally.  :)

There will be two shows one at  7pm and 9:30pm. 

Here is a message from Rose:

For several years I have celebrated CANADIAN THANKSGIVING in Boston, among friends.
You know, a feast of turkey, stuffing, gravy, potato, sweet potato, peas, turnips, brussels sprouts and pumpkin pie followed by stomach distension, loose pants, tea & GRATITUDE! This year, YOU ARE INVITED to celebrate my country’s seasonal harvest at Club Passim.

JOIN ME for CANADIAN THANKSGIVING!
Oct 12, 2015 TWO SHOWS 7 p.m. & 9:30 p.m. Chef Michael will create a special Thanksgiving burger and salad, and I will bring the pumpkin pie! The incredible Duke Levine will join me along with a few familiar friends for a thankfulness showdown. 

See you there, Rose Cousins

ROSE COUSINS is an award-winning songwriter, singer, and recording artist from Canada.  Originally from Prince Edward Island, she now lives in Halifax, Nova Scotia and performs across the United States, Canada, Europe and Australia. 
Her JUNO award winning album WE HAVE MADE A SPARK was named to NPR's Top 10 Americana & Folk Albums of 2012, won 3 ECMAs, the Canadian Folk Music Award for Best Contemporary Singer, and was long-listed for the prestigious Polaris Prize in Canada.  In America, she's been recognized by USA Today (Pick of the Week), Oprah Magazine, WFUV, WXPN and various other media outlets for SPARK and the short film IF I SHOULD FALL BEHIND about the community in Boston where it was made (rosecousins.com/film).  Her songs have appeared in many films and television shows - most notably "Go First" and "Let The Light Come In" were featured on Grey's Anatomy. 
In September 2014, she released an EP collection of covers and originals called STRAY BIRDS.  In 2015, Cousins has further expanded her business, releasing Newfoundland duo Fortunate Ones’ debut record THE BLISS on her label Old Farm Pony Records.
 “achingly candid” USA Today

“excellent balance of despair and hope” WFUV New York

“haunting and beautiful” WXPN Philadelphia

“Some voices hit you hard from first blush and this is one of them.” Exclaim!

“rich emotional nuances… gorgeous vocals… astonishing harmonies” Chromewaves

"dark and sweet and totally powerful" Uptown Winnipeg ★★★★
"Stark, impeccably written songs ... elegantly understated ..." NOW Toronto ★★★★★

“It’s no wonder Cousins is the object of audience affection…” The Boston Globe

"Her lyrics are direct and forthright, her voice is crystal clear" The Irish Times ★★★★
"conviction and heart ... haunting to uplifting in an instant" Maverick UK ★★★★

WEBSITE:  www.rosecousins.com
PRESS KIT:  rosecousins.com/media-tools

SHORT FILM: rosecousins.com/film

results.description:
Brand new or frequent inventor? Entrepreneur launching a great idea? From twinkle in your eye to patents to overseas procurement to licensing your idea, we support and help you. Doors open at 6:30 for socializing; meeting begins at 7 PM.

IANE, Inventor's Association of New England meetings are free to members with a suggested small donation for visitors at the name badge table. Annual membership is $40 per year. Every month we have interesting speakers and topics. Each June we have a members +1 social at a suburban location.

Our usual meeting location is at MIT, building 4 just to the East of the Dome. There is free street parking along Memorial Drive, Vassar St. or Ames St. On Google maps, zoom in on MIT and the building numbers will appear, so you'll know where to go. The Dome is Building 10, behind Killian Court, and building 4 is to the right. Leave at least 10 minutes to walk from your car to the room. The area is amazingly safe to walk at night; the MIT students don't know when to stop so are always around.

results.description: Let's meet under a dark sky (as this night is a moonless night) and bring a pair of binoculars with you. For those of you who've ever wondered: "What's that really bright star-looking thing up there that's not moving"? This event might be for you! I'm looking to see if this can work to draw out some people in this Meet-up and will be cross-posting in another Meet-up too so we can get some really good participation. The basic idea is that we all bring some celestial object to share that we've found by our own observations of the night sky. I want to facilitate this but the intent will not be Jim entertaining you all with my vast knowledge of the night sky. (Even though it was said on more than one occasion that I took up "space" in college) You MUST participate "actively" by bringing one or more of the following three things; 1.) Binoculars, 2.) A Telescope, 3.) One or more celestial deep sky treasures that you've researched and can locate in the night sky to share with the group. I'll be bringing all three myself. I also have a pair of binoculars with a mounting that allows for people of all heights to see very well. I'm testing this event in a three different meet-ups to see if it can get some participation and if it's an idea to host regularly.

results.description:
Science and Cooking returns! - A semester-long public lecture series that pairs Harvard University professors with popular chefs and food experts to showcase the science behind different cooking techniques. This lecture series is sponsored by the Harvard University John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. 

Full schedule below and HERE. Free and open to the public. 

:: :: ::

Lecture 5) Monday, Oct. 12 - Science and Emotions: Delicious or Disgusting? - Andoni Aduriz, (@mugaritz), Mugaritz and Ramon Perisé, Mugaritz

(Shouldn't this be entitled "Food and Emotions ...? - S. )

:: :: ::

These public lectures are based on the Harvard course “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” but do not replicate course content. Unless otherwise noted, all talks take place in the Harvard Science Center (1 Oxford St., Cambridge, Mass., Hall C) and begin at 7 p.m. Each presentation begins with a 15-minute lecture by a faculty member from the Harvard course, who will discuss one of the scientific topics from that week’s classSeating for all lectures is first come, first seated. If you have questions regarding this public lecture series, please contact [masked]. 

Sample Lecture: Explorations of Chocolate Textures [Lecture 4 (2012)]

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tt9g2se1LcM&index=10&list=PL546CD09EA2399DAB


 Full schedule

Lecture 1) Monday, Sept. 7 - Thinking about Flavor - Dave Arnold (@CookingIssues), Booker & Dax, and host of “Cooking Issues” and Harold McGee (@Harold_McGee), writer, “Curious Cook”


Lecture 2) Monday, Sept. 14 - Pasta Magic - Mark Ladner, (@ChefMarkLadner), Del Posto

Lecture 3) Monday, Sept. 21 - The Science of Sugar - Joanne Chang ’91, (@jbchang), Flour Bakery, author of “Flour” and “Flour Too”

Lecture 4) Monday, Sept. 28 - Title TBA* - *Jim Lahey, (@jimlaheySSB), Sullivan Street Bakery

Lecture 5) Monday, Oct. 12 - Science and Emotions: Delicious or Disgusting? - Andoni Aduriz, (@mugaritz), Mugaritz and Ramon Perisé, Mugaritz

Lecture 6) Monday, Oct. 19 - Heat Transfer to Capture Flavors - Josep Roca, (@CanRocaCeller), El Celler de Can Roca and Raül Sillero, El Celler de Can Roca

Lecture 7) <Location TBA> Tuesday, Oct. 27 - Viscosity and Polymers - José Andrés, (@chefjoseandres), ThinkFoodGroup

Lecture 8) Monday, Nov. 2 - Title TBA - Bryan Voltaggio, (@BryanVoltaggio), Volt*Michael Voltaggio, (@MVoltaggio), Ink

Lecture 9) Monday, Nov. 16 - Fermentation on Wheels: Food Education and Community Impact - Tara Whitsitt, (@tarawhitsitt), Fermentation on Wheels

Lecture 10) Monday, Nov. 23 - Title TBA - Nathan Myhrvold, (@ModernCuisine), former Chief Technology Officer of Microsoft, co-founder of Intellectual Ventures, author of “Modernist Cuisine”

Lecture 11) Monday, Dec. 7 - Title TBA - Tom Colicchio, (@tomcolicchio), “Top Chef” judge and chef/owner, Craft Hospitality, and Mei Lin, (@meilin21), “Top Chef” season 12 winner, and Gail Simmons, (@gailsimmons), “Top Chef” judge, Culinary expert, and Food & Wine magazine Special Projects Director

:: :: ::

The Harvard College Course: The Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS) and the Alícia Foundation developed a General Education science course, “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” which debuted in the fall of 2010. The course uses food and cooking to explicate fundamental principles in applied physics and engineering. (Watch a video about the course.) Limited to currently enrolled Harvard undergraduates, the class brings together eminent Harvard researchers and world-class chefs. 

:: :: ::

A version of “Science and Cooking” is offered for credit through the Harvard Extension School. An online course will be offered in the fall and spring semesters. Registered students will have access to the expertise and support of Harvard teaching staff.

:: :: ::

For more info visit <a>www.seas.harvard.edu.</a>

Contact: [masked].
results.name: Science and Cooking  (5) Science and Emotions: Delicious or Disgusting?

results.description:
2 Player Games, ANY Game (Previously X-Wing Miniatures)

An opportunity to play those two player games that we do not play on a regular (mostly euro?) boardgaming night.  

If we have an odd number of players, or if we just feel like it, yes, it is fine doing a 3, 4 or 5 player game as well. 

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played? 


Anything.  Bring anything that you think will gather enough interest.  Examples: Netrunner, Marvel Dice Masters, Memoir '44, Twilight Struggle, Few Acres of Snow or even chess if that is your thing.  Put other suggestions on the event comments.

Will try this format a couple of times to see how it goes.

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it?

results.description:
IMPORTANT NOTE: This game night is a special case because it is also hosting the Beantown Gamers Math Trade!  Because the Math Trade will take up several tables and involve a number of people attending who normally don't, the RSVP cap is much lower for this event.

NEW MEMBERS: Because we expect to be very full, please choose another game night to start attending our group.  We apologize for the inconvenience!

If you are part of the Math Trade, please do NOT RSVP here; your spot is already figured into the numbers.  Thanks!

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

BEANTOWN GAMERS RSVP POLICY:

1. You must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.

3. If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 48 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

4. If you would like to come but there are no spots, send Tucker a message.

5. We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 48 hours, or frequently cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

6. If you use a "+1" spot, all of the above applies to you and your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
Exploring Mindful Self-Compassion with Kristy Arbon. Self-compassion is the emotional attitude of mindfulness when it contacts suffering. While mindful awareness is typically directed toward moment-to-moment experience, self-compassion focuses on the experiencer. Mindfulness says, “Open to your suffering with spacious awareness and it will change.” Self-compassion adds, “Be kind to yourself in the midst of suffering and it will change.” Mindfulness asks “What do I know?” and self-compassion asks, “What do I need?” Self-compassion can be learned by anyone, even those who didn’t receive enough affection in childhood or struggling with feeling deserving.

Kristy Arbon is the Administrative Director for IMP and also the Administrative Director for the Center for Mindful Self-Compassion. She teaches the Mindful Self-Compassion (MSC) program developed by Chris Germer and Kristin Neff, in the US, New Zealand and Australia. She teaches so that she can learn and she learns so that she can teach. She offers a regular MSC with Susan Pollak, President of the Board of IMP, at The Arlington Center

This monthly continuing education (CE) program presented by the Institute For Meditation & Psychotherapy is for psychotherapists interested in Buddhist psychology, meditation, or mindfulness. Each lecture will address theoretical and clinical issues at the interface of these rich healing traditions, with topics ranging from addictions to forgiveness to countertransference. These community evenings offer an opportunity to gather with colleagues in an informal setting to explore the intersection between Buddhist psychology and modern psychotherapy. This year’s presenters are long- term meditators with significant expertise in practice and in teaching. Each presentation will be followed by Q&A and discussion, moderated by Christopher Willard, PsyD. 2 CE’s are offered each evening to psychologists, social workers, nurses, LMFTs and LMHCs. $25/members of IMP, $30/non-members, $10/mental health students with ID. 9-month series $175/members, $225/non-members ~ no refunds > missed sessions

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during nautical twilight.


The best time then is 5:30 to 6:30 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.
results.how_to_find_us: This is not a group event, it is an individual challenge
results.name: Challenge: Capture the Zodiacal Light

The hike is fairly easy with some moderate terrain, making it a perfect hike for the entire family. Friends of the Blue Hills will provide a snack and some water before the hike. Please dress in layers (no cotton) for the weather, wear appropriate hiking footwear and bring sunscreen, rain gear, a day pack, water, lunch, extra clothing and any personal medicine you may need. Take in the sights with your camera and/or binoculars if you have them.
Please RSPV to llbean.com/dedham to reserve your spot

Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

All are welcome.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
How Rachel Carson Became a Revolutionary: Environmental Politics and the Public Sphere

Please RSVP to [masked]. Seminars are free and open to the public, but an RSVP is required. More Info and Event-Link HERE (scroll down). Subscribe HERE to receive seminar papers. 

Tuesday, October 13th, 5:15-7:30pm

Massachusetts Historical Society

1154 Boylston Street, Boston

:: :: ::

Silent Spring is generally considered a foundational text of the modern environmental movement. However, this paper contends that Rachel Carson’s legacy is more mixed than the historical memory about her allows. This essay considers the surprisingly varied reception of Silent Spring over the last five decades. Ultimately, it argues, that assessment that Carson's work was revolutionary reflects the vicissitudes of environmental politics as much as anything intrinsic to the book itself.

David Hecht, Bowdoin College

Comment: Chris Bosso, Northeastern University
results.name: Rachel Carson

A dramatic thriller set against the backdrop of a series of historic events, DreamWorks Pictures/Fox 2000 Pictures’ “Bridge of Spies” is the story of James Donovan, a Brooklyn lawyer who finds himself thrust into the center of the Cold War when the CIA sends him on the near-impossible task to negotiate the release of a captured American U-2 pilot. Screenwriters Matt Charman and Ethan Coen & Joel Coen have woven this remarkable experience in Donovan’s life into a story inspired by true events that captures the essence of a man who risked everything and vividly brings his personal journey to life.

Directed by three-time Academy Award®-winning director Steven Spielberg, “Bridge of Spies” stars: two-time Academy Award winner Tom Hanks as James Donovan; three-time Tony Award® winner Mark Rylance as Rudolf Abel, a KGB agent defended by Donovan; Scott Shepherd as CIA operative Hoffman; Academy Award nominee Amy Ryan as James’ wife, Mary; Sebastian Koch as East German lawyer Vogel; and Academy Award nominee Alan Alda as Thomas Watters, a partner at Donovan’s law firm. The film is produced by Spielberg, Marc Platt and Kristie Macosko Krieger with Adam Somner, Daniel Lupi, Jeff Skoll and Jonathan King serving as executive producers. The screenplay is by Matt Charman and three-time Academy Award winners Ethan Coen & Joel Coen. “Bridge of Spies” will be released in theaters on October 16, 2015 from Touchstone Pictures.

Website: http://www.bridgeofspies.com
Like us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/BridgeOfSpies
Follow us on Twitter: @BridgeOfSpies

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,

Harvard's David Rockefeller Center for Latin American Studies is hosting a free screening of Brazilian film, "Olhos de Botao" (Button Eyes).

***

http://drclas.harvard.edu/event/artsdrclas-film-series-olhos-de-bot%C3%A3o

Olhos de Botão (Button Eyes, 2015) is a fictional suspense film, set in the seemingly serene countryside of Pernambuco, Brazil. An elderly couple, Miguel and Dora, lives in isolation with little to say to each other. One day Miguel finds a lost, homeless young girl near the farm, and the couple decides to take her in a decision that upends their routine and relationship. It's a great little haunting film that keeps you intrigued to the end. The three main characters provide a fascinating triangle of different emotions with an intense battle that grips the viewer between Dora and Julia throughout. A weel thought out and interesting concept, leaving frustrating but enjoyable questions for the viewer.

http://www.imdb.com/title/tt4478634/synopsis?ref_=ttt_ov_pl

http://www.imdb.com/title/tt4478634/synopsis?ref_=ttt_ov_pl


Screening and workshop with director Marlom Meirelles. Moderated by Richard Peña, Visiting Professor, Department of Visual and Environmental Studies, Harvard University; Professor of Film, Columbia University; Director Emeritus, New York Film Festival

***

There will be light food and beverages starting at 5:30 pm.  The screening starts at 5:45 pm.  I have changed the start time of this event from 5:15 to 5:30 pm.  I know that 5:30 pm is a little early for most people. If you are not able to connect before the film, make sure to connect with members after the film.  I will hang out at exit for a little while immediately following the film.  Most likely there will be a reception in lobby, so I encourage you to mingle and look for Meetup members.  

The auditorium is located inside the building, downstairs.  

Just a reminder, this is an actual meet-up event, not an advertisement. For events to be successful, I need to know who to expect and how many.


This is certainly a free and public event and all are welcome to attend regardless if you belong to this Meet-Up group.  I only ask that you only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and intend to meet members of the group. If you reserve "YES" and then have a change of plans, no problem, please update the attendance reservation.  A consistent history of not showing up for events may cause you to be removed from the group.

I look forward to seeing you all at this event.

Joana

***
