results.description:
We are expanding opportunities for participating in the Boston LS user group and will hold this meetup virtually. 


Click on hyperlink to review Information for connecting to the virtual event - 

You will need to have a headset or earbuds to hear audio and you can either use your devise microphone or ideally have a USB microphone headset. Have everything plugged in before you enter the room.

●  Enter the virtual space - http://adaptknowledge.adobeconnect.com/ls/

●  Please login in the space labeled “guest” -- enter the name you would like to have displayed.

Once in the room everyone will be given audio permission.


Overview of the Virtual LS Meetup



Purpose:

Identify, understand and maximize the opportunities we have to engage our colleagues, customers, stakeholders etc. by using LS and other structural approaches in meetings, project initiatives and group gatherings of all kinds.

Outcomes and Next Actions:

·  Build awareness of how structure impacts the way we meet, talk and think together.

·  Explore how new structural approaches expand and shift your current engagements.

·  Prepare to apply a single LS in an existing engagement expand participation, increase creative input

Flow of the Meetup:

1.Introductions and share out of framing question:

What challenges do you or a group you are part of have in engaging stakeholders for initiating or sustaining projects and generating innovations?

2.Application/Experience: Use the LS known as “Purpose to Practice” (P2P) to define the elements of our learning and working together.

We will do a complete round of all 5 elements.  For each event we will use/practice 1, 4, ALL as the "structure" for conversation around these five questions.  (review the LS 1,2,4,ALL on the LS site)

1.  Purpose: Why is the work important to you and the larger community?

2.  Principles: What rules must we obey in pursuit of our purpose?

3.  Participants: Who must be included to achieve our purpose?

4.  Structure: How will we organize to distribute control?

5.  Practices: What are we going to do? What will we offer to our users/clients? How?

We will share the output with the entire Boston group and all invited to add to the 5 elements.


Debrief the results and experience of working with P2P

What was surprising?

What is unclear or needs additional engagement/conversations?

How will this model provide value to participants both in our work together and in their outside projects?

How is P2P typically applied in a face-face setting? What is it best used for?

3. Reflections and Next Actions:
results.name: A Virtual Liberating Structures Meetup

results.description:
In an early stage company, as a sales rep, you often need to build the foundation of your sales strategy and customer base with little to no marketing.

One approach is to build out an inbound marketing strategy from the very beginning and create buzz. The downside is you generate a great deal of interest but spend a lot of time on unqualified leads.

The second approach is to build your early sales success leveraging your network, your early customer success and very targeted outreach approach.

We will dive into this second approach with our special guest Melyssa Plunkett-Gomez, a Boston startup sales veteran from companies like Crimson Hexagon, Unica, Kana, Crashlytics, and now Allego.  Come join us for this in depth conversation, networking with industry peers, and a ton of great selling insights!


Sponsors


Allego provides an intuitive just-in-time sales learning platform that boosts sales performance by transforming enablement and training through video content sharing.  As the only mobile-first, video-optimized solution, Allego ensures rapid adoption of the most relevant content from the field, on any device, designed for the distributed workforce. Over 10,000 global users rely on Allego to capture their best ideas, master their pitch and accelerate their performance. Explore further at www.allego.com.

WeWork is a community for creators. We transform buildings into beautiful, collaborative workspaces and provide infrastructure, services, events and technology so our members can focus on doing what they love. We currently have 43 locations in sixteen cities with over 25,000 members. Book a tour at www.wework.com.

Spiro is the personal sales app for quota-carrying salespeople who want to make more money.  You can sign up for their private beta now at spirohq.com.
results.name: Selling Before Marketing

results.description:
A viable, early stage, Cybersecurity product might be the most difficult of all startup products to build. Cybersecurity products must be flawless and exude a high level of credibility to the customer. This puts an immense amount of pressure on the design team to bring a disciplined and thoughtful approach to early stage product design and development.

Join us on 10/13 at Accomplice to learn more about designing cybersecurity products and catch up with others in the UX & Cybersecurity communities. RESERVE YOUR TICKET HERE!!!

Our topics and speakers for the evening include:

Disciplined Design; Shortcuts to Learning without Building

Dan Matiaudes - Designer @ Zensight

Writing and sustaining code is expensive. At a startup the idea is always to use the most lean methods to learn and iterate. Using design sprints as a way to create shortcuts to building solutions for the big hairy problems allows you as a team to remain nimble and get to a working system quicker.

Designing Cybersecurity Products from Scratch
Dustin Webber - CTO @ Critical Stack

RSVP & RESERVE YOUR TICKET HERE

results.description:
**********************************

Agenda: Double Bill!


**********************************

Social Linked Data - a Solid effort to re-decentralize the Web


 Andrei Sambra - MIT/W3C

Solid is an exciting new project lead by Prof. Tim Berners-Lee, inventor of the World Wide Web, which aims to radically change the way Web applications work today, resulting in true data ownership as well as improved privacy.

ABOUT THE SPEAKER


Andrei Sambra is a researcher at MIT, working on Small (Linked) Data -- personal data/content about a specific user. He is interested in topics such as identity, authentication, data ownership, and in general by all Web technologies that help re-decentralize the Web.

-------------------------------------------

Linked Research 

Sarven Capadisli, MIT 

Linked Research (LR) is intended to influence a (paradigm) shift in scholarly communication by fostering the use of the native Web stack. LR proposes an acid test to the research community in order to verify, approve, or test the openness, accessibility and flexibility of the approaches for enhanced scholarly communication. The LR authoring tool is a candidate towards this interoperable initiative.


ABOUT THE SPEAKER


Sarven Capadisli is a Linked Data technologist; primarily working on statistical linked dataspaces and promoting the "Linked Research" initiative.

results.description:
This meeting is sponsored by AKAMAI.

Spring Boot, the new convention-over-configuration centric framework from the 
Spring team at Pivotal, marries Spring’s flexibility with conventional, common sense defaults to make application development not just fly but awesome! Join Spring developer advocate Miya W. Longwe for a look at what Spring Boot is, why it’s gaining momentum, and why you should consider it for your next applications ((REST, web, batch, big-data, integration, whatever!) and how to get started. The session will be live coding of a fully functioning REST application using Spring Data  Mongodb and Spring Boot.

Miya W. Longwe is a Senior Software Engineer and Tech Lead at Healthedge, Burlington, Massachusetts where he is currently working on a software product that provides the integrated financial, administrative and clinical software platform for healthcare payers. He has been software professional since 1997.  His 16 years software development career includes working for large companies to small startups, building solutions for enterprises and consumers, working with a broad range of technologies. He is a hands-on java developer. He believes that in order to be a relevant and effective software developer one needs to remain a deeply knowledgeable, up-to-date, and productive software developer.  His research interests include model-driven engineering, domain specific languages, test driven development and project risk management.Miya graduated from the University of Malawi (Lilongwe, Malawi) and has an MBA from the University of Wales Cardiff Business School (Wales, UK) and a Masters in Software Engineering from Brandeis University (MA, USA).

Occasionally, Miya can be spotted fishing the banks of the south shore (MA) with his two boys, William and Daniel.
results.name: Java and Services: Code Lab-Spring Boot and Spring Data using MongoDB

results.description:
If you signed up and paid for the class, but you did not receive an email with the announcement below regarding location instructions, it means you did not submit your Google form below. Please fill it out. Also, please read the announcement below for location + logistics information.

http://goo.gl/forms/JEI3z2kGu1 


ANNOUNCEMENT 1:

I hope all is going swimmingly on this pleasant autumn afternoon. I’ve got some information for you. It’s all important, so make sure you read this in full.

Location:

If you’re a Wayfair employee:

The class will be held in Cornice / Baluster on the 7th floor. Skip to the next header.

If you’re not a Wayfair employee:

Here are the instructions to get to the office. First go into Copley Mall and go to the center of it. At the very center of the mall, there are water works and lots of huge tropical-looking plants. Stores nearby include Dior, Hugo Boss, and Williams Sonoma. There will be elevators on one side of the mall, across from BCBG Max Azria, and then escalators on the other. Take the elevators up to the “SKYLOBBY”. There will be someone at the security desk. They will need your ID. We will have provided a list of people to attend the event.

When you get past security, go to "4 Copley Place." Once inside those doors, get on an elevator and go up to the 7th floor. There will be a reception desk that will point you to the room that we will be in: “Baluster / Cornice.” If there’s no one at the reception, then go past the reception desk and slightly to the left, where there will be two doors to a large room. That’s where the class is held.

Note: give yourself **PLENTY** of time to find our office, especially for the first class. I’d say to give yourself a 15 minute cushion. Traffic around the area can be bad, and it takes a shockingly long time to navigate yourself around the mall. It will be all right if you get here early because we’ll have TAs hanging around starting at 6:00.

Non-Mac users:

As this class will be taught via Mac, it’s important that you get to the first class 30 -40 minutes earlier so that you can set up your computer accordingly. We’ll have instructions printed out and two TAs on hand in that time to help you set up.

You need:

1)  Your laptop

2)  Your charger

3)  To eat beforehand / bring food with you

Bathrooms:

When you exit the room, walk straight past the reception desk, and then hang a right. Bathrooms are near the kitchen.

Looking forward to meeting you all on Tuesday, October 13th at 6:30 pm (or 6:00 pm if you’re a non-Mac user).

Cheers,

Emily

###################################


ABOUT:

In this class, we'll teach you how to program in PHP. Our goal is to take it slow and break each topic down into digestible pieces so that you'll walk away with a strong understanding of programming fundamentals.

Though we are focusing on PHP, a widely used language that powers sites like Facebook, Youtube, Wordpress, Wikipedia, and Wayfair, the concepts that you learn will be transportable to any programming language. 

We'll meet Tuesdays and Thursdays for two weeks, starting on October 13th. See below for the schedule.

SCHEDULE:


We'll meet on Tuesdays and Thursdays for two weeks, starting on October 13th:

October 13th: 6:30 - 8:30pm (come in at 6:00 to get set up if you do not have a mac)

October 15th: 6:30 - 8:30pm

October 20th: 6:30 - 8:30pm

October 22nd: 6:30 - 8:30pm


TOPICS WE'LL COVER:

• variables

• basic data structures

• loops

• if/else statements & case switch statements

• basic control flow

• functions 

LEARNING STYLE

The class will be structured so that it will alternate between classroom style lecture and hands-on coding for the duration of the class. 


GOALS:

We want you to walk away with a strong understanding of how to code and be able to solve a basic programming puzzle, much like the ones that developers get asked in job interviews.


REQUIREMENTS:

****No programming background needed.**** 

This class caters to newcomers, beginners, and those who want a stronger grasp of their fundamentals.

You will need to bring a laptop and charger.

***If you do not have a Mac, please come to the first class 30 minutes earlier to get everything set up.***


WHO CAN TAKE THE CLASS?

You do not have to be a woman to join our class---we are an inclusive organization and welcome any gender or identity.



INSTRUCTOR:

Emily Xie is passionate about teaching and helping others learn to code. She has previously taught advanced object oriented programming at BostonPHP, and she currently works at Wayfair as a software engineer. In her spare time, she enjoys cooking, photography, and playing Age of Empires II. 

https://www.linkedin.com/in/xieemily


https://twitter.com/emilyxxie


HEAD TA:

Aaron Oehlschlaeger.

**All attendees are expected to abide by the Girl Develop It Code of Conduct.**


https://www.girldevelopit.com/code-of-conduct

Speakers BIO:

Steve Hughes is a Principal Consultant Lead at Pragmatic Works. His area of expertise is in data and business intelligence architecture on the Microsoft SQL Server platform. He was also the data architect for a SaaS company which delivered a transportation management solution for fleets across the United States. Steve has co-authored three books and delivered many presentations on SQL Server and data architecture over the past six years.  He also provides insights from the field on his blog at http://www.dataonwheels.com.

Anthony Martin is a Principal Consultant for Pragmatic Works.  His area of expertise is in business intelligence and predictive analytics.  As a Principal Consultant, Anthony plays an important role understanding customer’s BI project requirements, and with a wealth of project experience, is able to recommend optimal solutions.  In addition, he is a major PASS speaker/contributor, and a Microsoft Virtual Technology Specialist (V-TSP).

results.description:
*** Not an official meetup but a free event that might be of interest to out members***

Please register on the website:

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/measuring-and-motivating-health-behavior-change-using-mobile-technology-with-stephen-intille-tickets-18526374886


From the event announcement:

Measuring Behavior and Motivating Health Behavior Change Using Mobile Technology: Opportunities and (Difficult) Challenges
Stephen Intille, Ph.D., Associate Professor in the College of Computer and Information Science and Bouvé College of Health Sciences, Northeastern University

Abstract
New mobile apps and wearable devices for measuring health-related behavior and motivating health behavior change are being introduced by academia and industry at a dizzying rate. There are certainly some exciting opportunities in “just-in-time” behavioral measurement and intervention technologies enabled by these technologies. There are also, however, some major hurdles to overcome to prove that these new ideas lead to meaningful improvements in health. Part of the challenge is that short-term behavior change may be relatively easy, but maintaining behavior change is fundamentally difficult for most people to do. To address this, transdisciplinary teams of technologists and behavioral scientists must work together to deploy prototype technologies in “messy,” real-world settings for relatively long periods of time. I will discuss some of my group’s experiences building and deploying systems for measuring or motivating behavior change, with special focus on an app for weight loss, and use them to frame some challenges practitioners designing interfaces for health technologies may want to consider going forward.

Bio
Stephen Intille, Ph.D., is an Associate Professor in the College of Computer and Information Science and Bouvé College of Health Sciences at Northeastern University. His research focuses on the development of novel healthcare technologies that incorporate ideas from ubiquitous computing, user-interface design, pattern recognition, behavioral science, and preventive medicine. Areas of special interest include technologies for measuring and motivating health-related behaviors, technologies that support healthy aging and well-being in the home setting, and mobile technologies that permit longitudinal measurement of health behaviors for research, especially the type, duration, intensity, and location of physical activity.
For more on Stephen Intille see http://www.ccs.neu.edu/home/intille/cv-web/bio.htm.

Evening Schedule
6:30 – 7:00 Networking over pizza and beverages
7:00 – 8:30 Meeting
8:30 – 9:00 CHI Dessert and more networking!

Sponsors
IBM Research is hosting us and providing food.
results.name: Measuring & Motivating Health Behavior Change Using Mobile Technology

These sessions at Baby Pool/Charlestown Navy Yard will focus on a 6 week rotating schedule of classes designed to introduce the basics of Parkour in concentrate classes. The schedule will follow in order: 

• Safety, Landings and Balance

Class 1 will be focusing on how to land, move and stay safe practicing Parkour outdoor and in the real world. 

• Vaulting

Class 2 will focus on the foundation of Parkour - getting over low-level obstacles fast and efficiently through the use of vaulting.

• Precisions

Class 3 will focus on accuracy of jumping and foot/eye coordination honing basic standing and running jumps.

• Wall Techniques 

Class 4 will focus on conquering obstacles too large or tall to vault, in tandem with using walls as a means to keep a more efficient run.

• Tumbling/Acro

Class 5 focus is on tumbling and acrobatic skills, in pursuit of fully understanding movement in a 3D space and total proprioception.

• Flow + Speed

Class 6 links together all the previous lessons into one cohesive movement, and a timed obstacle course setting.

------

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 


This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/

Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.

The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed. All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
WHY ME?  Understanding Karma

a meditation class series 

TUESDAYS | OCT 13th - NOV 17th


7:00 - 8:30pm

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis

Do you ever wonder why certain things, good or bad, happen to you? How can an understanding of Karma change things for the better?

Karma means ‘action’. Every action we perform leaves an imprint on our very subtle mind and each imprint eventually gives rise to its own effect. Our mind is like a field and performing actions is like sowing seeds in that field. In this series, we will explore Buddha’s teachings on Karma. We will learn how to apply its wisdom into our daily lives in beautiful meditations, so that we can learn to accept our present circumstances and joyfully cultivate our future happiness.

Each class includes a short talk and two guided meditations. Everyone welcome - no experience necessary.  

Drop in anytime! No need to pre-registration. 

Cost | $10 per class / $5 students & seniors.  Members FREE! 

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

For more info please call[masked] or email [masked]

results.description:
Insight is one of the all-time favorite seminars of many old-time PGN members.  And, surprisingly, it is also a favorite of new PGN members who happened to take it when it was last in town.  

Why?  Because it applies proven methods of awareness and transformation across numerous, essential parts of your life.  

In an intense, but exhilarating, three day workshop, you discover how to finally become the true you that you've always wanted to be but didn't know how to uncover.  You will leave with numerous tools, many of which you will use for the rest of your life, and with a glimpse of how your life would soar if you applied all those tools regularly.


Come join us for an informal conversation about how Insight will change your life. 

A small, diverse panel of Insight graduates will share their experiences:  
- How they (finally?) decided to take Insight; 
- What were their experiences in the room;
- What were the immediate changes after the workshop;
- What have the long-term benefits been; and,
- Why, after a year, after a few years, and, for a couple of them, after decades, they still hold their Insight I in such high regard. 

Come and talk about where you are in your own life, and where you would like to be, if you had the insight to get there.

Panelists Include:

Susan Treichel

Software Developmental Analyst (Meditech)

Kirsten Jettinghoff

https://cdn3.sussexdirectories.com/rms/rms_photos/sized/61/99/179961-286212-2_120x150.jpg?pu=1401276126

Mental Health Counselor

Pam Haley

Host of Heartbeat Salon-MetroWest North

Dennis Pratt

Founder of the Personal Growth Network 


Why Should You Go?

Insight is often cited by graduates as one of the most profound and uplifting weekends they have ever experienced in their lives.  But the opportunity to take this seminar is not often available.

The Insight I Seminar is back in town -- scheduled for October 23-25, 2015 in Woburn.
- - > http://www.meetup.com/Personal-Growth-Network/events/220690183/

An Insight Teen Seminar is also scheduled -- for February 18-21, 2016 in Dedham 
- - > http://www.meetup.com/Personal-Growth-Network/events/221875651/

These workshops are offered rarely.   The last adult Insight was a year ago.  The last Teen Insight was a decade ago.

Join us for this discussion about the amount of insight one needs for life.   Maybe you too would love a little Insight into your life.


A Bit About Insight 


Insight is offered all around the World from Australia to South America to England to Bulgaria, and the list goes on and on.   Insight has been offered in the Boston area, off and on, since 1979.  Occasional workshops returned to our region about three years ago after a decade-long absence.

Come join us and hear from local graduates, recent and long-ago, about their experience of Insight and how the seminar transformed their lives.
results.name: Insight: Bring Insight to Your Life

This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

We'll meet at 7:40, Pray Evening Prayer (stand to the right of the entrance door at exactly so that we can  start & finish the Divine Office before the event starts at  8:00PM--PLEASE BRING AN UMBRELLA ON CASE IT RAINS!) and before going out fto thr Cosmo & Damien Festival in East Cambridge, we'll partake in the Rosary Candlelight Procession. 

We will meet afterwards and get a bite to eat at a local place, such as Anna's Taqueria in Brookline at 446 Harvard Street.

http://www.annastaqueria.com/

Have the following link setup for Evening  Prayer:

<a>http://divineoffice.org/ord-w04-tue-ep/?title=Oct+13%2C+Evening+Prayer+for+Tuesday+in+the+28th+week+of+Ordinary+Time&date=20151013#sthash.BCWITmfL.dpbs</a> 


 Our Lady of Fatima appeared in Fatima, Portugal to 3 children, which started on May 13, 1917. Our Lady appeared many times. She promised that she will perform a miracle. On October 13, 1917, she fulfilled her promise to a crowd of more than 70,000 people. They witnessed the Miracle of the Sun. A replica of the Miracle is embedded on the wall of the Shrine of Our Lady of Fatima in Boston, MA. The message was not only for the children. It is also for the world. It was for this reason that the Crusaders of Fatima came into existence in Boston. It was in 1957 that the First Saturday Group started the First Saturday Devotion. The devotion has a Mass at 9:00 AM followed by the rosary at 10 AM. A Candlelight Procession is also celebrated on the 13th of the months from May to October. The Shrine of Our Lady of Fatima in Brighton was made to provide the people a place to pray. Today the Shrine is open from 10:00 AM-6:00 PM everyday Monday to Sunday. Rosary for World Peace is said every Sunday at 3:00 PM. There were many men and women of hope who made the Shrine available for us. They knew the Message of Peace and the importance thereof in the future. They believed that we will need a place such as the Shrine of Our Lady of Fatima. The message of Our Lady of Fatima… “I am the Lady of the Rosary…When my Immaculate Heart triumphs…Then, there will be Peace.” May 13, 2017 will be the 100th anniversary of Our Lady of Fatima Apparition. Let us start the preparation for the Celebration. Join us to continue to pray for peace in each of our own families, peace in our communities, peace in our country, and peace in our World.
results.name: Candle Light Procession Our Lady of Fatima Shrine in Brighton, Massachusetts 8PM

results.description:
Essence of Healing is excited to present teacher and speaker

CAROL DEARBORN for a FREE talk about:

YOUR BODY, YOUR WELL BEING, YOUR LIFE!

Tuesday October 13th 7:30pm

• How can we understand the seeming opposites of Western (or Northern, if you prefer) medicine and the truth of energetic healing?

• How much of what your Western doctor says is your real prognosis?

• How can you be true to your path as a healer, intuitive, and explorer of this vast region, while also giving and receiving tangible help?

• Do health, healing, and wellness have to be a solitary journey?

Carol will answer all these as she discusses with you her stroke – from a Western and then from a seemingly opposite energy or shamanic viewpoint.  Which is correct?  Which, or how much of each, should we use?  How can we understand ad utilize science verses the utterly unscientific, yet true and valuable, energetic perspective?  Is Integrated Medicine as far as we’ll go?  What changes – physical, emotional, and spiritual – can you expect as you delve into the mysteries of this quest?  Above all, how will you use this wild and precious life when your wellbeing and your vehicle are changing?

Please join teacher and speaker Carol Dearborn as she discusses her own stoke and her journey into a deeper understanding of these and many other issues.  There will be ample time for questions and discussion of this vital topic.

This is a FREE event but please RSVP!

Carol Dearborn is an initiated shaman in the Peruvian Inca tradition, a visual artist, President Emeritus of the Sufficiency Foundation, and Reiki Master Teach.  She is also a member of the Executive Board of the Andean Research Institute and has more than 30 years’ experience teaching many forms of energetic healing.  Her mission is to help awaken modern cultures to our freedom and responsibility to create a sustainable presence on Earth through the evolution of human consciousness and particularly our connection to the sacred in all forms.  

www.essencehealing.net
results.name: Your Body, Your Well Being, Your Life a FREE talk with Carol Dearborn

results.description:
Hello and welcome to another edition of the Manga Club! I hope you are ready for another month of chaos and excitement and we discuss the wonder of Japanese Comic books!

This month, I decided to try to find something interesting, unique and creepy as all hell. A part of me was tempted to suggest a certain title that violates the laws of physics while killing zombies, but I decided that would be too easy. Besides, other than questioning what was in the local drinking water, I couldn’t think of too many discussion questions for that series. Therefore, I decided that it was time to break out something newer and more exciting! This time, I am talking about the Another Omnibus by Yukito Ayatsuji !

Another (Manga)
by Yukito Ayatsuji (Author), Hiro Kiyohara (Artist)

In the spring of 1998, Koichi Sakakibara transfers into Class 3-3 at Yomiyama North Middle School. But little does he know...his new class has a horrible secret. When he takes his seat in class for the first day of school, Koichi is unsettled by his fearful classmates. Despite this atmosphere and warnings from fellow students, Koichi is drawn to the beautiful, distant Mei Misaki, another classmate. But the closer he tries to get to her, the more mysterious she and their class become. And when a fellow student dies a disturbing death - the first of a long chain of deaths - Koichi seeks to learn the truth behind the curse of Class 3-3. But can he get answers before the curse kills him?

I have placed an order for some copies at the venue, and don’t forget our special deal! On the night of the Manga Club, all participants get ten percent off all graphic novels in the store, and twenty five percent off any future Manga Club title releases in stock! So if you come to the September Manga Club event, you can get the October or November titles for twenty five percent off as available!

BUT PLEASE REMEMBER, THIS DISCOUNT ONLY APPLIES TO VOLUMES IN THE STORE ON THE NIGHT OF A MANGA CLUB EVENT! THIS DISCOUNT DOES NOT APPLY AT ANY OTHER TIME OR TO A PREVIOUSLY RESERVED GRAPHIC NOVEL! THIS DEAL IS A GIFT NOT A PRIVILEGE SO PLEASE DO NOT ABUSE IT!

Thank you and I hope to see you there!

Alix Lavaud has been training Martial Arts for over 45 years and is a master of Modern Arnis, Pien San Wing Chun Kung Fu, and has extensive training in Small Circle Jujitsu.  He also humbly owns the rank of Lakan Apat (a 4th degree BLACKBELT ).


Lineage

Modern Arnis :  Remy Presas  -->  Alix Lavaud

Wing Chun:  Henry Mui  -->  Alix Lavaud

Small Circle Jujitsu:  Wally Jay -->  Alix Lavaud


Philosophy

 Go With The Flow ...

Some Quotes we Love

“If your mind is empty, it is ready for anything. In the beginner’s mind there are many possibilities, but in the expert’s there are few”
― Shunryu Suzuki


“Everything is perfect and there is always room for improvement.”

“We must exist right here and right now!”

Sign-up for the Webinar at: https://www.innerengineering.com/online/free-meditation-webinars-2?signinsrc=Meetup-NewEngland

***REGISTRATION closes 45 minutes prior to the webcast.***  Please make sure you sign-up on our website at least 45 mins prior to the webcast to receive your live log-in link via email. 

(Technical Support:[masked]) 


Isha Kriya Guided Meditation-

A lot of people find it really difficult to calm the mind and settle the body for meditation when they first try it. Too many people get frustrated and give up on meditation before they can experience its many benefits.

These 1-hour guided sessions offer a simple, but powerful kriya practice that aligns your mind, body, and inner-energies to easily and naturally become meditative. Once meditative, your experience of the life within you and the world around you becomes much deeper and richer. Daily activity becomes effortless and joyful. 

You can easily learn this 12-to-18 minute Isha Kriya process in one session and practice on your own, or return to class to ask questions and deepen the experience with the group. Benefits of regular practice include improving health, energy and vitality; enhancing mental focus, memory and clarity; reducing stress and establishing a deep sense of peace and inner balance.

Isha Kriya is a gentle, seated practice, which can be practiced in a chair. No previous meditation experience is necessary.

The Isha Kriya process was developed by realized yogi, Sadhguru Vasudev. Sadhguru is renowned for his powerful yoga and meditation programs, as well as thriving humanitarian initiatives. He has been hosted to speak and offer meditations at numerous global leadership forums, businesses and universities, including the United Nations, the World Economic Forum, the British House of Lords, TED, MIT, and the World Peace Congress.

This free session will be facilitated by a trained Isha Kriya instructor. Contact: [masked],[masked] for more information about Isha USA or this session.

For more on Sadhguru and Isha, visit IshaUSA.org/blog

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during nautical twilight.


The best time then is 5:30 to 6:30 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.

results.name: Challenge: Capture the Zodiacal Light

results.description:
A goal setting meeting in mid October begs the question: Isn't goal setting supposed to be done the last week in December?

The answer: not if you actually want to hit your 2016 goals

The reason: setting goals is not a 1 hour once a year task. In fact, if goal setting is done correctly, you won't just have a list of things that you want to achieve, but a sequential list of steps that need to be taken on a day to day basis in order to achieve your goals.

In this week's marketing meeting we will discussing:

1. Why setting goals is so important
2. The process necessary to create actionable goals
3. The amount of time that needs to be dedicated to planning your goals(and no it is definitely not 1 hour per year)
4. A review of my goals worksheets for the past few years
5. And much more.....

results.description:
Unfortunately, I'm suggesting that we stop and reconsider this initiative. 

I plead guilty to having jumped in partially because of my zeal to make us the first US city with a free, citywide IoT data network. I didn't do the spadework to get a steering committee in line to manage things, and now we aren't moving forward: no coherent strategy, no specific responsibilities.  I'm quite happy to step aside and let someone else take the lead. 

I do think, however, that we should understand the spirit -- if I understand it correctly -- of the Amsterdam project was to have a data network open to all, rather than a centrally-organized, corporate-dominated one, in order to foster an environment that will encourage startups and neighborhood-based IoT innovation.
results.name: Regretably, we still couldn't organize call. We need to rethink this initiative

results.description:
We are flattered and intrigued that Marianne Williamson, a four-time #1 New York Times bestselling author and one of the world's most influential speakers on the topic of spirituality, is making a point to visit the Humanist Hub during her brief upcoming visit to Harvard. Williamson is perhaps best known for the lines, "...Our deepest fear is not that we are inadequate. Our deepest fear is that we are powerful beyond measure.", in her 1992 book A Return to Love. She is not a humanist, and we can't and don't promise to agree with her on every topic discussed at this brown bag lunch session.

However, we are happy to draw our community's attention to Williamson's latest essay, "American Revolution 2.0," an entirely secular call to save American democracy before it is too late. This idea of a new American revolution will be the topic of our conversation: is it an idea around which spiritual and secular communities can unite? Join Greg Epstein and staff and leaders of the Humanist Community at Harvard and the Humanist Hub, to find out.
results.name: Brown Bag Lunch Dialogue: Marianne Williamson, "American Revolution 2.0"

group.name: The Humanist Hub in Harvard Square

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill 
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street 
Mission Hill, Roxbury 
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops) 
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer, 
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2). 

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).


We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm or so (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Use the T - #66 bus comes by - E-Line or Orange Line

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' 
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort.
TALK with us FIRST !!
Looking for Gifted Marketers to
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas

What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?

Portion Control

Bake...Don't Fry!

Roasted Veggie Stackers

No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream

Avocados!!!

Salad with Chipotle Hummus

Simple Cilantro Chutney

More $2 bags of Produce!

These sessions at Baby Pool/Charlestown Navy Yard will focus on a 6 week rotating schedule of classes designed to introduce the basics of Parkour in concentrate classes. The schedule will follow in order: 

• Safety, Landings and Balance

Class 1 will be focusing on how to land, move and stay safe practicing Parkour outdoor and in the real world. 

• Vaulting

Class 2 will focus on the foundation of Parkour - getting over low-level obstacles fast and efficiently through the use of vaulting.

• Precisions

Class 3 will focus on accuracy of jumping and foot/eye coordination honing basic standing and running jumps.

• Wall Techniques 

Class 4 will focus on conquering obstacles too large or tall to vault, in tandem with using walls as a means to keep a more efficient run.

• Tumbling/Acro

Class 5 focus is on tumbling and acrobatic skills, in pursuit of fully understanding movement in a 3D space and total proprioception.

• Flow + Speed

Class 6 links together all the previous lessons into one cohesive movement, and a timed obstacle course setting.

------

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 


This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/

results.description:
Class Distinctions
Dutch Painting in the Age of Rembrandt and Vermeer


From princes to regents to milkmaids, Dutch artists in the time of Rembrandt and Vermeer portrayed levels of society from highest to lowest in brilliant color and detail.

Organized by the MFA, this groundbreaking exhibition proposes a new approach to understanding 17th-century Dutch painting. Through 75 carefully selected, beautifully preserved portraits, genre scenes, landscapes and seascapes borrowed from European and American public and private collections—including masterpieces never before seen in the United States—the show reflects, for the first time, the ways in which paintings represent the various socioeconomic groups of the new Dutch Republic, from the Princes of Orange to the most indigent of citizens.

Pastoral to Pop
20th-Century Britain on Paper


Prints and drawings from a century of change by England’s great artists

This survey of more than 50 British prints and drawings from the 20th century features rarely seen works from the MFA’s collection as well as recent acquisitions and loans. Ranging from an 1890s drawing of Brittany by Post Impressionist Robert Bevan to a 1999 etching by Lucian Freud—perhaps the greatest figural artist of his generation—this selection presents a surprising mixture of subjects and styles. Highlights of the exhibition are streamlined color linocuts made by Grosvenor School artists Cyril Power, Sybil Andrews, and Lill Tschudi, while abstract works on view demonstrate the “Vorticist” style—a uniquely British variant of Futurism and Cubism. Other sections of the exhibition touch on landscape, architecture, and the music hall; differing depictions of the human figure (including works by Henry Moore and David Hockney); and the British Pop explosion of the 1960s
results.name: MFA free Wednesday Art of Europe 2

results.description:
• 6:00 - 6:30 PM - Networking 

• 6:30 - 8 PM - Introduction to Data Science


Prerequisite: a basic familiarity with R. Laptop users should have R installed

• Overview:

Understanding statistical methods is key in the process of making sound business decisions. Linear regression is the most widely-used method for the statistical analysis of non-experimental (observational) data. In this seminar you will learn how to analyze data using regression methods, interpret results, and use them for prediction and hypothesis testing. We will also practice running regressions in the open-source statistical software program, R.

• About Speaker

Victoria Liublinska received a PhD in Statistics from Harvard University. Her research was focused on developing methods for sensitivity analyses of conclusions obtained from studies with missing data. It resulted in several publications in leading peer-reviewed journals.

After finishing her degree, she stayed at Harvard and taught statistics for several years. This year she transitioned to a senior research position at Harvard University Institutional Research office.

Victoria has a plethora of consulting experience in many different fields, including business and marketing (interned at Google, worked with Concentric, Inc.), clinical (assisted on multiple studies at NYU School of Medicine), people analytics (worked with HR at Biogen, Inc.), biology (worked with researchers at the Arnold Arboretum), and litigation (provided expert opinion on multiple cases).

results.description:
$20 to attend. Please be on time and sign up only if you're positive you can be present.


In this workshop we'll read your work and give you constructive suggestions to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll help you make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!
results.name: Group Screenplay Workshop - $20

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...

Cost: Free! Abstract:
Continuous Integration Testing (CIT) is a part of modern software delivery but what is it? What are the different roles and their functions in an organization employing CIT? It can be a great boon to an organization and it can, if not thoroughly considered, actually lower product quality. Brian White from Checkpoint Technologies will help you and your organization make the most out of CIT while minimizing risk to your product delivery.

Speaker Bio: Brian White is a Senior Technical Consultant for Checkpoint Technologies. In his 18 years in quality assurance testing he has worked in fields from network security to robotics to health insurance and more. He works as a consulting engineer assisting Checkpoint's clients in making the most of their automated, performance and manual testing efforts. Brian has also presented at numerous conferences and webinars on a variety of topics focused on Quality Assurance and software testing.

results.description:
Boston Traders' Meetup

You are invited to attend the monthly Boston Traders' Meetup meetings.

The format for the monthly meetings is that each person will introduce her- or himself and state the market that he or she trades and perhaps a very brief description of the approach taken. For example, an introduction could be, "Hi, my name is Fred Hampton and I trade forex breakouts during the London session."

From there, the floor is open for people to discuss anything about trading. You may talk about something you learned recently about trading or about an obstacle that you are facing in trading or make a request for resources from other members.

Please print out and bring this BostonTradersMeetup sign so you can connect with the other members easily.
www.meetup.com/BostonTraders/files/

Part of the purpose of this group is for people to connect with other traders so it's encouraged for people to exchange contact info. For example, if you are an options trader and another options trader talks about a topic that interests you, then feel free to ask the person if she or he would like to exchange contact info.

--------------------

results.description:
Please join us for an evening with John Cullinane, a true pioneer in the software industry.

John Cullinane formed Cullinane Corporation, the first successful software products company in the computer industry, the first to have an IPO, the first listed on the NY Stock Exchange and the first to reach a billion dollars in valuation. 

However, in reality what he did was be the first to figure out how to sell enough software as a product to make a profitable company out it. No one had done it previously, and very few have done it since. This is the same problem facing every software company today. Nothing has changed in the industry. All software companies would like to know how to sell their products more effectively. This is what he will focus on in his talk with particular emphasis on product messaging with the unique process he has for creating  sales messages that work. 

He will also discuss a point in his company's history when he only had $500 left in the bank and a payroll due that day of $8,500 and what he did to survive. Thus, this talk is geared to all software entrepreneurs regardless of what companies they work for.

Learn more about John Cullinane.


Introductory Speaker


As a special bonus we are offering an introductory presentation prior to John Cullinane's main presentation.  Join us at 6:30 for Brief Intro to GitHub presented by Boston PHP member, Rick Umali.


Topics to be covered include the following:

~ GitHub is not Git
~ Interacting with GitHub for the first time
~ Manipulating GitHub repositories with standard Git commands.
~ Alternatives to GitHub


Rick's new book, Learn Git in a Month of Lunches , will be featured in a new virtual self-study group called Git Lunch, Season 1.  Join us to learn more.


Agenda:

6:00 PM - 6:30 PM -- Free pizza

6:30 PM - 7:00 PM -- Brief Intro to GitHub with Rick Umali


7:00 PM - 7:15 PM -- Announcements

7:15 PM - 8:15 PM -- Software Entrepreneurship with John Cullinane


8:15 PM - 8:30 PM -- Q&A

9:00 PM -- Beers at Champions Bar in Kendall Square
results.name: How I started the first billion dollar software company.

results.description:
6:00 PM - Networking


6:30 PM - 8PM - Introduction to Data Science


• Prerequisite: A basic familiarity with R. Laptop users should have R installed

• Overview:

Understanding statistical methods is key in the process of making sound business decisions. Linear regression is the most widely-used method for the statistical analysis of non-experimental (observational) data. In this seminar you will learn how to analyze data using regression methods, interpret results, and use them for prediction and hypothesis testing. We will also practice running regressions in the open-source statistical software program, R.

• About Speaker


Victoria Liublinska received a PhD in Statistics from Harvard University. Her research was focused on developing methods for sensitivity analyses of conclusions obtained from studies with missing data. It resulted in several publications in leading peer-reviewed journals.

After finishing her degree, she stayed at Harvard and taught statistics for several years. This year she transitioned to a senior research position at Harvard University Institutional Research office.

Victoria has a plethora of consulting experience in many different fields, including business and marketing (interned at Google, worked with Concentric, Inc.), clinical (assisted on multiple studies at NYU School of Medicine), people analytics (worked with HR at Biogen, Inc.), biology (worked with researchers at the Arnold Arboretum), and litigation (provided expert opinion on multiple cases).
results.name: Introduction to Data Science

results.description:
Virtualizing your top-tier production SQL Servers is not as easy as P2V'ing it. Sometimes allocating more resources to the VM is the wrong approach, and getting it wrong will silently hurt performance. What is the most effective method for determining the 'right' amount of resources to allocate? What happens if the workload changes a month from now?

The methods for understanding the performance of your mission-critical SQL Servers gathered over the past ten years of SQL Server virtualization will be addressed, and valuable processes for performance statistic collection and analysis will be displayed. Come learn how to properly 'right-size' the resources allocated to a VM, improve the performance of your SQL Servers, and keep it maximized well into the future.

David Klee is a Microsoft MVP and VMware vExpert with over seventeen years of IT experience. David spends his days handling performance and HA/DR architecture of mission-critical SQL Servers as the Founder of Heraflux Technologies. His areas of expertise are virtualization and performance, datacenter architecture, and risk mitigation through high availability and disaster recovery. You can read his blog at davidklee.net, and reach him on Twitter at @kleegeek.

Our opening lightning talk on "Manging SQL Agent Job History" by Taiob Ali (@SqlWorldWide)
results.name: Right sizing your virtual SQL Server - David Klee

results.description:
Please join Code for Boston and Microsoft for a special evening of discussion as we recap the 2015 annual Code for America Summit.


In case you missed it, Code for America’s Annual Summit was held in Oakland, CA on Sept 29 - Oct 2, and - as you might imagine - the Boston area was well-represented by a number of local civic technologists, including representatives from the cities of Boston, Cambridge, Somerville, MassIT, and more.


In order to share what we all learned at Summit with the larger community and to build on the great momentum from that event, we invite you to join us for an informal evening at NERD featuring a “flash panel” and Q&A with Summit attendees, breakout sessions with members of the Boston civic technology community including representatives from the City of Boston DoIT, 2015 Code for America Fellowship City Somerville, MassIT, Microsoft New England, the Metropolitan Area Planning Council, and of course, your Code for Boston core team.
  Special thanks to Microsoft for providing the refreshments and hosting this exciting event.
  Looking forward to seeing you at our Code for America Summit Recap + Mixer!

results.description:
On Wednesday, October 14th starting at 6:30 pm at the Boston Button Factory (close to South Station), Boston Security Meetup and MobileTea present the 7th edition of MobileTea. This evening event consists of knowledge and networking for anyone interested in security and mobile development. Participation is “free as in beer” and consists of 4 keynote speakers interspersed with 4 networking sessions that include live DJ’d music and hors d'oeuvres.  


Presentations will vary from 20 to 30 minutes and are followed by 15 minutes of networking.  Be prepared for an informal atmosphere, great food and drink.  Bring your passion for all things development, we look forward to meeting you!

Performing live: DJ Valerio Galli (Rome - Italy).

Mixologist: Chris Allen (Red5 - Pro)

Event Program:

6:30 - 6:45 Networking & Music

6:45 - 6:50 Welcome & Intro [Giorgio & Dawn & team]

6:50 - 6:55 Lulzy News [Cindy]

7:00 - 7:30 OAuth – What is it? [Scott Matsumoto] (25 mins present / 5 mins question)

7:30 - 7:45 Networking & Music

7:45 - 7:50 Tool of the Month [Will]

7:50 – 8:15 Who owns software security? [Tim Buntel & Paul Boss] [Susan Remondi] (20 mins present / 5 mins question)

8:15 - 8:30 Networking & Music

8:30 - 8:55 Mobile First AppSec [Susan Remondi] (20 mins present / 5 mins question)

8:55 - 9:20 Mobile Security in Live Video Streaming [Chris Allen] (20 mins present / 5 mins question)

9:20 - 9:30 Raffle, Wrap Up & Thank You

9:30 - 11:00 Networking & Music @ the venue

Networking Session 1 - DJ Mix 1 - Food & Drink 

OAuth: an open authorization standard. Ok - but what is it? [Susan Redmondi]
OAuth is pretty ubiquitous in security. It's dual purpose: Out in the digital world, there are a lot of resources that we might want to share access to where an all-access pass just won't cut it (think: all those permissions Facebook games ask for), and, more generally, it protects REST APIs. We'll start with an introduction to OAuth (assuming zero knowledge), talk about some use cases, and look at some code a developer would need to put together to talk to companies like PayPal, Facebook, or Google.  


(speech level: intermediate; duration: 25 minutes)  

Networking Session 2 - DJ Mix 2 - Food & Drink 

Who owns software security? You do! [Tim Buntel @tbuntel & Paul Boss]
Just about every week it seems like another organization is hit by a high-profile security breach - even though most of the vulnerabilities exploited in both web and mobile apps are easy to fix when they’re found early. So why do we continue to see the same software security mistakes made again and again? We have the answers! And this talk will show how you, the developer, are the solution. We’ll include a demo of a new developer tool that can you build more secure apps, APIs, and services, too.  


(speech level: intermediate; duration: 25 minutes)  

Networking Session 3 - DJ Mix 3 - Food & Drink 

Mobile First AppSec [Scott Matsumoto]
Mobile First Design is disrupting AppSec as much as it’s disrupting application design.  Mobile First Design affects applications well beyond the layout issues for the supported devices.  The architectural differences between Mobile First and web-based applications means that the halcyon days of AppSec security are over.  The top vulnerabilities are different for Mobile applications.  The differences start with application architecture and the classes of vulnerabilities. We'll also touch on the design of the security control and use of tools like Burp.  We’ll can’t cover all of them but we cover as many of the differences as we can cover in 20 minutes.


(speech level: intermediate; duration: 20 minutes)


Networking Session 4 - DJ Mix 4 - Food & Drink 


Mobile Security in Live Video Streaming [Chris Allen @mrchrisallen]Chris Allen, co-founder of Infrared5 will talk about his team’s experience building out live streaming solutions for their customers. He will delve into what’s needed to properly secure live streams and how to build experiences like this for mobile. Chris will also discuss their product Red5 Pro (http://red5pro.com) and how it is addressing security in this space.


(speech level: intermediate; duration: 20 minutes)


Networking Session 5 - DJ Mix 5 - Food & Drink 

Not receiving emails?

Some members have said they're not receiving our emails. You might have unsubscribed to our special announcements. To fix it: Click Settings > Email Updates > Choose Boston Security Meetup under "Updates about your groups" and check off "Announcement about a specific Meetup" and "Announcement to members about the group".

Sales and Recruiters

We appreciate your interest in our events; however, in order to keep the focus on learning and having fun in a casual environment, we request that you not engage in marketing, sales, or recruitment business at our meetups. If you would like to mingle with our members in a professional capacity to promote a product or recruit, please contact us through the Meetup Messenger about sponsorship opportunities.

Looking for speakers! 
If you sent us an abstract of your talk and haven't received a response yet, please send it again. Your message may have been buried in layers of emails. Reminders are helpful!

Do you have a family member or friend who wants to get in shape but doesn't know how to start? Help get them walking or jogging.

We have 2 groups:

Our Walking Group will exercise and encourage one another towards walking a 5K. 

Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.

Using CoolRunning.com’s Couch To 5K program we introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 8-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles).

•  Anyone from the community can participate. 


• Led by experienced runners. 


• Mondays through Thursdays 6:30pm-7:15pm; Saturdays 10 am-10:45 am 


• 45 minute time commitment (3 days a week) 


• Goal of jogging and finishing a 5K

• Our Fall session will begin on Monday, September 28.

(Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.)

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group at the Dedham High School Track.

Our Couch to 5K will end with the "Dedham Turkey Trot" on Thanksgiving morning.
results.name: Fall Couch to 5K

results.description:
Last month we discussed how accessibility affects users with disabilities and this month we'll learn how to fix many of those issues with our HTML and CSS so that we can build more accessible websites. Doors open at 6:30pm for food and drinks, which will be provided by Vermonster. The talk will start at 7pm. 

A practical introduction to accessibility standards, resources, and the importance of prioritizing semantic development. This meetup will cover best practices, common mistakes, and explain why well-designed sites and software are also accessible ones. Hopefully, this will provide encouragement for developers to realize that accessibility is not an insurmountable hurdle, but an essential puzzle piece for writing elegant code.

A bit about our presenter: 

Ali Areskog is a HTML/CSS Engineer at NGP VAN. Previously, she worked at Abt Associates as a Programmer Analyst building out the front-end of various websites for the federal government. For government work learning about accessibility is mandatory, and unfortunately helped shed a light on the huge gap in education developers receive. When Ali is not coding or worrying about accessibility she is usually outdoors, enjoying life away from the screen glow.
results.name: Accessibility & Semantic Development: Intro to Building Accessible Websites

results.description:
Come join us for a midweek climb!


All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~
results.how_to_find_us: Will meet at 6:30 PM at the cubbies by the stairs

Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
