Get in shape before the season!! The leader (Bob Barnes) of the Wedeln Ski and Snowboard Race Team will hold dryland training every Wednesday night this Fall. The workout is great for anyone who wants to get in shape, you do not have to be a skier or racer. Bob's enthusiasm for skiing and training is contagious, he will get you working hard and getting results. All fitness levels are welcome but come ready to sweat. Bob will lead the group in Plyometric based training methods designed to get the leg muscles ready for the season. This is the same workout that he has used for many years to prepare for the ski season.

There is no charge - we are just a bunch of skiers and riders trying to help each other get in shape. Darlene Stokes and Tom Lane will also lead the group in additional exercises designed to increase flexibility and build a strong core. Last year we had many people from Meetup join us for these workouts. Some even became regular guests up at our ski house in NH. Ski Fitness Training is a great way to get ready for the season and make some friends you can join on the slopes when the weather gets colder. The workouts last 1.5 hours and are always immediately followed by a few drinks and sometimes some food at a variety of Waltham Center Bars/Restaurants. Please wear work-out clothes and athletic shoes with some ankle support.

OAuth is pretty ubiquitous in security. It's dual purpose: Out in the digital world, there are a lot of resources that we might want to share access to where an all-access pass just won't cut it (think: all those permissions Facebook games ask for), and, more generally, it protects REST APIs. We'll start with an introduction to OAuth (assuming zero knowledge), talk about some use cases, and look at some code a developer would need to put together to talk to companies like PayPal, Facebook, or Google.  
(speech level: intermediate; duration: 25 minutes)  

Networking Session 2 - DJ Mix 2 - Food & Drink 

Who owns software security? You do! [Tim Buntel @tbuntel & Paul Boss]
Just about every week it seems like another organization is hit by a high-profile security breach - even though most of the vulnerabilities exploited in both web and mobile apps are easy to fix when they’re found early. So why do we continue to see the same software security mistakes made again and again? We have the answers! And this talk will show how you, the developer, are the solution. We’ll include a demo of a new developer tool that can you build more secure apps, APIs, and services, too.   
(speech level: intermediate; duration: 25 minutes)  

Networking Session 3 - DJ Mix 3 - Food & Drink 

Mobile First AppSec [Scott Matsumoto] 
Mobile First Design is disrupting AppSec as much as it’s disrupting application design.  Mobile First Design affects applications well beyond the layout issues for the supported devices.  The architectural differences between Mobile First and web-based applications means that the halcyon days of AppSec security are over.  The top vulnerabilities are different for Mobile applications.  The differences start with application architecture and the classes of vulnerabilities. We'll also touch on the design of the security control and use of tools like Burp.  We’ll can’t cover all of them but we cover as many of the differences as we can cover in 20 minutes. 
(speech level: intermediate; duration: 20 minutes) 

Networking Session 4 - DJ Mix 4 - Food & Drink 

Mobile Security in Live Video Streaming [Chris Allen @mrchrisallen]
Chris Allen, co-founder of Infrared5 will talk about his team’s experience building out live streaming solutions for their customers. He will delve into what’s needed to properly secure live streams and how to build experiences like this for mobile. Chris will also discuss their product Red5 Pro (http://red5pro.com) and how it is addressing security in this space. 
(speech level: intermediate; duration: 20 minutes) 

Networking Session 5 - DJ Mix 5 - Food & Drink
results.name: Mobile Tea #7 The security chapter

results.description:
Julie Fraser will be leading this LovingKindness meditation.

In partnership with the Cambridge Ten Thousand Villages store, MindfulBoston teachers will be leading a series of Compassion Meditation events as a service to our community.
Place:
The Cambridge Ten Thousand Villages is located at
694 Massachusetts Avenue
Central Square, Cambridge 02139
Time:
6:45pm to 8pm

Description:
Meditating on kindness, compassion and human connection is one of the traditional ways to build resiliency during times of stress.

Schedule:
There will be an informal schedule.
At about 6:45pm we'll set up some seats and have a chat about what meditation is about. This is the official start time for our event.

The front door will be locked by 7:01. Make sure to arrive either on-time or early!
The store's registers will be closed by 7:05 so that employees can join us in meditation.

How to reserve your space:

Please rsvp here or call the store to rsvp. There are no "tickets" but we would like a head count in order to prepare a big enough space for sitting together.

Note: we typically have up to 30 people attend these events. RSVPing is pretty important because we need to move bookcases around to fit everybody in the space. Thanks! Seating:
If you have hip/knee or other reasons to need a chair, make sure to rsvp here and say 'reserve a chair' in your comments.
There are seven folding chairs and a few low stools. Zafu style cushions are sometimes available if the store has some in stock. But there are no guarantees. Most of us will be sitting on the floor. Feel free to bring your own pillow with you. What is planned:
The hour (or so) that we spend together will include: discussion about compassionate healing for ourselves and each other, and an experience of lovingkindness meditation. The length of the meditation itself will probably be about 15 to 20 minutes long. No previous experience is required, the meditation will be easy for beginners to understand.

results.description:
TAMBAKOS FILM SERIES: October 14

"THE LODGER" /Silent

COST: Free

TIME: The Silent Film starts @ 7:00 pm ( running time: 68 min)

*LIVE MUSIC by Jeff Rapsis

ABOUT THE FILM: 1927- Directed by ( very young Alfred Hitchcock) Starring: Marie Ault, Arthur Chesney, June, Malcolm Keen, Ivor Novello. The search is on for the man responsible for a series of murders in fog shrouded London. Legendary filmmaker Alfred Hitchcock's career began in the silent era, when the young director first produced his brand of darkly suspenseful thrillers,

FILM 7:00 p.m. Screening with LIVE accompaniment by Jeff Rapsis
Jeff Rapsis lives in Bedford, New Hampshire, and accompanies silent film programs in venues throughout New England. A lifelong silent film fan, he began creating original musical scores and staging silent film programs in 2007 as a way to keep the form before the public. His technique is to create a set of original music in advance for each film, and then improvise a score based on this material as the screening takes place. Outside New England, he has accompanied films at the New York Public Library’s “Meet the Musicmakers” series and the Kansas Silent Film Festival. Rapsis has also provided original music for several silent film DVD releases by Looser Than Loose Vintage Entertainment of Manchester, N.H., and scored the independent feature film Dangerous Crosswinds (2005).
FREE EVENT

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11

results.description:
Most Wednesdays we gather for an open gaming night at the Panera in Porter Square. This event is open to anyone, and usually doesn't have any sort of pre-arranged agenda -- anything you can bring is fair game, provided you can get it done in three hours!

* Your gallant host almost always brings something to play, and takes requests if you get said request to him by Tuesday night at the latest. Behold the collection: http://www.bgg.cc/collection/user/CmdrOverbite?gallery=large&rankobjecttype=subtype&rankobjectid=1&columns=title%7Cstatus%7Cversion%7Crating%7Cbggrating%7Cplays%7Ccomment%7Ccommands&geekranks=%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09Board+Game+Rank%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09&own=1&objecttype=thing&ff=1&subtype=boardgame

* Due to logistical concerns and a desire to keep peace with the management (who have been notably chill thus far about a bunch of freeloading nerds taking up their table space), I have set a limit of twelve attendees on these events going forward. I doubt this will be much of an issue, given our typical attendance numbers.

* Because our events tend to be small, and the games we typically play tend to be long, if at all possible, please let us know if you plan to be more than a couple of minutes late so that we don't launch into something without you. Likewise, if you're planning on arriving more than a half-hour late, you should be aware that it may not be possible to include you in a game. You're welcome to come by and hang out but the chances are better than even that we'll be hip-deep in gaming goodness by the time you arrive.

* Please be respectful of our hosts; stay mindful of closing time and throw 'em some business if you're hungry.

* Have fun and roll high!

Welcome to the first meetup posted to this group!!

Doors open at 7 - Event begins at 7:30, and goes until 9

Wine and cheese reception following the event

Fee: $25 per person (or bring a friend and you both pay $20)

How many times have you heard someone complain that whoever they meet online is not a good fit.  Or that they’re not meeting anybody?  Have you complained about online dating? 

You're not alone. There are a lot of men and women who are suffering – needlessly - because of HOW they’re going about the whole online dating thing (and they don't realize that this experience that they are having is f-i-x-a-b-l-e). 

BUT…you also hear about all these people who are connecting with great people online, right? Lots of dates. And the dates are awesome. They're having a great time. Both scenarios are happening… ALL. THE. TIME. 

So maybe you’ve been on the “This ain’t workin’!” side of the equation, and you want to join the “Wow, this is rockin’!” gang… If so, you’ll want to be there for a very informative evening where you’ll learn what those people are doing who are having fun, meeting great men and women, and all as a result of online dating. Come…join us! Learn how you can ROCK your online dating adventure!

Presenter: Karen Jones, founder of The Heart Matters, has been a relationship coach since 1997, and has helped countless women end up in scrumptious relationships.  She is a very big fan of online dating…if it’s done right (and she loves to help women get it right!).   To learn more about Karen, please visit her website: www.TheHeartMatters.com
results.name: How to ROCK Your Online Dating Adventure!

results.description:
Herbal medicine is the people’s medicine, so its practitioners must serve the people. Herbalism is medicine from the edge, so herbalists must build community with those who are marginalized. Herbalism is “alternative” medicine in our society today, so its practitioners must advocate for the underrepresented.

To do this, we need to acknowledge the presence of colonialism, racism, classism, patriarchy, and other forms of oppression within the realm of herbal medicine. We need to talk about privilege and power. As herbalists, we must find ways to honor traditional knowledge without engaging in the appropriation of native cultures, and work to preserve ancestral herbal wisdom without exploiting environments, plants, or people.

None of this is easy or simple, but it is necessary. We invite you to join us for a spiraling discussion of these issues, oriented towards finding ways we can all help each other develop respectful relationships between people, peoples, plants, and places.

Wednesday, October 14th, 2015
7:00pm – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

This is a free event, and we invite all interested parties to participate!

RSVP by emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.
results.name: Decolonizing Herbalism: A Community Discussion

results.description:
Herbal medicine is the people’s medicine, so its practitioners must serve the people. Herbalism is medicine from the edge, so herbalists must build community with those who are marginalized. Herbalism is “alternative” medicine in our society today, so its practitioners must advocate for the underrepresented.

To do this, we need to acknowledge the presence of colonialism, racism, classism, patriarchy, and other forms of oppression within the realm of herbal medicine. We need to talk about privilege and power. As herbalists, we must find ways to honor traditional knowledge without engaging in the appropriation of native cultures, and work to preserve ancestral herbal wisdom without exploiting environments, plants, or people.

None of this is easy or simple, but it is necessary. We invite you to join us for a spiraling discussion of these issues, oriented towards finding ways we can all help each other develop respectful relationships between people, peoples, plants, and places.

results.description:
Doors open at 7 - Event begins at 7:30, and goes until 9


Wine and cheese reception following the event

Fee: $25 per person (or bring a friend and you both pay $20)

How many times have you heard someone complain that whoever they meet online is not a good fit. Or that they’re not meeting anybody? Have you complained about online dating? 

You're not alone. There are a lot of men and women who are suffering – needlessly - because of HOW they’re going about the whole online dating thing (and they don't realize that this experience that they are having is f-i-x-a-b-l-e)

BUT…you also hear about all these people who are connecting with great people online, right? Lots of dates. And the dates are awesome. They're having a great time. Both scenarios are happening… ALL. THE. TIME. 

So maybe you’ve been on the “This ain’t workin’!” side of the equation, and you want to join the “Wow, this is rockin’!” gang… If so, you’ll want to be there for a very informative evening where you’ll learn what those people are doing who are having fun, meeting great men and women, and all as a result of online dating. 

Come…join us! Learn how you can ROCK your online dating adventure!

Presenter: Karen Jones, founder of The Heart Matters, has been a relationship coach since 1997, and has helped countless women end up in scrumptious relationships. She is a very big fan of online dating…if it’s done right (and she loves to help women get it right!). To learn more about Karen, please visit her website: www.TheHeartMatters.com

Announcing a new meetup group!

Boston Online Dating Success. http://www.meetup.com/Successful-Online-Dating-in-Boston/

With all kinds of help from experts in the field to make your online dating experience as fun and successful as possible.  

<a href="http://www.TheHeartMatters.com"></a>
results.name: How to ROCK your Online Dating Adventure!

results.description:
One of the big topics in the presidential debates is how to reform our prisons. The incarceration numbers in America are literally off the charts (see the chart in the Atlantic article below). Much has been written on how this affects communities and families. Is this a major problem? What factors have brought this about? What should be done about it? 

A million articles on this lately, but here are a couple:

The Atlantic, "The Leader of the Unfree World" (Matt Ford)

The New York Times, "The Prison Problem" (David Brooks)

results.description:
The Public Open Night at the Observatory is a chance for people to come observe the night sky through telescopes and binoculars and see things they otherwise might not get to see, and learn some astronomy as well. The Open Nights are held most Wednesday evenings throughout the year, weather permitting.

It is open to everyone. Starting times are 7:30pm during the fall and winter, and 8:30pm during the spring and summer. The program lasts about an hour.

Weather

The weather is always a factor when observing. Unfortunately we can’t control the weather and we can’t observe when there are clouds, haze, or rain; so when the weather is bad, the Open Night will be canceled. Predicting the weather in New England isn’t easy, so we won’t know if the Open Night will be held or not until the day of the program. To find out if the Open Night will be held, call our information number at[masked], no earlier than two hours before the scheduled starting time. This lets us make the decision as late as possible while still giving those who live farther away time to get here.

Remember, it gets very cold in Boston in the winter and the telescopes are outside, so dress warmly.

>>> Tickets <<<

Public Open Nights are open to everyone, however space is limited. To reserve a ticket for admission click this link which will take you to our Eventbrite page.  [see website]

Location

The Public Open Night is held at the Coit Observatory at Boston University. We are located at 725 Commonwealth Ave. in Boston, right above the Astronomy Department. The stairwell to the Observatory is on the fifth floor right next to room 520.

Unfortunately, there is no disabled access to the Observatory.
Information

For information, please call[masked]-2630.

The Public Open Night at the Observatory is held clear Wednesday nights from 8:30 – 9:30pm. Call[masked] for the status.

Source: http://www.bu.edu/astronomy/events/public-open-night-at-the-observatory/
results.name: Public Open Night - Coit Observatory at Boston University

results.description:
Dance Freedom   11 Garden St. Cambridge MA 7:30-10:30 October 14th
Warmup & 1st Set:Chad , 2ndSet: Robin,   Host Jessica

Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing


Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a dark or white "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.   

Buy The Books

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during nautical twilight.


The best time then is 5:30 to 6:30 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.

results.name: Challenge: Capture the Zodiacal Light

Building World Class Data Organizations and Teams with Pragmatic Works

Please register with this link:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/building-world-class-data-organizations-and-teams-with-pragmatic-works-tickets-18823966992

Many data organizations today are struggling to define and attain maturity. The diversity in data platforms, BI tools, user needs and vendor stories is dizzying. The teams themselves are struggling to keep up and their knowledge gaps weaken confidence and that keeps them from focusing on innovation for the organization. Successful data strategy and teams are world class. They are the crossroad between technology and the business' insight and ability to innovate. We will teach you how to identify the blind spots in your strategy, educate and empower your team, and start producing for your business faster than even before. Together, we will design your world class data organization and team including:
• Setting organizational and team values
• Defining your scope of practice and capabilities
• Planning for a strong relationship between company strategy and your team
• Creating world class processes
• Building your world class execution plan
• Systems for turning data technologists into organizational leaders

Management and technologists will enjoy this session together. Management will get the tools and confidence pulled straight from our global experience. Technologists will love seeing how they can quickly take the hard work they are doing and focus it in ways that will drive big results and confidence from their business. Every business wants to move faster, make better decisions and be more connected. The only way to do that is when your data strategy is world class. Let's build it together!

Speakers
Adam Jorgensen - President Pragmatic Works
Jason Strate - Principal, Pragmatic Works
Steve Hughes - Principal, Pragmatic Works
Anthony Martin - Principal, Pragmatic Works

On this webinar, we will teach non-technical founders how to start growing their basic technical skills, and outline several technologies, methods, and tools that you can use to start building a basic product on your own. In addition, we will discuss what you should and should not build on your own, and outline strategies for how to find developers and a technical co-founder. 

This webinar will feature two successful serial entrepreneurs: Weiting Liu (Founder and CEO of Codementor), and Adeo Ressi (Founder and CEO of the Founder Institute, 9X entrepreneur, and Managing Director of Expansive Ventures). 

You’ll learn:
-Pros and cons of the basic technologies being used today

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Thursday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Jamaica Plain
Do NOT sign up UNLESS you are willing to work hard for about 2 hours.
Others can attend each week and carry home a $2 bag of vegetables and fruits.


Alternate Thursdays from 3:00 -- 4:00 PM  
[Volunteers arrive 30 minutes earlier and stay up to 30 minutes after close.]
[Those getting bags of produce can expect to retrieve them from 3-4 pm.]
From May 28 onward

Amory Street Building
125 Amory Street
(22 Bus toward Ruggles)
Jamaica Plain
Boston, MA 02130
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Amory Street Building at 125 Amory Street in Jamaica Plain,
Boston, MA 02130

Between Jackson Square and Stony Brook MBTA Orange Line stops.
Near Dimock and Atherton Streets.

The Amory PACE Center is a comprehensive service center and residential apartment complex for frail elders and persons with disabilities.

Boston Housing Authority (BHA) recently completed a $4 million renovation at 125A Amory Street, a formerly dilapidated structure behind the Amory Street Elderly/Disabled public housing development. 

The community is now supported by a full-service center for elderly and disabled residents over the age of 55. The Center is operated by the Upham’s Corner Health Center through its Elder Service Plan-PACE (Program of All-inclusive Care for Elders). PACE is a community-based, comprehensive initiative providing medical, adult day health and supportive care for frail elders that allows them to remain living independently in the community rather than in a nursing home. 

• http://jamaicaplaingazette.com/2013/06/07/new-senior-health-center-serves-125-amory-housing/


• https://www.bostonhousing.org/en/Departments/Planning-and-Real-Estate-Development/Amory-PACE-Center.aspx


In Massachusetts, PACE programs operate under the Executive Office of Elder Affairs. This is the first PACE site in the Amory neighborhood, with two other sites in Boston.

This six-story, elevator-equipped building has approximately 181 units in studio, one-bedroom or two-bedroom.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEER for biweekly Thursday afternoon $2/bag of produce in Jamaica Plain, held on ALTERNATE WEEKS

When you volunteer, YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Jamaica Plain neighbors so they can eat the way I do - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up portable banquet tables, set up the food in order of density (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

We arrive around 2:30 pm (maybe as late as 2:45 pm) and work until 4:30 pm (can leave as early as 4:15 pm if we've finished all our work).

In the FRONT of the Amory Street Building at 125 Amory Street in Jamaica Plain.

Wear comfortable clothing.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Alternate Thursdays, from 3:00 - 4:00 pm
Reserve FIRST before just showing up.
[Volunteers arrive 30 minutes earlier and stay up to 30 minutes after close]
From May 28 onward
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends! Forward the invitation to others!
Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' buttons 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Want to volunteer at a DIFFERENT location OR just stop by and get bread and produce?

Then check out this website and find a site that is more convenient to your location and schedule:

http://www.fairfoods.org/dollarbag.html

Volunteers MUST register in advance with phone and e-mail AND commit to work the full 2 hours (2:30-4:30 pm), but it probably won't be that long.
results.name: $2/bag - VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Jamaica Plain: Amory Street Bldg

</a>The Members of the Open Innovation Club cordially invite you to an Innovation Meetup and Cocktail Reception for the official launch of the OIC Boston Chapter

PERSONALIZED HEALTH

Advanced analytics, digital devices and overspecialization services

Personalized health aims at providing the right treatment, to the right patient, with the right dose, at the right time. With lower cost of sequencing, we can now customize a therapy with a patient’s genetic profile. But the concept of personalized health is also transforming the entire medical process, allowing additional stakeholders to be involved. This innovation meetup will provide insights on the impacts of data analytics, connected devices and personalization services in the healthcare sector and beyond.

results.description:
We’re honored to announce that we’ll be hosting Chris Edwards at our new Boston headquarters, as part of our Digital Rendezvous Speaker Series. Chris left his post as EVP, Group Creative Director at Arnold to write his memoir, Balls, which details how he handled his very public gender transition inside and outside the agency. His story is heartwarming, inspiring and truly remarkable. He's a sought after speaker and is well respected in both the advertising and creative communities. We’re excited to have Chris join us for this inspiring talk and Q&A!

What: Digital Rendezvous with guest speaker Chris Edwards

Where: Aquent/Vitamin T’s new headquarters

 501 Boylston Street, 3rd Floor

When: Thursday, October 15th at 5:30 p.m. There will be an hour of networking before Chris begins his talk promptly at 6:30 p.m. Food and beverages will be served.

•Important: You must RSVP via Eventbrite in order to attend this event. Please include your full name to register so you’ll be able to enter the building with security. You must show a photo ID upon entering the building.

RSVP: http://www.eventbrite.com/e/digital-rendezvous-with-chris-edwards-tickets-18448424735

About Chris:

Chris grew up in the Boston suburbs and graduated from Colgate University with degrees in psychology and sociology. In 1993 he took a job as a junior copywriter at Arnold, a high-profile Boston ad agency owned and run by his father, Ed Eskandarian, a prominent figure in the advertising world. There Chris used the principles of branding and marketing along with his ever-present sense of humor to rebrand himself and orchestrate what was quite possibly the most widely accepted and embraced gender transition of its kind – at a time when the word transgender didn’t exist. All while building an award-winning advertising career spanning nearly twenty years. His best-known creative projects include the infamous McDonald’s singing fish (“Gimme back that Filet-O-Fish, gimme that fish”) and the YouTube McNuggets rapper guys (“I’m into Nuggets y’all”), both of which went viral and infiltrated pop culture. He was also part of the creative team on Truth, the long-running campaign targeting Big Tobacco, which was recently ranked one of the top 15 ad campaigns of the 21st century. 

For more on Chris’ book project and a link to his full creative portfolio, check out

http://www.chrisedwardsballs.com
results.name: Digital Rendezvous with Chris Edwards

results.description:
The Year We Thought About Love
Dir Ellen Brodsky (2015) USA 68 min

The Cambridge GLBT Commission, the City of Somerville's LGBTQ Community Liaison, and the Cambridge Public Library present a free screening of the new documentaryThe Year We Thought About Love.

What happens when LGBTQ youth of color band together and dare to be “out” on stage about their lives and their loves?

True Colors is a Boston-based theater troupe that raises LGBTQ awareness by performing to middle and high school students, social workers, friends and family. For this season, they have decided to explore the topic of “queer love” in all of its manifestations.

Director Ellen Brodsky introduces us to an incredibly inspiring group of young people who use the power of dramatic expression to cope with their own conflicts. Alyssa has been kicked out of the house for coming out as trans. Chi is struggling with acceptance from his conservative Baptist church. Giftson is a Haitian-American who’s already endured tragic violence in his personal life.

Watch the trailer at http://www.TheYearWeThoughtAboutLove.com/ .

Join the Facebook Event at http://on.fb.me/1Nabzh3 .

  The Year We Thought About Love brings us inside the
  collaborative creative process in which these young
  personalities grow into sharp, empowered performers.
  After the Boston Marathon bombs explode yards from
  their rehearsal space, the troupe becomes even more
  determined to share their stories of love to help their
  city heal. — Jimmy Radosta

Doors open at 6pm with information tables & socializing; the program is set to begin at 6:30pm.

The screening will be followed by a Q&A with members of the cast and director Ellen Brodsky.
results.name: Free Screening of "The Year We Thought About Love"

Our HR solution includes services such as payroll processing, human capital consulting, employment law compliance and employee benefits, including health insurance, retirement plans and workers compensation insurance. results.description:
6:00-7:00 Networking, Introductions, Pizza

7:00-7:45 Cloudian & MonadCloud

Scale-Out Storage: Why "cheap & deep" is not enough!


•  Electronic data storage is nearly 60 years old. It is the bedrock of computing. The emergence of the public Internet and the World Wide Web in the early 1990s quickly accelerated the need for more storage. Increasing volumes of Web content, e-commerce, e-mail, social media and all manner of human and machine generated “unstructured” data has overwhelmed the capacity and scalability of legacy file and block storage technologies. Object-based storage (OBS) has emerged over the past decade as a way to scale storage to meet the rising torrent of data being generated. The presenters from MonadCloud and Cloudian will provide a short history of data storage and focus on what object storage is, why it is important today, and what Cloudian is delivering to its customers through its partners.

•  Cloudian has developed a 100% AWS S3 API-compatible object-based storage software that can be installed on clusters of industry standard x86 storage servers. The presenters will explain why Cloudian focused on full AWS S3-compatibility, and how it incorporates prominent open source software projects, like Cassandra, Redis and Puppet into their object-based storage software. The use cases for object-based storage will be covered and how Cloudian approaches the market for object-based storage. The presenters will close-out their presentation by explaining how Cloudian has gone beyond the “cheap and deep” nature of object storage and moved into using its storage clusters to create “smart data” and storage that remains “forever live” on its clusters.

Speaker Bios:

Tim Wessels, MonadCloud LLC (presenting)

http://www.monadcloud.com

Tim created his IT career deploying some of the first Novell NetWare Local Area Networks in New England.  He worked as a network consultant for several premier VARs in the region and in his own IT consulting practice.  He started Oort Cloud Computing in 2010 to assist clients in moving their IT services to the cloud. In 2013, Tim developed MonadCloud to deliver public and private cloud storage solutions.  MonadCloud designs, builds and supports object-based storage clusters using Cloudian’s HyperStore.  Tim is a Cloudian Certified Engineer, and MonadCloud has been designated as a Cloudian Preferred Partner. 


David Barberis, Cloudian Inc. (presenting)

http://www.cloudian.com

David has over 20 years of experience in engineering and architecting technology solutions for a broad range of customers in financial services, telecommunications, healthcare, education and pharmaceuticals.  He worked at Vontu, Opalis Software, 3PAR, Compellent Technologies and Dell prior to joining Cloudian as a Senior Solutions Architect.  David’s approach to successful solution architecting and sales is to educate customers, so they can make the best decisions to achieve their objectives. 

Peggy McGovern, Cloudian Inc.

http://www.cloudian.com

Peggy has over 25 years experience as a successful sales professional in the enterprise storage market. She worked at Box Hill Systems, EMC, FalconStor, 3PAR and HP prior to joining Cloudian as their Northeast Region Sales Director. Peggy’s customers include Fortune 500 companies, as well as start-ups. Throughout the course of her career, she has developed an extensive network of customers, partners and colleagues. 

8:00-8:45 Caringo - A Crash Course on Object Storage. How It’s Helping Businesses in Every Industry and How It Can Help You!

Are you being asked to store petabytes of data, make it searchable, accessible by any enterprise/cloud application or device, and guarantee integrity for decades – all with the same or maybe a modest increase in budget? Guess what? You aren’t alone.

In this session, we will share our experiences working with hundreds of customers of various sizes across a number of different use cases with a focus on: Where object storage sits in the rapidly evolving storage market Trending use cases in the Medical Imaging, Service Provider, Web Content Delivery, Evidence Storage & Open Data Center markets The common issues object storage solves across these use cases How you determine if object storage can solve your data management issues 

Speaker Bios: 

Nilesh Kunvarji - Sr. System Engineer for Caringo Software

Bio: 20+ years experience in IT. 15+ years providing Enterprise Storage Management Solutions for SAN, NAS, backup/recovery, DR solutions, email management, and availability solutions to SMB and large corporate customers and strategic partners. 3+ years with Project/Portfolio Management solutions. 2+ years with Governance, Risk, & Compliance (GRC) solutions. Based in Atlanta, GA he has been part of the Caringo team since September 2014 as the East technical lead.

Ben Canter – East Region Sales Manager

BIO: 15 years’ experience in IT sales with focus on Data Center solutions. Certified and trained on solutions from IBM, HP, VMWare, Cisco, EMC, Microsoft and NetApp, the most recent focus has been on the Software Define Storage area. Based in Douglas, MA he has presented to multiple regional organizations (VTUG, VMUG, CIO Synergy, BNUG) on storage related topics.
results.name: Object Storage - Crash Course and Best Use Cases

results.description:
REGISTER HERE

This class reviews Infant and Child CPR and choke-saving skills for ages birth to 8 years old. It follows the American Heart Association's Family and Friends curriculum. It is not a certification class; but it is specifically created for those who wish to have the hands-on skills and knowledge on how to save the life of someone in their family. The class includes a combination of lecture, discussion, and a lot of hands-on practice. Participants will have their own manikin to practice on during class and a book to take home with them. Additional topics of car seat safety, sleep safety, prevention strategies, childproofing, and basic first aid for children will be reviewed. This is the class that every parent, grandparent, and caregiver should take! 

*** Due to the hands-on practice and serious nature of this class, please make childcare arrangements for your children. (12 people max) 


Thursday October 15th, 2015
6:00–9:00 pm

REGISTER HERE
results.name: Infant & Child CPR, Safety, and First Aid Training

results.description:
FINAL UPDATE:  If you paid attention to the 2015Red Sox season, especially the end and you remember Boston's last 6 World Series teams then you have a great chance of getting a lot of correct answers and winning! Red Sox Trivia will begin at 7:15pm. If you are running late call Laurie's or post a message. Several of us will be at Laurie's early for dinner and drinks at 6pm. We are still looking for groups or individuals to play. There are 6 or 7 people playing so far. If you are alone you can be added to someone's team. You do not have to play to attend.

UPDATE: As an incentive to attend and play any Native who signs up to play for the FIRST TIME will start out with 5 points. A Team of 2 new players could start out with a 10 point lead! Let's give the repeat winners a challenge this week! Trivia will begin at 7:15pm. 

Trivia questions will feature Season Ending Questions and Post Season Team Questions. This is Individual or Group Trivia with Teams of 2 people. You do not need to play in order to attend. For any of you first timers, we actually kind of give you the answers to the questions before we start!

"50 SEASONS of RED SOX TRIVIA" is an EXCLUSIVE EVENT produced by the Red Sox Natives.

Do you know your Red Sox Baseball from the past 50 years? Do you want to compete to win a $50.00 Gift Card to Laurie's 909?

Please join the Red Sox Natives for "50 Seasons of Red Sox Trivia" - The Season Ending & Post Season Edition at Laurie's 909 on Thursday, October 20. We are looking for a few good Red Sox fans to challenge prior winners from the Natives, Wakefield Weeknights and Laurie's 909 regulars. Individual or Group Trivia with teams of 2 people!

This Event is sponsored by Red Sox Natives Sponsor Laurie's 909 and Red Sox Native Bob from Laurie's along with Dan Pranka from New England Sports Tours. 

Here is the Lineup for the evening:

1. Arrive after work or 6:00pm

2. Enjoy cocktails, appetizers, and dinner with other Red Sox Natives and fans. 

3. Talk Baseball with the Red Sox Natives and other Red Sox fans.

4. Register between 6:00pm and 7:00pm to play 50 Seasons of Red Sox Trivia

5. Red Sox Trivia Begins between 7:00pm and 7:15pm.

6. Individual or Group Teams of 2 people answer approximately 75 questions from Seasons 1965 thru 2015. There will be questions from these seasons and the decades.

7. Individual or Groups with most correct answers and points wins a $50.00 Laurie's 909 Gift Card. The 2nd and 3rd place individuals win a Gift Card for a free appetizer from Laurie's 909.

 8. Approximately 1.5 to 2 Hour duration.

 9. Take the 909  train back to Boston if you are attending from the City. 

We will be gathering at the "Nickel" Bar at Laurie's.

There is no cover or trivia entry fee.

Full menu is available until 9:30pm. Late night menu is available afterward. If you have a group of people that want a table reservation for dinner please call Laurie's at[masked] and make a reservation. For information on Laurie's 909 and the menu go to www.lauries909.com. .

If this will be your first time meeting the Red Sox Natives Crew please check out the photos of those who RSVP Yes so you can find the group.

Please remember to maintain your own tab or pay as you order and tip your servers. However, if you sit at a group table a group bill may be provided so please communicate with your server when ordering. Credit Cards may be held by the servers at Laurie's.

Laurie's 909 is Wakefield's newest restaurant and Bar with live entertainment several nights per week and many special E Mail list promotions. Laurie's is located at the Wakefield Commuter Rail Train Station in Wakefield. The Reading and Haverhill Commuter Rail trains stop at Laurie's. Laurie's is easily accessible within 10 minutes from Routes 128, 93, 28 and 1. results.description:
The Boston Traders Meetup will be hosting a monthly options meeting to discuss options trading. This will be an informal gathering of folks who trade options who would like to share their knowledge and learn from each other. 


Beginners and experienced traders are welcome.


This event will be held on the Thursday evening before the monthly expiration Friday.* Holding the meeting at monthly expiration will allow people to discuss the trades that they have put on during the prior month and perhaps to share ideas for trades to put on in the next month. For weekly options traders, the monthly expiry is of little significance unto itself, but for the monthly options traders, it will hold more significance.

Mary-Lou Drozek will be moderating this meeting. She has been trading options for about 5 years and is happy to share ideas.

The meeting location is Panera Bread in Quincy, which has wifi and is visible from the North Quincy T stop on the Red Line. The location could possibly change, so please check back with the event page just to confirm the location before heading off to the meeting.

-------------------------------------------


* Meetup allows for scheduling "the third Thursday of the month," but not the "Thursday before the third Friday of the month," which is what we need. Using the Meetup scheduling system alone without intervention would mean that the third Thursday will be on expiration week except for those months starting on a Friday, as is the case in August of 2014; in which case, the meeting would fall a week after the monthly expiry week. We believe that we will be able to successfully manipulate this consideration in the meetup system to keep the meetings all on the Thursday evening before expiration Friday. If you see a meeting time that isn't the Thursday evening before expiration Friday, please let us know and we will correct it. Thank you.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet in the study room on the middle floor on the parking lot side of the building.

results.description:
Join us at the MIT Stata Center to hear from a powerhouse panel on Smart Transportation Solutions.

Please register for this event at the MIT Enterprise Forum of Cambridge via the following link. Free for members of the Forum. $20 for non-members. 

REGISTER

Listen to the PODCAST between FleetAdvantage President Brian Holland and our own Randy Cronk -- IoT to improve safety, increase productivity and reduce costs via connected capabilities such as dynamic cruise control, enhanced slipstreaming and more . . . . . 

The US population and our need for ‘stuff’ is growing. Yet our transportation systems- roads, transport capacity, and personnel are not meeting the needs of our growing and diverse needs.
Capacity is shrinking just as our demand is growing. Shorter driver hours, environmental and city ordinances shorten delivery hours and ecommerce sales keep growing.
At the same time highway safety issues, as well as risks and threats keep growing.
Government solutions are slow. So industry needs to adjust to the new realities of shrinking capacity and increasing cost and risks.
The transportation market has responded to this challenge with diverse technologies from Telematics, mobility, asset tracking, IoT and integrated cargo and fleet management systems. Trucks and trains are already loaded with technologies that continue to be enhanced to improve on time, safety and cost metrics.

Join us for this informative session from some of the most innovative companies in the transportation sector.
This session will discuss the options and technologies today—IoT, GPS, RFID +Sensors, Streaming data, Location-based systems, visualization, optimization and analytics — that are used to enhance transportation.

Speakers:
Ken Wood, Executive Vice President, Product Management, Descartes Systems

Dennis Groseclose, CEO, TransVoyant

Brian Holland, President and CFO, Fleet Advantage

Andy Souders, Senior Vice President, Products and Strategy, Savi

Marc Held, Founder and CEO, Weft

Moderator:
Ann Grackin, CEO of ChainLink Research
results.name: IoT Takes to the Road: Getting Smarter in Transportation

results.description:
We'll be holding a Meetup event at Peabody Essex Museum that will coincide with the museum celebrating all things small in the world - from Tiny Houses to micro-museums and mini-literature. The inspiration comes from PEM's new exhibition Sizing It Up: Scale in Nature and Art (October 10, 2015-Sept 18, 2016). The "party" will feature a cash bar, live music, gallery experiences, art making and a TINY HOUSE PARKED OUTSIDE! Tiny House Northeast will have one of their "Weelhouses" there: http://www.tinyhousenortheast.com/

Also, Getaway owner, Jon Staff, will talk about his company: http://getaway.house/


PEM has offered to waive the $10 fee for the event for our members! Cash bar, still...  :) 


http://www.pem.org/exhibitions/182-sizing_it_up_scale_in_nature_and_art#The Big Draw and Sizing It Up Mash-Up


http://www.pem.org/calendar/event/1310-small_worlds

Here's a rundown of events! 

ALL NIGHT LONG

ART MAKING | Create Space 1

In the spirit of Alice in Wonderland, make bookmarks and notebooks using playing cards (while supplies last).

BEER TASTING | Atrium

Sample some of Notch Brewing’s best. Sample tickets available at table.

BINOCULAR CHALLENGE | Art Nook

Use reverse binoculars to make everything look tiny, and try to walk a wiggly path.

LIVE MUSIC | Atrium

Watch the talents of DJ Rubix, an 11-year-old student from MMMMAVEN in Cambridge.

MUSEUM POP-UP | Atrium

Enjoy a miniature pop-up exhibition by Somerville’s Mµseum.

TILTSHIFT-O-SCOPE| Level 3

Try out the tilt-shift photography station and then take your own photos around the museum using the Instagram filter. Tag @peabodyessex #PEMpm. While you’re at it, see if you can find our miniature friends lounging around the museum!

TINY HOUSE | Outside Museum Entrance

Tap into the Tiny House movement by checking out a custom home built by Tiny House Northeast.

LITTLE LIBRARY | Atrium

Learn about the miniature books and tiny prints in our collection from PEM’s Phillips Library staff Catherine Robertson, Jennifer Hornsby and Sarah Jennette.

6:15, 7:15 and 8:15 PM

MINI ORIGAMI DEMO | Atrium

Get a closer look at the art of folding miniature origami with exhibition artist Wensdy Whitehead.

7 PM

MOVIE | Morse Auditorium

Shrink down in size and join Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland.

7-8 PM

TINY HOUSE MEET-UP | Maker Lounge

Join members of the Greater Boston Tiny House Enthusiasts meet-up group as they discuss each of their experiences with Tiny Houses and how they got involved in the movement.

7 and 8 PM

ARTIST WORKSHOP | Create Space 2

Gloucester-based artist Ken Riaf helps bring your most vivid memories to life in miniature form and offers examples of his work. Bring small mementos to include in your piece. Each session has 15 spots available; first-come, first-serve.

7:30 PM
AUTHOR TALK | Bartlett Gallery

Join exhibition artist and author Michael Paul Smith as he discusses his work re-creating miniature scenes and shares passages from his book Elgin Park: An Ideal American Town.
_________________________________________________

Transportation info: http://www.pem.org/visit/directions.php

We will carpool as much as possible. Other option by Commuter rail:

Take the MBTA Commuter Rail (Newburyport/Rockport line) to Salem station. Due to construction currently taking place at Salem Station, a pedestrian detour has been constructed. Follow the pathway indicated from the station, up the stairs or access ramp, turning left once you have reached the street level (Bridge St.). At the intersection at Bridge and Washington Streets, proceed on Washington Street. Follow Washington Street, turning left onto the Essex Street pedestrian-way. The museum will be on your right at the end of the pedestrian-way.

The museum is approximately one-half mile from the Salem station. If you are concerned about the walk from the station, buses are available. See the directions listed under "By Bus" for the route numbers.

results.description:
Next Gen Collaboration with Office 365 Groups

Office 365 Groups helps you collaborate by easily bringing together your colleagues and the applications you need to get work done. Office 365 Groups leverages a standard definition for team membership and permissions across Microsoft Exchange, SharePoint, and later Skype for Business, Yammer and the rest of Office 365, managed through Microsoft Azure Active Directory. Come learn about the future of self-service collaboration designed to support dynamic teams in your company.

With the dramatic increase in collaborative content over the past number of years, finding the information or person you need, can become ever more challenging.  Find information and the right person quickly. Delve has established people as a simplifying metaphor to quickly re-find information and stay in the know of what happens around the people who matter to you. Learn how the people experience in Delve helps with finding of information, broad discovery, and discovery of expertise to boost collaboration in your organization. This sessions showcases the advancements of the people experience in Delve which provides a 360 degree view of a person in Office 365, enabling you to discover who does what and who knows what in your organization

Dave Feldman  is Senior Technical Director for SharePoint, Analytics and Custom Development for Atrion, a new England based consulting firm. A technical leader, solution architect, and developer with more than 20 years of experience working with Microsoft technologies, Dave has spent the past nine years dedicated to SharePoint and Business Intelligence. From the largest enterprise customers to small businesses, Dave believes in understanding the business problem or opportunity then driving solutions through deep technical understanding and user focused design.

Dave is the author of "Developing Business Intelligence Apps for SharePoint." by O’Reilly Press and frequently speaks about SharePoint and BI around the Boston, NH, RI, CT, and NY.

The Event is FREE of charge. Food and beverages will be provided. Please register at our web site, www.BosO365UserGroup.com or at http://bit.ly/1LSamqo.

We hope to see you there!

The organizers
results.how_to_find_us: info@BosO365UserGroup.com
results.name: Next Gen Collaboration with Office 365 Groups

results.description:
The mythological origin place of the Incas was the source of academic controversy for some time. In the early twentieth century, Machu Picchu was thought to be the place where Manco Capac, the first Inca king, originated. However, other evidence indicates that Manco Capac came from the Andean town of Pacariqtambo. Gary Urton will discuss these different perspectives, focusing on how an ancient adobe wall at the center of Pacariqtambo links its history with Machu Picchu's, and how its study can inform our understanding of larger-scale adobe buildings, from the time of the Incas into the deep pre-Columbian past.

Gary Urton, Dumbarton Oaks Professor of Pre-Columbian Studies, Harvard University

Free and open to the public. Complimentary event parking available at the 52 Oxford Street Garage.
results.name: Society, Politics, and Burial in the Andes: A Lecture

results.description:
Folks, we are moving this meeting out one week to the 15th.

It will now be Thursday, October 15th at 6:30 in Hudson at Mike's house.

Charlie

========================

We have many seats left open for this interesting event next Thursday the 8th. Hope you can make it.
=========================
Original Announcement:

Mike Blake, our friend, founder, RVP, CS, CWJ, etc. will present wines of the Cotes-du-Rhone region.

As you probably know, this region is fascinating, with wines blended from a wide range of grapes grown in a relatively warm region with many soil types that produce a variety of wine characteristics.

Mike has been working with wines from this region recently and will have some interesting examples and background for us.

This meeting is being held earlier than normal in October to fit Mike's schedule.

Perhaps Mike can comment on this subject and add some detail at some time before October comes around.

In any case please save the date and we'll all look forward to these wines.

Charlie
results.name: Cotes du Rhone at AWS Hudson - Oct. 15th

results.description:
Klarna, a new payment technology, is hosting this event at the Four's in Boston. They are providing free appetizers and there is a cash bar for anyone that wants drinks. Klarna will be doing a quick 15 minute presentation on eCommerce checkout and how Klarna can greatly improve checkout conversions. 


The rest of our time can be spent networking and sharing useful tips about eCommerce and the industry.

Klarna is changing the game with how people buy, especially on mobile devices.  We eliminate the need for registrations or logins and take 100% of the risk on the transaction. Klarna on average is driving conversion upwards of 20%.

With Klarna, new customers only need to enter top-of-mind information including email, zip code and billing address. For returning customers, it’s a one tap payment experience. By offering all payment methods in one single buying flow, we separate the buying from the paying and allow consumers to pay at their convenience.
results.name: eCommerce Checkout Optimization

results.description:
Why All The Realtime? - An intro to RethinkDB, an open source, NoSQL, distributed document-oriented database (Daniel Alan Miller) 

RethinkDB is the first open-source scalable database for the realtime web. It exposes an exciting new access model -- instead of polling for changes, the developer can tell the database to continuously push updated query results to applications in realtime. 

Daniel Alan Miller is a resident Developer Evangelist with RethinkDB. Having tried to build realtime applications in the past, he was drawn to RethinkDB's change feeds like a moth to a bug zapper. While technology is always cool, building stuff for people is even cooler. Daniel hopes to help everyone do just that with RethinkDB. He loves gelato :ice_cream: and one day hopes to deliver it in realtime to everyone everywhere.
results.name: Why All The Realtime? - An intro to RethinkDB

results.description:
It's been a wonderfully hot summer filled with many things bike advocacy. It's that time of year to bring summer to a close and gear up for the fall with a great celebration of the Boston Cyclists Union's work this year and what is to come! There are alot of exciting things happening at the Bike Union. Come celebrate with us to learn all about it. 


This event is all-ages (ID required for beer & wine). 

To gain entry you simply have to be a member of the Bike Union, the organization that is changing not just Boston, but setting examples for all of New England. Lucky for you, joining is a very easy thing to do. You can join at the door, online at bostoncyclistsunion.org, or by buying a ticket on Eventbrite.

This event may sell out! Even if you are already a member, tickets are recommended.

Tickets available on Eventbrite 

Invite your friends on Facebook

Montague Bikes, El Pelon, Cambridge Brewing Co., Downeast Cider Company, Whole Foods, Ashmont Cycles, Perceval Brewing Company, Life Alive, Flatbread, Bikabout, Lärabar,

results.description:
Do you have a family member or friend who wants to get in shape but doesn't know how to start? Help get them walking or jogging.

We have 2 groups:

Our Walking Group will exercise and encourage one another towards walking a 5K. 

Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.

Using CoolRunning.com’s Couch To 5K program we introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 8-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles).

•  Anyone from the community can participate. 


• Led by experienced runners. 


• Mondays through Thursdays 6:30pm-7:15pm; Saturdays 10 am-10:45 am 


• 45 minute time commitment (3 days a week) 


• Goal of jogging and finishing a 5K

• Our Fall session will begin on Monday, September 28.

(Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.)

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group at the Dedham High School Track.

Our Couch to 5K will end with the "Dedham Turkey Trot" on Thanksgiving morning.
results.name: Fall Couch to 5K

results.description:
"Energy Deregulation:  a $500 Billion Frontier"

Bruce Vega and Alex Rhalimi will present how energy deregulation is the and what that means for ecologically-informed visions of human life on the planet.

Warren Buffett and Bill Gates each has said that energy deregulation is the biggest transfer of wealth in the history of business, and it's ongoing (from The Motley Fool).

Learn about direct carbon reduction (vs. offsets) and sustainability impacts.


Thursday evening discussions with community forming.
Discussions and Q&A will follow each presentation.
For some interesting comparisons, bring your utility (light, electricity) bills.

Consider bringing food to share (with plates and utensils).
results.name: Energy Deregulation: the $500 Billion Frontier (250 Elm Street, Davis Square)

results.description:
YES - park in the lot

NO - don't cut in line

YES - get there early (doors at 7. get there by 6:45)

YES - dress for stargazing

YES - look for the meetup sign, or just talk to the people around you. Everyone here is Nerdy and Fun whether or not they found out about this event from this meetup group.

We generally sit on the back left of the auditorium. Or we get there too late and end up in the overflow room. THEN we try to find each other in telescope lines on the roof.

MAYBE - we'll go out somewhere after, maybe not. Folks might be tired, or hard to collect into a group, or self-organizing and looking for beer, or burgers.


- H

From the Harvard stop on the MBTA Red Line, take any bus or trackless trolley going west on Concord Avenue in Cambridge (Arlmont Village and Belmont Center buses; Huron Avenue trolley) and get off at the Observatory Hill stop.

For more information go to  http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/events or call 617.495.7461.


The CfA would prefer that attendees not take pictures, but if you decide to, please do not use a flash.

******************************

From the CfA:


Watch It Live

Big Bang Astronomy from the Ends of the Earth


John Kovac, CfA

In the frozen wasteland of Antarctica, temperatures can drop to -100°F and the Sun disappears below the horizon for half the year. Yet the same harsh conditions that make survival so challenging also make the South Pole an ideal location for astronomy. From here, scientists are studying the faint glow of the Big Bang known as the cosmic microwave background. Their goal is nothing less than to tease out the subtle signs of cosmic inflation and open a window onto the birth of the universe. After a roller-coaster ride of discovery and setback, the quest continues. At the helm: John Kovac, who has traveled to the South Pole more than 20 times in his career. John Kovac is an associate professor of astronomy at Harvard and leader of the BICEP2 Collaboration.


******************************

NOTE: if anyone would like to be an assistant organizer to help run various* events please contact me - Heather

*various = various science and nerdy events around town, and NOT the ones that only market your own event/product.  (SPAM=no)

The waiting list and attendance limit is for the CfA to have a more accurate attendance count.

Please RSVP truthfully. 

If you end up on the waiting list and you REALLY like the topic you can show up anyways as this is a public event.

Thanks!

H

results.description:
This monthly Meetup is a place to learn tunes and to play them slowly with other musicians. The tunes we play can be found here (Sheet Music). Since the list is getting large we have started selecting a rotating list of about ten tunes a month that we will definitely play so that new members can have a chance to play along without learning every tune right away. I update this list and email it monthly.

This is still a new group, and how we go about learning and playing is still a work in progress. But the goal is to have fun, and to get together with others who enjoy playing Irish music. Musicians of all levels are welcome. Since the goal here is for everyone to play, new members are encouraged to suggest tunes from the list and to suggest tunes to add to it. If the group as a whole knows a tune well, we'll play it slowly a couple of times, and then pick the tempo up a bit. 

Note on tempo

If you have gone to a typical Irish Session, we play a little faster than half that speed. But we'll start tunes slowly enough that everyone should be able to play along and learn by ear. If you haven't been to a session it is best to just show up and see if the tempo suits you :)  If you like metronomes...  For Reels (4/4), Hornpipes (4/4) and Polkas (2/4) set the metronome from 100 to 140 BPM and play one quarter note per click. For Double Jigs (6/8), Slip Jigs (9/8), and Single Jigs (12/8) set the metronome from 65 to 95 BPM and play three eighth notes per click. 

Directions

By Subway

The closest Red Line stop is Davis Square. From Davis Square you can either walk Northwest on Holland Street or take the bus (the 87 or the 88) to Teele Square. It is about a 10 minute walk between Davis and Teele Square. You can recognize Teele Square as a 5-way intersection with a small triangular island having a sign that says Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection.

By Bus

The 87, 88, and 89 buses stop in Teele Square.  The 87 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and Arlington Center. The 88 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. The 89 bus runs between Sullivan Square (Orange Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. You'll want to get off the bus in Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection. The 77 bus runs between Harvard and Arlington Heights. You can walk from Mass Ave to Teele Square.

By Car

There is parking behind the West Somerville School that is one block West of the church. Parking there is available after 5PM even though the signs are somewhat ambiguous. From Powderhouse, turn onto Curtis, heading up the hill toward Tufts. Take the first left turn from Curtis onto Raymond Street. Ignore the NO LEFT TURN sign, as it is only in effect during rush hours. Raymond runs behind the school. The lot is about half a block down Raymond on the left.

Street parking is also available one block away on Packard Avenue from Powderhouse Blvd on the hill to the Tufts University campus. Pay attention to street signs to avoid parking in a restricted area.

See the map at: http://clarendonhillchurch.org/...

Accessibility

The church has a lift that requires someone to move from a wheelchair to the chair on the lift. I haven't had time to look at this yet, but I will have someone show it to me over the holidays.

results.description:
Thursday night figure drawing has an emphasis on one long pose, giving time for more involved approaches.  Painters and drawers welcome to this informal and supportive group, meeting in Damon's painting studio.


A few warm up quick poses will be followed by a long (2.5 hour) pose, with breaks for the model.

Members pay $10 as on Monday night, non-member drop-in is $25.  Membership fee for each month of $25 brings discounts on drawing and painting sessions and classes.  Pay membership fee online (see left-hand column) via paypal or credit card, or in person with cash or check.  First session of the month would therefore be $35 ($25 membership fee plus $10 session fee) and each session thereafter would be $10. 

Thanks!
results.how_to_find_us: corner of Central Street and Vernon Street, big brick building.  Park on Vernon street in front of building or in lot behind building.
results.name: Long Pose Drawing and Painting Session
