results.description:
Sometimes we hide our true selves.  How would your life be different if you were able to connect authentically with others from your true self?

Join us this evening at our MetroCharles Heartbeat Salon...

... where you'll have an opportunity to explore how you see yourself and and how you relate to others.

Sometimes we make assumptions about others, and about ourselves, that get in the way of authentic connection in the present moment.  These assumptions can cloud our view of each other.  What if you could see yourself and others more clearly and make better choices?


Freedom of choice for each participant is emphasized; you are always at choice to explore at your own comfort level, while being encouraged to stretch your boundaries just a little.  This will be a supportive environment designed to create real, fulfilling connections.

To prepare for the evening... 

Please think about the following prior to coming to the event:

1.  Identify for yourself three qualities of a satisfying relationship.

2. How would that kind of relationship make you feel?

Our Leaders This Evening...

Karen Wagner and Elizabeth Carrington are passionate about creating experiences that allow us to tap into authentic contact with one another and ourselves.  They have facilitated four previous exploration and relaxation retreats in Western Massachusetts: “Creating a Passionate Life”, “Practicing Radical Self-Love”, “The Power of Choice”, and “Creating REALationships”. They were the first facilitators to ever lead a Hearbeat Salon.  A full house of members enjoyed their experience. (See comments.)

Elizabeth and Karen facilitate workshops that focus on intimacy, transparency, freedom, and the power of community in a context of adventure and curiosity.    They blend their backgrounds of diverse personal growth experiences to create unique exercises, inviting us to make shifts in our lives that we desire.  Their personal growth venture is now called “Evolve”.  This evening stands on its own but is also a taste of the processes and explorations from their next Evolve retreat, “Dream Bigger: Create the Life You Want” coming up soon on the weekend of November 13-15. 

Please join us to welcome Karen and Elizabeth to our MetroCharles Heartbeat Salon in Somerville, to explore what authentic connection could mean to you.

Links


For Newbies: 
  *  What is a Heartbeat Salon? 
  *  Guidelines for Attending a Heartbeat Salon .

For Veterans: 
  * Find a Heartbeat Salon Near You . 
  * Calendar of Upcoming Heartbeat Salons. 

For Hosts: 
  * Hints on How to Host a Heartbeat Salon . 
  * Topics from Past Heartbeat Salons .

For Presenters: 
  * Hints on How to Present at a Heartbeat Salon .

Suggestion Box: 
  * Suggestions for a Heartbeat Salon (topics, locations, etc) .
results.name: HBS-MetroCharles: The Art and Skill of Connection

results.description:
We'll run routes along the Charles River Greenway, Riverwalk, Newton and neighborhoods of Waltham, with options to extend for those who are looking to add distance (or end early!) Afterward we'll hop into the bar for post-run drinks. 

We meet in front of Shoppers Cafe and leave at 7:00p. There should be plenty of parking on the street and in the neighborhood. All levels are welcome, with a broad range of paces!

Runs are typically 3-5 miles. 

As our daylight becomes more limited, it is highly recommended to at least wear bright clothing, and also to consider bringing a reflective vest and/or lamp.  


See you there!

results.description:
"When people see some things as beautiful,
other things become ugly.
When people see some things as good,
other things become bad.

Being and non-being create each other.
Difficult and easy support each other.
Long and short define each other.
High and low depend on each other.
Before and after follow each other.

Therefore the Master
acts without doing anything
and teaches without saying anything.
Things arise and she lets them come;
things disappear and she lets them go.
She has but doesn't possess,
acts but doesn't expect.
When her work is done, she forgets it.
That is why it lasts forever."


We will continue with reading and interpreting the text.(line by line and verse by verse)

results.name: Tao Te Ching by Stephen Mitchell verse2

results.description:
Cambridge meetup is back! We are going to have this event every other week!


http://www.championscambridge.com/


As usual, please bring your driver's license or passport, if you would like to have alcohol. They are strict about IDs, No IDs no booze.  But people under 21 are welcome as well to this event  - Champions is almost as much a restaurant as a bar and you need not order a drink.


You are responsible for your own consumption and please start and settle your own tab. Please bring your Credit/Debit card or cash and start your tab with the waiter.    Please be sure to tip - we suggest 20% as it is a lot of extra trouble for them to do separate tabs, but it saves us work and allows people to leave at different times.  But first be sure that the tip is not included already - it usually is not but occasionally is, at 18%, if there is a large group, in which case you need not tip additional.  (If you know the price of what you ordered, and add 6.25% MA meals tax, and that is the total, they have NOT added in the tip.)

RSVP required. Please sign up. If you RSVP "Yes," but your plans change, please change your RSVP to "No" so others can sign up. Deadline for reservation is 3PM as we need to get an accurate head count for the reservation. On nights when we are expecting many people, we limit the RSVP number to 27. However, if you'd like to attend, but can't RSVP, send a message to an organizer, as we may be able to get you in.


Champions is located at MIT/Kendall Sq. station. If you come from Boston side, you will see right in front of the T exit. It is part of the Marriott. Even though the address is listed as 50 Broadway, you can really only see it from the Main street side.  We are usually either in the separate room toward the Marriott lobby, or else at two long central tables in the room to the right of the host station.
results.how_to_find_us: We usually make a reservation. Please RSVP by 3pm on the day of the event. Ask hostess for Japanese/English Meetup group.

results.description:
Join us every third Thursday September - April for our Story Slam series. Come and share your own story or listen to outrageous true tales from here and beyond. Think you can tell a great story? Share your five minute (or less) story for the audience. Story tellers drop their name in a hat and are chosen at random to compete against other story tellers for the best theme related story of the evening. 3 winners are selected by the audience and will receive prizes. There is a cash bar, complementary appetizers, and free parking.

Tickets: $10.00 in advance| $15.00 at the door

Advance tickets are available through eventbrite!

2015 - 2016 Themes
September 17 – Ouch
October 15 – Jinx
November 19 – Audacity
December 17 – Sibling Rivalry
January 21 – Small World
February 18 – Exit Strategy
March 17 – Respect
April 21 – Death & Taxes
results.name: Monthly Story Slam: Jinx

results.description:
The time-honored tradition of saving seeds merges botany, history, observation, and experience. Lee Buttala, editor of The Seed Garden, by the Seed Savers Exchange, will provide an overview of plant reproduction and pollination, how to preserve varietal traits, and the many reasons for saving seeds from your favorite heirloom and open-pollinated plants. Even if you don’t have seeds to save, Lee will help you understand the origin of that heirloom tomato that you picked up at the farmers market and share knowledge that has been passed down through generations by farmers and home gardeners for preserving the plants that sustain us.
Fee $5
Free parking

Register at my.arboretum.harvard.edu or call[masked]-5277.

Lee Buttala is an Emmy Award–winning television producer of Martha Stewart Living and was the creator, producer, and director of Cultivating Life, a PBS series on outdoor living and gardening. He has written for The New York Times, Martha Stewart Living, New York, and Metropolitan Home. He also served as the preservation program manager for the Garden Conservancy and has studied garden design at the Kyoto University of Art and Design, the Chelsea Physic Garden, and the New York Botanical Garden.
results.name: The Art and Practice of Saving Seeds

results.description:
Award-winning Fresh Seafood on Boston's North Shore

The Village Restaurant in Essex Thursday @ 7:15 pm

Come join North Shore Social for an amazing dinner and fantastic company. I found this gem of restaurants and can't wait to share it again with the group.

"My favorite is Essex's Village Restaurant ... There is something special about the clams here," says acclaimed New York Times food writer, Mark Bittman. "No clam lover should pass through Cape Ann without sampling a plateful of the best soft-shells in the universe." (see more Village Restaurant reviews here.)

So, what's the secret? Quality & freshness. Our clams are dug right here—in Essex & Ipswich—by local clammers. We know every clammer personally and they know us. They know we only buy the sweetest, freshest, highest quality clams. It's that simple—and it's been that way since we opened in 1961.

The same goes for all of our fish and seafood. It's fresh. It's local. It's real.

The world's top food critics love The Village in Essex (see why). But don't take their word for it. Come, taste for yourself. Enjoy classic New England cuisine with a contemporary flair at affordable prices.

http://www.wedigclams.com/

MULTIPLE MEETUP EVENT SPONSORED BY:


NORTH SHORE SOCIAL


PLEASE RSVP FOR THIS EVENT IN ONLY ONE GROUP

AND KEEP YOUR RSVP UP TO DATE!

Be safe, yours truly Eirini Kay

SEE YOU THERE!!!

</a>

<a href="http://www.eventbrite.com/"></a>

<a href="http://www.eventbrite.com/"></a>

<a href="http://www.eventbrite.com/"></a>

“The Greek Night Party was so much fun. Thank you so much. The food Eirini cooked was out of this world. Eirini did such a good job organizing the event and making sure everyone had a blast. I would recommend North Shore Social to everyone.”

Need a little more convincing?

Click here to see the rest of our 80+ testimonials!

Manifest and Magnetize Your Desires!

A channeled guided meditative journey within to connect to the All that You Are and to manifest and magnetize your desires into your life!

Once in a deeply relaxed state in our comforting and supportive space, you will be guided to open yourself to the unlimited possibilities life has to offer you.  You will visualize your desires, co-creating with source and your highest and greatest self! 

You will 'marinate' in the energies of Source and receive what you need (on all levels) at the time to assist you in manifesting your desires and surrendering to the universe and allow them to flow into your life - in their own perfect way! 

All levels of spiritual beings are welcome.  Simply being in the energies is healing in and of itself!

Nicol will use channeled energy and sound to facilitate this group - you will only receive what you need at the time and will never receive more than you can handle.

Please note that by the power of your own divine free will - you are free to live your life on your terms once you leave our space.  The energies are intended to assist you in your physical life!

Energy Exchange $10 at the door.

Doors open at 7:15pm and the group will start at 7:30pm.  Please note the building is locked after 6pm so you will need to call up to get buzzed in - instructions are to the right of the door. [masked] if you have trouble.

Nicol is a certified spiritual counselor and reiki master practicing in energy work for over 15 years! 

www.essencehealing.net  to learn more about Nicol and Essence of Healing

results.description:
Events for the Public

The Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics sponsors a variety of free programs for the public. Among these events are Observatory Nights held on the third Thursday of the month (excluding June, July and August). Observatory Nights feature a nontechnical lecture and telescopic observing from the observatory roof if weather permits. The lectures are intended for high-school age and older audiences but children are also welcome. We also sponsor a variety of other special observing events throughout the year. No reservations are necessary, but seating is limited to the auditorium's capacity. Admission is free.

These events--unless otherwise noted--are held in Phillips Auditorium (at the rear of the CfA complex near Madison Street and large parking lot), 60 Garden Street, Cambridge, about 1 mile west of Harvard Square. Parking lots marked for Observatory Staff are open to the public on event nights. Parking is free.

The Observatory does not host private events.

Monthly Observatory Night
Thursday, October 15, 2015
7:30 pm:  Big Bang Astronomy from the Ends of the Earth


John Kovac, CfA


In the frozen wasteland of Antarctica, temperatures can drop to -100°F and the Sun disappears below the horizon for half the year. Yet the same harsh conditions that make survival so challenging also make the South Pole an ideal location for astronomy. From here, scientists are studying the faint glow of the Big Bang known as the cosmic microwave background. Their goal is nothing less than to tease out the subtle signs of cosmic inflation and open a window onto the birth of the universe. After a roller-coaster ride of discovery and setback, the quest continues. At the helm: John Kovac, who has traveled to the South Pole more than 20 times in his career. John Kovac is an associate professor of astronomy at Harvard and leader of the BICEP2 Collaboration.

For more information, including accessibility, or to sign up for the events mailing list, call the Public Affairs Office, (617)[masked] or email [masked]. Please request sign-language interpretation at least 2 weeks before the event. Current sky information is available. Entrance is at the west of the CfA complex, near Madison Street and large parking lot. The CfA is easily reached by public transportation. From the Harvard MBTA Station (Red Line), take any bus or trackless trolley going west on Concord Avenue (Arlmont Village and Belmont Center buses, Huron Avenue trolleys) and get off at "Observatory Hill."

Source(s): http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/publicevents

Also available via their YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/ObsNights
results.name: Monthly Observatory Night

results.description:
Hello! Fall is here and Cab Franc is in the air. Let's celebrate by getting together at an adorable neighborhood BYOB restaurant Kitchen on Common in Belmont to have a blind tasting of Cab Franc wines.


The chef, Joh, has created a special prix fixe just for our group! The menu will include a choice of soup or salad, an entree choice of veggie pasta, chicken or steak and a cookie platter. Coffee and tea will also be served after dinner. The cost will be $45 pp including tax and tip, (Of course extra tips are welcome :)) If would be easiest if you could bring cash.

Also, bring a bottle of Cab Franc in the $20-40 range to share with the group in our blind tasting format. The restaurant will provide glassware. 

Cabernet Franc, that Jancis Robinson describes  as the feminine side of Cabernet Sauvignon, is often used as a blending grape with Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot in Bordeaux blends.  As a single varietal, its spice and structure make it a wonderful food wine. Did you know Cab Franc even has its own holiday? It's August 30. Mark your calendars for 2016!
results.name: Join me for an evening of Cab Franc at Kitchen On Common in Belmont

results.description:
Greetings to all the incubators old and new!

Come on out to this weeks incubator for another week of silliness, laughter, and of course improv games and exercises galore.

This group is for everyone whether you are an actor, improv comedien looking for extra practice or just looking to destress from your week and do something random, fun, and maybe a bit challenging for the brain.  Smile and come on down, your up next on the cambridge improv incubator!

Again, no previous acting or improv experience required.

Smile!  Hope to see you Thursday.

Any questions or concerns let me know!

Cheers!

Peace, prosperity, and happiness,

Jason J.

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
